review_body: The location next to the airport bus terminal is very convenient, but you need to use the metro or taxi, in order to reach the tourist areas. The rooms and the service are excellent as well as the breakfast.

This was our second two week stay and as before the hotel, (executive floor) room and quality of service were excellent. From the lounge staff to the doorman everyone was polite, proactive and most efficient. The hotel is ideally located for getting around Tokyo and beyond with access to the Hanzomon line (SkyTree at one end and Shibuya at the other) through the hotel basement, and the Asakusa and Hibiya lines a five minute walk away.The Sumida river is close by and a lovely place to walk along in the day or evening.A special mention to the little flower shop in the basement - fantastic arrangements for the room at reasonable prices.The hotel contains several restaurants and in the immediate neighbourhood there are literally dozens of places to eat and drink.
user_name:
cdilla
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Have stayed here a number of times in recent years, the high level of service stays the same. Recently refurbished gym is good, executive lounge on the top floor with a great view. Rooms could perhaps do with modernisation and the lifts are still annoyingly slow, but recommended on the whole.

This hotel is in a convenient location : next to TCat terminal for transport to/ from airport. Subway next door and lots of restaurants nearby. I would definitely recommend staying on the Executive floors rather than standard floors. The 20th floor executive lounge had a super breakfast - fabulous buffet selections and was a good place to enjoy evening drinks with a view. The bell and concierge staff were all very friendly and tried to help in every way possible. Would definitely stay again.
user_name:
PF2500
New York City, New York

review_body: This was my first visit to the Royal Park Hotel. The service was excellent from the front desk to the lounge. The location is central to restaurants and bars. I had multiple business meetings in the main floor restaurant / lounge area. The experience was excellent.

Lovely hotel in every respect. The 20th floor receptions for happy hour, dinner options, and full breakfast is a significant benefit. Staff were consistently super friendly and efficient. Enthusiastically recommended.

We stayed for 6 nights in this excellent hotel. The rooms are of a high standard and service was excellent. The hotel is well situated with numerous restaurants within a 10 minute walk. The nearest metro and train station is a 5 minute walk away.Highly recommended

Reasonably good hotel that is well connected to the airport; well connected to walk to major sights and a real bonus that the limousine bus terminal from the airports is across the street.Excellent service was the stand out. Helpful concierge. The decor is a bit dated. Good gym / spa floor which is newly refitted.Executive floors with lounge access good.We were in Tokyo when the World Cup was on specially the Typhoon - we were help up in the hotel for a day and there was an earthquake. Perhaps a note from the management to explain the hotel would be safe and a concession on food and drinks may have been a nice touch (as I understand other hotels did!). Something to think about....

The staff at the hotel are amazing! The staff are so polite and welcoming. The hotel rooms are great size considering the options in such a mega city and the vast range in costs.Location is perfect! Easy bus limousine transfer from Haneda to the TCAT. The TCAT is literally next door to the hotel. There is a subway with direct access to the hotel. It takes 10 minutes to get to Tokyo Station that also is the location for the Shinkansen. With subway immediately adjacent to the hotel anyway in Tokyo is easily accessible. The hotel provides a smart phone during your stay so you save on international data roaming!I found after a busy day and/or night exploring it was nice to return to the neighbourhood the hotel is located.

This hotel is pefectly located, next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal and, directly abve Suitengamae subway station. Genuinely 4.5 stars with agood selection of restaurants and very attentive staff. A perfect base at a reasonable price for a stay in Tokyo.

this is located in the business district of Tokyo and is amazing. The service is good, it has more than 8 restaurants (i did not count how many) , the food is amazing, location is very good and its was a perfect getaway for us

We had an outstanding stay! Hotel staff were terrific and most spoke English but every one smiled and helped. We had paid for an Executive King (with Executive lounge access for breakfast and drinks) but were upgraded to a gorgeous suite. We could not have had a better overnight! The bathroom was split into a toilet room with a sink and a separate room with large shower/double sinks. Great location --- right opposite airport bus terminal (non-stop to Narita or Haneda) and hotel provided bell service to help us with our luggage.

Check inn staff was helpful and courteous.Very functional hotel. Room was nice and clean. Very close to tokyo station- north maranouchi exit. In a good area with lots of stuff nearby.View was that of a road from the 10th floor so nothing great.
user_name:
thesharma
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: I have been staying here a few times/year for 4 years. The recent “Renovation” of the pool/gym added only about 20% additional space to the gym but eliminated the pool and Japanese bath/sauna area, a huge loss in total value for the guests. The Club level lounge is, as always, lovely and well maintained by the friendly team, but it’s hard to make up for the loss of exercise pool and relaxing bath area. A shame ...

The hotel looks grand from the street level and the lobby and yet inside, in the rooms, it is functional and down-to-Earth. In a good way. The location is very useful. High tea in the cafeteria is popular. The only complaint that I have is that in the heat of summer, it is only possible to cool the rooms to about 23 deg C and this is not comfortable when I'm traveling for business and still need to wear a suit-and-tie. Not to worry too much.
長くなるので詳細は割愛しますが、このホテルのホスピタリティは最悪です。最低限のことも出来てません。施設も最悪です。朝食も値段の割にたいしたことはありません。家族に申し訳ない気持ちになりました。次に泊まることはないでしょうし、おススメもしません。This hotel is too terrible.I can’t recommend to stay at this hotel.

I stay in Royal Park more often support from front office staff is awesome, room is very spaces and more comfort, food taste in restaurants also good worth for money if I need any support hotel staff Mr Sivayy, Mr Karim and Mr Harsha supporting me a lot

Had the same experience as a previous reviewer who felt he was not treated correctly by the front desk.I have stayed at the Royal Park three times before some years ago for business, and really liked it. However, it seems like times have changed. This time, about two weeks before our stay, I emailed with the hotel / front desk to book two interconnected rooms. I was told I had a reservation and a price. A few days before we should arrive, I asked the hotel to reconfirm, which they did, but the price had gone up! After some back & forth they accepted the original price. When we landed in Tokyo Haneda, we called the hotel to finally reconfirm, as the correspondence had been slightly confusing. Then it turned out that they did not have any interconnecting rooms, and had no reservation in my name. Basically, they had no idea what we were talking about.Needless to say, we immediately booked another hotel. And by that maneuver we discovered that the price we had been quoted from the hotel was more than double from what we would pay for Royal Park, if we booked via hotel-dot-com.I am thus sorry to say that this hotel seems to have some serious issues with providing good service towards international costumers.

Booked 3 family rooms through Hotels.com with Buffet Breakfast stated clearly and Executive Lounge access. 4 children in total. Then a day after booking came the notice that the Buffet Breakfast only for 2 adults and children have to pay almost 2000 Japanese Yen per child and cannot even enter Lounge during evening times. Asked for clarification. Despite the message with the narration that typically responds within a day, after 10 days still no response. Asked if they could accommodate room only without lounge and breakfast but with a lower rate, no response. Asked if anything could be done, no response. This is very unacceptable. Beware when booking through Hotels.com when it says Buffet Breakfast. It gave me the wrong impression, and there was no warning that my impression was wrong. Only after booking.

very clean and professional hotel. some of the furniture and decor is a bit dated but everything else is great. friendly staff and they even give you a free android unlimited data text and calls even for international. I would definitely recommend for tourists looking for a reasonably priced hotel

Terrific western breakfast.Close to restaurants, bars and public transportation.Narita airport TCAT adjacent to the hotelMy room smelled like someone smoked in it last week but they didn't have another room available, even though it was a non smoking room.Do not eat in the restaurant on the 20th floor, it is way over priced and isn't very good.Concierge is very friendly.

As stated above we had to return again to the executive rooms as the lounge is so good in terms of breakfast, evening snacks and generous wines and spirits. All the positives reported here are spot on. We forgive the closure of the swimming pool as now you get a "Handy" free of charge, which we used as a Wi-fi hot spot for our phones for just Y300/day. As it was raining it was so convenient to take the lift direct to the subway ticket hall. The service and the staff are quite exceptional in this hotel, but the rooms are a little dated.Last time we were here we didn't find any exceptional local restaurants but this was because we were walking in the wrong direction! If you turn towards Ningyocho station after a couple of blocks you have a great selection of restaurants including the top rated Imahan restaurant for spectacular Shabu Shabu and Sukiyaki.Don't forget with the TCat Terminal on the opposite block makes this one of Tokyo's best connected hotels for NRT and HND.

Right next to the T-CAT, a straghtforward bus ride from Haneda Airport, I'd strongly recommend this hotel as your stay while you transit to other cities around Japan, or just stay there while you take the subway anywhere around. Unfortunately, I only booked for a night before moving onto other parts of Tokyo...Staff there is friendly and speaks perfect English, the people around the neighbourhood is (still) reserved but very friendly. I cannot remember when was the last time a staff at the concierge took initiative to come up to me from a distance away and help me with the luggage upon check in and check out, even when in other parts of Japan.Room was satisfactory and clean. I'm a smoker, and I didn't have a brave the weather to take a break. They have a clean smoking room on the second floor.Breakfast wise was simple enough. It was rather easy to get a taxi at the front of the hotel. But though the train stations are relatively nearby, due to the tiled pavement, I'd recommend you travel around with luggage equipped with strong wheels.Overall, we are very satisfied with the hotel and will certainly return and this time we will be staying more days.

The hotel is at a great location, staff is really friendly and the rooms are very clean. Breakfast was really good with great choices and variety for a western menu. Compared to other hotels in the area very spacious. I wish the gym was open.

This hotel is a bit outdated but definitely has its pros and cons.Pros:- Location as it is just above a metro station and no need to get out of the hotel to get to the metro- Each room is equipped with HANDY, which is a smart phone that you take with you wherever you go and you have internet all the time. Also, for 6-7 countries in the world, you can make phone calls for free...- Spacious rooms - Bathrooms are with a bath tab - Proximity of good and various grocery shops and restaurants Cons:- Expensive breakfast - Outdated rooms for the hotel classification - A bit pricey roomsThere are several restaurants, but we didn't visit them. Paolo, the hotel manager was a great support to us and provided many valuable information. Other staff very responsive and helpful.

Great place to stay with wonderful amenities. The room is well appointed with a refrigerator, free beverages, toiletries and extras like slippers and robes make it a nice place to stay. It is near the airport and provides a shuttle to the airport. Nearby restaurants.

A great hotel in a great location, comfortable and worth staying again.The service provided is outstanding – for example, it was raining pretty hard and of course, I did not have an umbrella, but the Royal Park had many to spare!Pro:• Great location – close to the famous now closed, Tsujiki Fish Market, great restaurants, subway station. • Great breakfast buffet – mix of traditional Japanese and continental. So you can have the traditional rice, miso soup, grilled fish, natto, along with bread/cheese, yogurt, coffee, tea, juice (orange, apple, cranberry)…there is a coffee machine that dispenses green tea latte – it was a great find!• Laundry service – quick, efficient, and affordable, about $5 to launder/press a dress shirt within a day• Rooms are comfortable (and large even to American standards) with great and attentive staff• Right next door to the airport shuttle bus – for ~$8, 30 minutes later, you are in Haneda Airport – a bit more and longer for Narita Airport. Con:• GYM – non-existent. During my stay, it was being renovated so the “temporary” gym consisted of four converted rooms – three of the rooms had a threadmill and bicycle; the last room had a few yoga mats, dumbbells (not many)…needless to say, the gym was disappointing.NOTE: There are TWO Royal Park Hotels in the area, this is the 2-1-1 Nihonbashi property.If it were not for the non-existent gym, the rating would have been better! Or give guests the option to work out elsewhere at the real gym.

It is an old hotel but well maintained.You may feel a bit on the decor but it is still very comfortable. Located on top of the Suitengu Mae station, it is very convenient to Tokyo station area as well as Shibuya and areas like Ginza and Omotesando. The lobby is very big and the staff is very attentive, multilingual. The rooms are well maintained , the bathroom has many good amenities as well as a kettle and teas/ coffee available. They have a in room cell phone, that you can carry with you. This is a very good thing, you can use as a local cell phone with private number or use for roaming to your cell/ tablet. It is a very cool and helpful gadget since this is what all travelers look for in a new place nowadays. There are many restaurants in the hotel as well as convenience stores just across the hotel. The surroundings are interesting as it still keeps somehow an atmosphere of old Tokyo. It is very close to the TCAT , another convenience in going to the airport, Narita and Haneda.

Location is very convenient for airports and central Tokyo. There are several other more interesting Tokyo locations to stay in, but here you have a wide variety of restaurants for local nearby dining. And you are in Shinjuku or other more happening places in 20-15 min.The decor is dated, but the rooms are large and work well. My floor 10 room was right next to several elevated highways, and I could see the traffic from my window...but I could not hear a thing - not even at night.

Incredibly helpful staff and a large number of places in the property to eat, if you don’t want to sample the local cruising. The first impression when you walk in is very positive. Unfortunately that changes once you get to your room. The rooms are very dated and in dire need of an upgrade.Beds are small and if they were any lower, you would be sleeping on the floor. The shower controls are circa 1950 and the shower head is suitable for people under 5.5 feet tall. Towels are good. No iron/ironing board in the room, but they will bring one up to you. Biggest disappointment is there are no USB charging ports in the room.

I loved this hotel just for two things - the staff is extremely kind and helpful and the location is very convenient! Paolo the hotel manager was very friendly and his advise helped us explore Tokyo. The staff really go out of their way to help you in any way possible. Having said that, the rooms very nothing special and also cramped for the amount you're paying for renting the room. The breakfast is over priced and I recommend having breakfast at one of the cafe's in the city where you'll get the same or even better quality of breakfast for one fourth the price. I'd still recommend the place for the location and the wonderful staff but maybe travel light to save space in the room!

As usual RPH exceeded our expectations with respect to a very large room, modern amenities ( including a free use smartphone - Handy), too care of our reservations, very nice dinner at their top floor restaurant, wonderful breakfast every morning, open lounge during the day, snacks during the evening, provided subway passes, etc. Great stay! Thanks and will return again!

Well located, people are very nice; This time the swimming pool was under renovation, but we can't complain about that. My room for this time was a bit small, the smallest I never had (I come in this hotel for more than 10 years) but it was really confortable. And with the T-CAT nearby it is perfect for trnsportation from airport no matter Haneda or Narita.

I have stayed here many times but it had been 15 months since I was last there. The rooms are beginning to get worn down. They really need to begin renovating this hotel.  The staff is still very attentive. The location is still great. The fitness center is inadequate and not open 24/7. It is no longer worth the price…will have to look for other options.

The good part is the location which is handy, the bed is comfortable and the shower works well. Thats where it ends though. The reviews are bewilderingly generous. There is zero customer service if what you need deviates .00001 degrees from the established rules. The last time I heard so many "no's" I was five and talking to my mother. For starters, there is no gym as it is under construction until June, something found nowhere on their or any other website that we saw. OK this is necessary from time to time but any hotel boasting four stars would make arrangements with a local gym to take care of their guests during their stay. When I mentioned this obvious solution to the Asst. Manager Mr. Yamamoto I was met with such indifference that I was worried he had narcolepsy. I could go on but why bother. If they can't even fake customer concern right in front of us then I am sure no review will move them. If you don't travel much or are unaware of how hotels should operate The Royal Park will be fine. If you are experienced then pick another place.

The lower level of the hotel looks like five stars, the rooms are quite small and nothing special. The pluses- great connections from Narita/ Haneda through air terminal next door. Metro station in the hotel basement. If you do not mind walking for a mile or two many attractions nearby. Although near highway, almost no sound. Cons- gym was renovating. Breakfast buffet is over $30- not worth it unless you are a big eater. Plenty of excellent small shops serving good Japanese breakfast within 1/2 mile distance. Overall impression good.

I come here since the early 90's. At that time the hotel was new and highly luxurious. And actually that did not change a lot. I am using the executive floor levels, which includes breakfast on the top floor, with a nice view. As my business changed, it is the first time in 10 years that I am back in Tokyo, and that I booked again in the RP hotel and... they remember me clearly. This is extraordinary: they apparently looked me up in their old files, found me, and at my arrival they greeted me with "Welcome back mr. Myname". Impressive detail, but I felt like coming home. After that, the stay was perfect, as always...

This is my second stay at this hotel and still would highly recommend it. Good location, staff are friendly and helpful. Had my room earlier for an extra fee. Had some nice going on my floor on the first day, but being tired I didn't care. Overall very good

We got this hotel for a bargain on Expedia! It is in a great location and right on top of a metro station with direct access to the hotel. The room was a good size and very comfortable, also very clean.The breakfast was expensive but very good. We also did the lunch buffet, again this was very good.All the staff were very friendly and helpful.

The hotel is at a good location with a beautiful lobby and nice, comfortable rooms. However, it is a bit overpriced, especially if you want to have breakfast or check in early. Compared to its size I have found the number of tables and chairs in the lobby quite low.

Nice hotel, stayed in an executive room and was nice with everything you would need except an iron which you have to request. With executive room you have breakfast on the 20th floor, breakfast was buffet style. Restaurants are expensive in comparison to nearby restaurants. Not many tourist spots nearby but I ran once a day, Tokyo tower 11k away, Tokyo sky tree 12k away, river around the corner.

Nice hotel with good facilities. Being located on top of a subway station made it easy to get around Tokyo. Staff are friendly, helpful and attentive. Room service office a multi course set "Special Value option" for about 6,000 yen which is quite good. After 10pm the room service options are understandably limited. Breakfast is good and served on the 20th floor. I would stay here again

Spotless three-day visit. Clean and spacious rooms, friendly staff and convenient to and from the airports as it is next to the shuttle bus station. It is also less than ten minutes walk from three different metro stations making access to pretty much everything in Tokyo very easy.

We stayed here five years ago and we were happy to return. The hotel is just next to the express bus station from Narita and so is very convenient. The metro is just under the hotel so convenient for that too. The staff was very helpful and hotel benefits as a member were most welcome. The room was clean and the beds were so comfortable it was hard to leave in the morning. the cost is a bit high but it is Tokyo after all. Would definitely stay here again.

This 5-star hotel is already approaching her 30th anniversary, but you would not be able to tell as everything have been maintained in good shape. The locale is one where one could find both the old historical buildings to new modern facilities.It is only about half an hour away from Haneda Airport and driving to the hotel is no hassle. There is an underground parking lot with 176 units where staying guests can enjoy daily parking rate at a very reasonable 1500 yen.We had stayed at the Deluxe Twin Room at Standard Floor and were surprised by how spacious the room was. Of 42 square metres in size, the mild-colored tone room has two large twin beds, a sofa with coffee table, writing desk with chairs, and even a make-up station.By any standard the room is large, and considering we were in the central part of Tokyo the space was luxurious. The room is also comfortable and cozy, offering us a very good rest after flying over from Hong Kong and spending the whole day outside.There are a number of restaurants in the hotel. Breakfast was included in our package and we enjoyed a good buffet meal at Chef's Dining Symphony on the First Floor. There were a good range of both Western and Japanese dishes and I particularly liked their ham and sausages.Service is up to international standards, with the touch of Japanese warmth and friendliness. The staff could speak good English and there was no issue on communication. In fact there was a Polish manager who helped us for the check-in.Having booked my stay here via Relux, the whole package cost 33,000 yen (exclude tax) for the room and breakfast for two. Very reasonable and if you want to stay in a comfortable and spacious room without paying crazy prices in Tokyo, this is one of my recommendations.

Had a real good time staying here at the Royal Park Hotel.. Rooms were clean, staff really helped a lot...Also, there are many restaurants around to choose from and the Hanzomon subway station is right below the hotel...Really convenient and highly recommended.

Good hotel. Rooms are great albeit small , but this is Tokyo ! Was given exec floor access and breakfast was very welcomed. But by far the best thing is the “handy”. Basically a free android smartphone with genuinely free and unlimited calls and data. Including international calls. I thought there was a catch but there really wasn’t ! I’d stay here again just for this ! Made getting around and keeping in touch worry free

Newspapers in the morning, gracious desk help, and an outstanding buffet breakfast. The Executive floor always has appealing snacks and beverages. The best feature, however, is that each room is supplied with a smart phone one can take on local travels with interactive maps and info—in case you or your accompanying family doesn’t have foreign smartphone coverage.

Executive floor was quiet with a nice view of Tokyo. Room was clean, modern, and very comfortable. Executive breakfast buffet had many good options, especially for Americans, including made-to-order eggs, bacon, cereals, fruits, etc.

My 3 night stay was excellent at this hotel. Rooms were of a good size and comfortable. There are several good restaurants in the building and via the lower floor of the hotel you have direct access to the hanzomon subway line that directly goes to popular places such as shibuya. Also several other subway lines are withing walking distance. There is a bus terminal very closeby which goes to narita airport, saving you a lot of money. We took a taxi from narita on arrival but is was around 160 euro due to the distance. So take the bus! Much cheaper and a more comfortable ride.Service in the hotel is excellent. Would stay here again next time.

Great hotel and great location in Nihonbashi. You are right in the center of it all. You can walk along the Sumida River--very pleasant. In the opposite direction is a neighbourhood full of nice little restaurants. We actually walked to Chiyoda from the hotel...about 50 minutes. We also walked along river to the Tokyo Sky Tree area...also about 50 minutes. However, the hotel is connected to the subway and so you can be to all of these places very quickly. It was about 20 minutes to Shibuya crossing by the subway...very simple. You can get subway cards at the hotel. Also, there is a cocktail hour and complimentary breakfast if you take that option. The hotel is also right across the street from the airport bus terminal. So, you can take a designated airline bus directly to and from Narita. I liked the hotel quite a bit and I'm sure I'll stay there next time I visit Tokyo.

There were 4 of us and we booked 2 bedrooms and stayed here during 23 - 25 December 2018. Hotel is near City Air Terminal and next to train station, another one within 5 mins walk. No shopping though, just a few restaurants and KFC nearby. Most of the restaurants have Japanese menu. It is about 15 - 20 mins away from Skytree and 30 mins away from Odaiba by taxi which cost about Yen3,000 each way. Taxis are easily available from hotel entrance. We did not want to walk in cold winter to stations so hopped on to taxis. Guest rooms are fairly spacious with bath tub and side table and chair. Hotel breakfast has quite a good spread with western and Japanese choices.

The hotel is conveniently located at one of the stops of the limousine bus from either Narita or Haneda airport at City Air Terminal, which is yards away from the hotel.The lobby & entrance of the hotel is extremely grand. Plus, you’ll have direct access to the subway station from the hotel on the Hanzomon Line (Z10 stop) - direct line to Shibuya & Ginza.Room-wise is a bit old and slightly cramped. Due to jet leg, we weren’t able to checkout the breakfast.

This was my second stay at the Royal Park Hotel. In all, I stayed a total of 5 nights at the hotel during this visit. (Prior visit was 4 nights in 2016.) The Royal Park Hotel did not disappoint and met all of my expectations. The hotel is quiet and clean. (My stay was over the New Years holiday.) All of the staff were friendly, courteous and helpful. My room was clean and well maintained. All of my visits I upgraded my room in order to have access to the lounge on the 20th floor for both breakfast and happy hour. From the lounge the view of Tokyo is incredible! I did visit the lobby lounge and main bar during my visits. Again impeccable service from the Royal Park Hotel employees.As stated in other reviews, the hotel is conveniently located right next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) - there is a passenger bridge from the Royal Park Hotel to TCAT on the 2nd floor. There is also direct access to the Hanzomon subway line in the bottom floor of the hotel.I will plan to stay at the Royal Park Hotel for my next visit to Tokyo.

Great hotel. Very polite and helpful staff. Conveniently located next to the Metro Station and the Tokyo City Air Terminal from where the Airport Limousine buses go to and from Narita and Haneda Airports. The hotel has a great Executive Lounge where the views can be admired at breakfast, during cafe times and evening cocktail times. There is a beautiful tea house as well. Plus swimming pool and fitness suite. WiFi connection for my mobile phone was very problematic in the room though this massively improved on the Executive Lounge floor. Worth the expense for my Christmas present to myself! ...very conveniently located for access to the historical district of Ningyo Cho

This was a very crisp and well operated hotel with a nice level of luxury. The room was efficient and comfortable, the service very good, the room service breakfasts, excellent, and the Japanese restaurant experience very authentic. The location was excellent for those wanting convenience to Narita. The TCAT bus terminal is right next door which makes getting to an from the city extra convenient. This hotel is not in the middle of the "action" but a very nice place to stay with ample cab service to wherever you'd like to go.

Disappointing to be charged extra for use of pool and fitness room.Very pretty picture of pool on the website does not accurately represent reality.Also - opening hours for the pool and fitness room are not the greatest especially for jetlagged travelers who wake up early and have to wait until 6:00 for fitness room to open and 6:30 for pool to open.Smell of cigarette smoke in certain areas is very unpleasant and unwelcoming.On positive side - rooms have nice view and location is convenient.Food in the executive lounge is nothing to rave about but ok.

I always book a larger room on the Executive floor. This gives you a lot of space, and the room is very comfortable. The bathroom is compact, but functional, with a good bath. I like the aircon, you can just choose the temp you like. I get it down to 18 at night! The Executive lounge is great, with a rooftop view over Tokyo, and drinks in the evening. The whole hotel is spotless, and good value for a five star hotel. Two advantages. First the hotel is next to TCAT, so you just get off the bus, and it is 50 yards to the hotel. Second there is a Subway station in the basement. It is a shame there is no longer a rooftop bar at night, as the bar on floor-1 is dark, and they allow smoking. I find this the best value and convenient hotel in Tokyo. One example of service. I had a problem in the Teppanyaki Restaurant, as the set menu had changed from the one I was given when I checked in. Thus no lobster! I complained, politely, to the lady in the Executive lounge, and she offered to refund the early check in charge I had paid. £50 or so!. I agreed! Quite a gesture.

The Good: Lots of choices for restaurants in this hotel, expensive but choices are available. The rooms are really nice. The location is fantastic, Air Terminal is next door so bus to both airports is perfect, and for a morning run or walk the river walkway runs for miles. The Bad or Not Good: The executive lounge is really nice in the morning, good breakfast food and choices but at night the lounge stops any food and drinks at 8pm. This is really early, I wish it would go until at least 10pm. This is really my only problem with this hotel and the price I pay per room, the executive lounge should stay open longer for food and drinks.

This hotel is very old fashion. The rooms are clean but old. The most disappointed for me was the fitness room. You must pay additional fees to have access to the fitness center of the hotel. Not speaking about massage or sauna. But the basic gym access is extra charge and not included in hotel room price. At least not in mine and seems not in the one of my colleagues too.

5 Star and deserved of 10. All employees are customer oriented and focused on ensuring that expectations are exceeded in every way. The executive floor is the only way to go if you want to have the ultimate and glorious experience in Tokyo. Our room on floor 18 was incredible. The spacious and well designed room had the equivalent view of the highest towers in Japan. The most important and wonderful aspect of this hotel is the staff! I have supervised up to 1500 and worked for great companies. I am extremely picky about the hotels I stay in (especially when over $500/night). I have zero complaints. Thank you, Sir Yamamoto. Thank you to the entire crew of incredible people. We love Japan because of you! Arigato!

Stayed here many times - very relaxing and comfortable.Great service with a smile , staff are so welcoming. Great quiet location, lovely walking neighborhood.The Scotts Bar is the best.Traditional low key bar with exceptional service.Next to TCAT, easy access to Narita.

The Royal Park Hotel at Nihombashi always delivers with its sense of elegance, their short walk proximity to the TCAT airport Limousine bus terminal, and their consistent attention to service. The bathrooms in many rooms have been upgraded to a walk-in rain shower with water pressure that puts hotels in the USA to shame. I always stay at the executive level with access to the attentive staff of the lounge who always recognize their visitors especially ones like me that may stay 2 - 3 times per year. Breakfast in the exec lounge with custom made omelets/eggs any style, always satisfies, and the lobby restaurant is always on point for a quick business lunch with colleagues. I've eaten at most of the restaurants in this hotel over the years and you cannot go wrong with any of them. My favorite is the Tepanyaki restaurant on the 20th floor. All inside eateries have a hotel guest discounted option that is well worth the price. If you stay, do take the time to enjoy the pool and the intensely hot water Jacuzzi spa which is located separate for men and women. It's a great way to soak away the jet lag. If weather permits you can quickly walk or jog over to the riverside promenades for an early morning workout. Great location and wonderful hotel.

First of all the location is next to the TCAT, you can get a limo bus to TCAT from both Narisa and Haneda. Subway is just in the basement, what else you need. You can get both subway and limo bus tickets from the front desk. Rooms are spacious and neat. You get a mobile device, so no need for international roaming, you can call any international number from this device. It has espresso machine, so saves cost of a morning coffee I guess with a noble intent to conserve energy, the aircon temp is probably set high. You get a weird smell once you enter the room, goes away in few hours once the Aircon is on.It’s got five good restaurants, gym and spa.Everyone is very courteous and helpful. Overall a comfortable stay

We managed to book a 3-bed room here (not easy in Tokyo) for myself, wife and adult daughter when we had to escape Kyoto early because of the approaching typhoon.Then our Emirates flight was postponed for a day (typhhon warning again) so had to book another night which we were very happy to do.It turned out to be an excellent choice, should be 5-star if it isn't.Our room gave us access to the executive lounge on the top 20th floor. which had a wonderful birds-eye view of the city.Great extensive buffet breakfast in there. Then free coffee and cakes all day 11 to 5.Incredibly then free cocktails, wine, beer, etc from 5 to 8 with even more free food at another extensive buffet - enough to fill up without bothering with a restaurant.All this included in the room rate which we thought was terrific value compared to anything similar in London, say.I did go to the Symphony restaurant alone on the 2nd night which offered a good value fixed price 4-courses fo staying guests (reviewed separately.Another advantage was the airport bus station across the road (3 minutes) where we got a tourist discount rate for the ride to Narita.Very highly recommended.

I’ve stayed at this hotel twice when traveling for work, a subway station is located right there, you don’t have to go outdoors (perfect on those rainy days). A bus station is across the street to easily and cheaply get to and from the airport. The rooms are decent size, especially for Tokyo. The breakfast buffet on 20th floor provides a variety of options, with a chef who will make eggs anyway you like, and amazing city views. Only complaint is that cocktails at the hotel bar are very expensive.

Staying at the Royal Park was what I could expect from a highly rated hotel, and more. The rooms were comfortable and clean, the service was impeccable, breakfast delicious and the many restaurants offered variety and quality. Working in the restaurant area outside of meal times was comfortable and relaxing. Direct access to the subway and right next to the airport bus station were very welcome pluses.

Very modern hotel, staff excellent, restaurant food was good. But rooms small like most Japan hotels. Bed very hard same as pillows, we got extra pillows but made little difference. Shame as could be easily put right.
user_name:
Derek C
Cold Ash, United Kingdom

review_body: If you get access to the executive floor you have a lounge on the top floor where you can have your complimentary breakfast. Enjoy the perfectly made omelette with a wonderful view of Tokyo. Come back after work and enjoy a drink, or two with colleagues. Rooms are for Japanese standards good size and you have all you need, including a mini-bar. The bed is good. Flying in to Narita makes the hotel a perfect fit with the direct buss stop next door at the T-CAT station.

The room is spacious enough to accommodate 2 single beds and a sofa bed. Location is convenient since the hotel is situated above subway station and TCAT is connected next door to the hotel. However, for the 4 stars rating hotel and price, the room needs to be renovated. Will stay there again if it is not priced so high.

This hotel is located centrally and easy to take train everywhere. Very clean and excellent breakfast choices. Friendly and helpful staff. Hotel is close to all restaurants and what Tokyo downtown offers.

Nice, friendly hotel with a central location. Conveniently located across the TCAT, with continuous service to both Narita & Haneda airports. I’ve stayed at other premium hotels in Tokyo, but nothing beats the Royal Park hotel. Try to get an executive room. The amenities are worthy. Highly recommended hotel for business or vacation.

Old hotel, small and old room, not enough bath supplies, not even towels.They overcharge everything, even the swimming pool! Unbelievable!Restaurants are overpriced as well.Very poor service, will never come back again

This is a great hotel for a business trip. It's setup pretty much in that fashion. Reception and check are smooth with some lovely mod cons for you to sign in with. The staff are really friendly and helpful. I use the lift you have to present your key on pad and it selects the floor for you.Being a process guy, I was really impressed when the lift apologies for keeping you waiting.Another great feature about this hot is the quick access to the sub way both too and from. When you arrive at the station below the hotel you are off the train and in your room in less then five minutes.However, food and drink are very high in price, I never eat at the hotel and only bought an after work beer once, the price put me off making that mistake again. If you get an executive room then you also get access to the executive dinning room on the 20th floor. I went there for breakfast and the views over Tokyo are great. Food selection is also good but not too vast like I've seen at other business hotels.I did like the egg chief. Whatever you wanted with reference to a egg dish in the morning, he quickly knocked up.

excellent hotel there is service is so good and dinning area also is good ..very nice ambiance and hospitality also is good .view from my room is so amazing hotel staff is very coursiuos and look after your needs

Our travel agent listed this as a 4.5 star hotel. Very nice rooms and service. Breakfast buffet was huge with lots of choices! My only negative was they took my wash cloth so if you bring one hide it! Very close to local transportation and bullet trains.

Very nice hotel with great service. Clean rooms, comfy rooms. Locations is also very good. Right next to Tokyo City Air terminals. Walking distance to the Ginza district. Close to emperial palace. Definitely recommend.
user_name:
Rob112002
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: First the hotel is conveniently located next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal which make getting to and from the Tokyo airports relatively easy. Having room to work in your room in most Tokyo hotels is a challenge . However is desk with internet service for you to work in your room.The executive rooms are perfect for the business traveler as they come with a buffet breakfast with an omelet station. There are cocktails from 5 in the afternoon until 9.I brought my wife with me on my last business trips. This was my first experience with the concierge desk which was very service oriented. One individual in particular, Paolo was always providing great restaurant recommendations . He also arrange to change the meeting place of a previous booked tour to the hotel lobby instead of Tokyo station.I was most impressed when Paolo showed up to restaurant he recommended 8 blocks away to cover a change in an excursion he booked for us.

Great hotel at Tokyo.Room size is good from Tokyo standard.TCAT terminal is next to hotel and hence traveling from Narita Airport to Hotel and back is very easy.Tokyo Metro station is in hotel area only.Staff is very cooperative and understand English.Room service and wifi are excellent.Lobby level restaurant is good but service is little slow.Will stay at the hotel again.

CONVENIENT. Right next door to the City Air Terminal, so if you need to travel to/from Haneda or Narita then you can jump on the bus which runs from about 0500 to latePRICEY. Watch out for the extras, tea bags in the room are an extra, the pool & spa is extra,and for me breakfast was an extra Y 3240 !!It's clean and spacious, probably too commodious and that's what you pay for.AIRCO. Being a European I wanted the bedroom temperature to be around 18-20 C but the aircon wasn't capable of such coolingOK place but I probably won't choose to stay there again.

This is a older hotel near the subway. It is located in a housing area and not touristy. There are a few places to eat and shop nearby including a dollar store and a local grocery store. The rooms are decent size and in need of refurbishing. The halls are dimly lit but the rooms are extremely quiet. The staff is very friendly. We had access to the executive lounge area for breakfast which was really good. Would I stay here again probably not! There is a fee to use the gym.

It locates next to Tokyo City air terminal. You can take the path on 2nd floor in the hotel to the air terminal without walking outside. 55 mins bus ride to Narita airport which is departing in every 20mins. Current cost Narita is JPY 2800 (Discount fare for foreigner JPY 1900) My room was next to the road with very busy traffic. But the room was extremely quite. Can not hear any noise from the traffic. 10 mins Walking distance to Starbucks coffee after crossing one or two bridges. The restaurant in the hotel is a little bit more expensive. It's Tokyo.

Very beautiful facility. Nice rooms and amenities, Staff were very friendly and accommodating. Convenient to the City Airport Terminal transportation center. Many outstanding restaurants are walkable from hotel.

This is the letter (minus just a little bit of profanity because TA does not allow it) I sent to the Royal Park Hotel. As an executive manager in the industry, I was disappointed. PLEASE GET WITH IT!!! Or lower your prices and don’t call yourself a five star hotel. BEGINNING of LETTERRoom 1249 May 6, 2018First of all, I want to know who gave you a five star rating? You should be ashamed.  Let me share with you just a couple of things. As an ex assistant food and beverage manager/director of places like the Tokyo Bay Hilton and the Tokyo American Club, having been out of the industry for close to 20 years, I really had a great expectation of staying in your hotel.  Let’s start with check in. We came in at 9:30 AM just to drop our luggage and had a slim hope that if our room was ready, it would be great, but of course the front desk was very courteous and let us know that our room would be ready by 3 PM. So we dropped our luggage in front of the front desk lady and she was watching us as the staff picked up our luggage, seeing clearly that we had a two-year-old daughter.  As I was busy in a meeting on the 18th floor for most of the day, I found out later that somehow our room became available around 10 AM and my wife was checked in and luggage was already in the room which made us feel very safe and happy.  We finished our meeting around 3 PM and as we saw we cannot order glasses of wine from the room service menu, I bought a bottle somewhere else and we had a couple of glasses before we headed out to dinner. ¥3300 for a cheese assortment? Wow.My wife had been in the room all day and noticed the coffee maker was very dirty, the envelopes in the desk drawer were crinkled, there was dust everywhere and the window looking out into Tokyo had wallpaper that was peeling from the edge of the window. Definitely in need of repair. When I went to the room, she showed me these things; I was taken aback. So therefore I called and asked for the Housekeeping Supervisor to come in, and I showed him all of the dust in the room, the coffee maker, the desk where the paperwork was stored and asked him if there was anything he could do about it.  We were heading out to dinner and I asked him if he could take care of it while we were gone, in which he did. Very nice and professional. And do you know something? When we returned, not only was everything in better shape to match the standards of a five-star hotel, he had a baby‘s toothbrush placed in the bathroom and little baby slippers near the entrance.  So I wondered at that time, why weren’t these items presented beforehand? When we were checking in, or should I say when we attempted to check in, the front desk receptionist clearly saw we had a child and could have noted to housekeeping to ensure that these items were already placed. Upon my wife’s check in at 10 AM, she was greeted by three different housekeepers on the floor cleaning rooms. Did not any of them see a two-year-old in tow and check the checklist to see if there was a child in room?Understand, that I would not have expected these items to be there in the first place but since they were placed there later, it made me wonder why they were NOT placed there in the first place. A five-star resort or hotel would have noticed little things like that and already have ensured that that service had been completed.  Not to say a five-star hotel housekeeping department would’ve had someone come in with a white glove and ensure there is no dust in the room at all, because we don’t want to mention the air cleaner that’s in the room. The Housekeeping department would’ve also ensured that the coffee maker was perfectly clean.  Well anyway, in food and beverage, we are constantly putting out fires. So it’s not how many problems you have in a day, but it’s how you react to those issues. You take care of the customer issue first, then the next day you talk about it in management and figure out how to react to it in the future.  That of course, brings me to my second issue. My wife and I were watching a movie and it included a scene where someone was eating Ramen. We had already taken our baths for the evening, and since we have a two-year-old child, we did not want to leave the room so we looked at the room service menu.  Udon was on the menu but not Ramen. Not only one udon, but two. TWO!!!! But I called room service anyway. I asked them if they had Ramen and they said you could come down and have the Ramen in the restaurant but they could not deliver it, though they could deliver other items from that particular Chinese restaurant.  To be honest, this made me mad.  Not only because you could do it, it was because the person on the other end of the phone, bluntly was disrespectful with an attitude.  Instead of apologizing and offering me an alternative, for example, “I am sorry sir but we do not offer Ramen from this particular restaurant at this time but if you call this number this particular company can offer this particular Ramen to deliver to the hotel.” This guy told me that he could not do it so I responded asking him if this hotel does not provide ‘Omotenashi’ service? You know hell, being a five star rated hotel and everything, then which he gave me attitude and said, no we don’t do it.  I think it was the attitude that set me off because I have bent over backwards ensuring that guest got what the they wanted, going up and beyond the call of duty to take care of the customer first and ask questions later. You can even charge them, you know, and they are fine with it.  So this is not about Ramen. This is not about how I had to go to Family Mart across the street and buy my wife some stupid box Ramen, when I am staying in the Royal Park (5 STAR) Hotel.  What this is about is a five star rating and making your customer do something that you should have provided in the first place. The person that I called at room service, the two individuals that were in the lobby that I explained my issue to; there was no one to step up to the plate and fix this issue. If it had been me that had come into contact with the customer with this issue I would’ve told him to return to their room and I would be there with their Ramen, no questions asked. You are a five-star resort and you failed on some stupid issue!!! You have got to be kidding me. Are you going to come up with some stupid excuse to tell me why you could not deliver some stupid noodles to some room for some customer that’s paying for five star experience? So the thing is, you don’t know if I’m just a regular Joe, or someone who writes for the Travel Channel. And it should not matter. You should provide OMOTENASHI. Especially if you want to be called a five-star resort. In return of an ‘I’m sorry letter’, what I would like to see is that you maybe gather your management team and go over what it means to be a five-star hotel in Tokyo and begin treating customers with that type of service.Or maybe just forget it. Because evidently you don’t care right now. Thank you for your time.

This hotel is easy to get to, has extremely nice rooms, great food, nice layout, feels safe, great location. I would stay again. They have a smart phone in room for your use that help with directions, specials in the area. Breakfast buffet was extremely well done. Sushi restaurant was divine.

I didn't get to choose the hotel I stayed at as I was traveling with a larger group. Despite it claiming to be a four-star hotel, this is more a three-star standard business hotel, especially for those who're used to staying at the international chains, like Hyatt and Starwood. Firstly, the hotel's location isn't fantastic, with nothing much within a 20-minute walking radius. While the easy access to a subway line helps, it typically takes several transfers to get to they key districts, other than Shibuya, which is perhaps 30 minutes away by subway.Secondly, the service was rather mixed. The staff at the front desk, in particular, wasn't very friendly. I faced difficulties communicating in English in a few occasions.Thirdly, I was shocked that I had to pay for access to the gym. Seems like this is somewhat common especially among the older Japanese hotels, but it just doesn't feel right for a supposedly four-star hotel to impose additional charges for something as basic as gym access.Lastly, the rooms were slightly dated and dimly lit, not in a hip way. The room just felt rather dull even with all the lights switched on.That said, I think the price is rather reasonable by Tokyo standards, and the rooms were of a decent size.

My 21 year old son and I stayed here for our first few nights in Tokyo. It was so easy to catch the Limo bus from the airport direct to the T-CAT station next to the hotel. This was excellent as it was our first trip to Japan, so area was quiet, safe and subway station under the hotel. Rooms were large for Japan standards, but otherwise the hotel was fairly average. Breakfast was extremely expensive. AMAZING Tempura restaurant a couple of blocks away, and 7-11 close by. All in all a great choice for first hotel in Tokyo.
user_name:
Sally J
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Although I had not problems throughout my entire stay and the service was good, I wouldn’t give it excellent as a comparison to other hotels. I stay at about 75 hotel per year, this was truly just an average hotel.

Everything about the hotel was so convenient , from being near the T-cat station, the metro and not too far from Tokyo station and the room was very comfortable and the executive lounge was the best we have been in. The views were gorgeous and the breakfast, afternoon tea and evening drinks and snacks were just such a treat. The omelette chef at breakfast was a master and a joy to watch. And even better to eat his art. Also all the staff members were so polite and helpful and we had a great time.

Great hotel with pretty large room is not common in Tokyo. Even though the location is a bit far from famous location but it’s connected to subway. I think it’s a good trade-off because rate is reasonable, hotel is big, room is big (you get sofa, work desk, and enough space to put down luggages). Wifi here is free and strong. Only small things that make this hotel not perfect yet (1) the bath tub drains quite slowly (2) breakfast although lots of selection but not interesting items and the refill was quite slow. Nearby there is small ramen place that serves quite nice shio ramen.

Pros-connected to TCAT and metro. Don’t have to even walk outside -offer interconnecting rooms for families-very helpful English speaking staffCons-dated property with very old bathrooms and dirty carpet

Enjoyed our stay. Convenient location and helpful English speaking staff. Room was fine for our family of four. Close to transportation including subway and TCAT. We also really enjoyed the ramen restaurant next door.

It was my second stay at this hotel (over a span of 13 years) and here are my opinions:1. The hotel is ideally located on top of a subway station, which is great; it is also connected with the Tokyo C Air Terminal (TCAT), so one can easily go to/from both Haneda and Narita;2. The main reception area is spectacular;3. The room: small as expected-we had to put one piece of luggage on the desk; air qualityvin the room was good due to a purifier device, but the hallway on our floor wad poorly ventilated and there was an unpleasant (but bearable) odor; the room - while very clean like everything else in Japan-felt outdated;4. Breakfast was very expensive at around 3,500 yen per person, so we had it around the hotel (there’s a Jonathan’s about 5 mins away on foot). Giving it four stars for the location/convenience.

Very nice hotel of high standard. Rooms, equipment and service are perfect. It is a little bit expensive. I do not like that the restaurants all close early. The bar is closed early as well and for late arrival it is difficult to get food or drinks.i believe that at least until midnight one of the restaurants/Bars should be available for orders.

This Hotel recomended for you Business Trip on Central Tokyo because they have subway station on the left side. If i’m wrong, Suitengae Station - Hanzomon Line. Outside hotel many restaurants and mini market, so u have alternative food. I and My Boss just walking to Japan Stock Exchange because only 20 Minutes By Walk.

This was our fourth stay here. Every aspect of the hotel: adjacent to the T-CAT, direct access to the Suitengumae Metro stop, comfortable Executive Floor rooms, outstanding breakfast and cocktail hour, and above all, superior staff, makes this our only choice when we come to Tokyo. I've noted this and much more in previous reviews so no need to repeat myself other than to note that we're already planning our return visit to Tokyo and the Royal Park is an integral part of each trip.

This is a great location when arriving in Tokyo, immediately next to the Tokyo Air Terminal which has buses from the Narita airport. You just walk a few steps next door.We were very pleased with the hotel. There is English-speaking staff and very helpful. It is also located right on a subway station, so it is very easy to get around the city. Subway tickets can be purchased at the front desk.The room was very clean and comfortable, but a little small. It included a refrigerator and WiFi.We opted each morning for the breakfast buffet. A little pricey at $36 US, but well worth it. It had a omelet station, soup, numerous hot and cold dishes, fresh juices, pastries - all you would expect and more.Definitely recommended.

Apart from the location - it is a 2 minute walk from the station and right next to the Terminal where you can take a bus to Haneda or Narita, the hotel is a bit dated. A comfortable stay though, but not as value for money as the other hotels we stayed in Japan.

Booked on NY’s Eve fir six nights. Hotel is next to Tokyo Air City Terminal. Brought ticket for airport coach and board bus at stop No 7. Arrived within an hour, checked in is smooth. Staff speak good english, even with 1 foreign staff member at the counter.When arrived at the terminal, can either walk across on 2/F to the hotel as hotel is linked with a walk bridge. Or, the hotel is also linked with subway line station Suitengumae station (Hanzomon purple Line). Easy access to Ginza, Ikebukuro, Shinjuku etc.Room is spacious with space for twin bed, writing desk, armchair, luggage rack, closet and full length mirror, rare in Japan. Room size must have about 20 sq. m. Room is overall clean but with some hi-cup. Shower curtain was ink-spotted. Hotel claimed they embraced green, but didn’t gave us the choice whether the bed linen was changed on our request. They decided it. If you like soft bed, it’s ok. We found it too soft though.Food and beverage in the hotel was quite expensive, compared with outside restaurants, even compared with Mont-sando Hill high-end shopping arcade. However, quality was not comparable. We paid average US$230 per night, because of peak seasons, it normally charged around US$150~180 per night according to online booking price.We have an early flight and brought coach ticket one day ahead. We walked across after checked out and swiftly arrived airport.Otherwise, we consider the stay was pleasant and would consider to stay again provided the price is right.

The TCAT is next block and the lift takes you straight to B2 subway station -- super convenient especially you have a 9am flight in Narita to catch. It is 5min walk to the office I visit so it is convenient x2 for me.Super excellent service from the staff. Room is clean and comfortable, only that it is not very spacious... But good enough for my solo business travel

It's quiet hotel and very helpful staff. The staff was very initiated to assist. Front Desk staff was patience, helpful and clear. They made the check-in and check-out process very quick. I like the room which is simple but with great amenities. They have a humidifier as the time I visit was autumn going to winter. They have a handy phone, which you can use to call local/international (certain countries) free calls! They gave one set of Shisedo skin care products and men products e.g. hair gel. They also have fabric spray. They have pyjamas and you can request for the type of pyjamas you are comfortable in. It's a great location near the Ningyo street. Had paintings, snacks, bookstores, cafes etc. They also have 2 convenience stores nearby. Next to the hotel is the limousine bus service counters, one more convenience store, a few restaurants (sushi, izakaya, macdonald etc), and 100 yen shop, a cafe and a kids clothing store. The hotel is about 20min ride from haneda airport and 50 min from narita airport. Overall the hotel gives great convenience, its amenities shows how sensitive they are to guests' needs. The only thing was the housekeeping wasn't that perfect. There was once I found a drawer was not closed properly after housekeeper checked on the standard no. of pyjamas to be in there. The other time, she did not keep the bedroom slippers properly as the other days and left lying untidily somewhere. I could hear walking sounds or furniture moving sounds, but i'm not sure if it's the building structure due to the coldness, or simply could hear the next room.

Our 3rd stay at this hotel and it is easy to understand why >Great location ( quiet, if you like that ). You can walk to the Ginza main shopping street and Tsukiji market under 20 minutesAir conditioner you can control ( in many other hotels in Japan -especially the 'business' ones, we found it too warm with little of no control over the temperature setting. Not so at this hotel )Good access to metro trains ( just next to Shiodome station, with covered subway to Shimbashi )Limousine bus to and fro from Hotel to Airport ( life-saver if you have several large luggage in tow and wish to remain stress free by avoiding the crowd and navigating through Tokyo station to/from the airport )Plenty of restaurants/ food outlet surrounding the hotel, serving for a wide range of cuisines from breakfast to dinner. 24-hour Family Mart outlet just below the hotel - they even have sandwiches/bento and oden !Great customer service, with a very helpful concierge desk. Rooms are comparatively larger, clean and totally smoke-free ( make that a mandatory requirement at booking ). Lastly, there is no physical key to the rooms - cards for every occupant. Would stay again anytime - just got to look out for 'specials'

I used to stay here regularly in the late 80's early 90's when I worked for a cash rich company. So I chose it when I visited Japan recently with my wife and I have to say that I was very disappointed. In the years since staying here, I have visited many other hotels in many other countries and some of them at half the price were much better. I booked an executive room costing nearly £300 per night and I have to say it seemed small and "tired". Certainly not the standard that I remembered. What used to be a public bar on the 20th floor is now for use of executive room holders only. So we used it. The drinks were free, but only form 5 to 8pm, after that they were put away and to be honest I'm not sure if any alcohol was available. No problem, but not what one expects from this standard of hotel.

For a combination of luxury and friendliness, this is the hotel I always come to ; ever since it opened 20+ years ago. The rooms are great, upgraded bathrooms; handy phone included during your stays d very central. The executive floor is superb; real leaf tea, great breakfasts and drinks all day, with a 3 hr cocktail period in the eveningAlso has a 25 m pool and sauna and plunge pool

I come to this hotel every year because it is close to my office in tokyo. I expect 5 star service for a five star price. The room was a dated and needs refreshing. Although the price is high there is nothing included in the price. Breakfast is extra. The gym is not included. Not satisfied and i have asked our office to find a more suitable hotel. Service is good.

I stayed here for 16 days in October for business. I thought the hotel was great, as was the staff. I stayed in a queen room on the executive level (floors 15-19). Check-in was smooth and easy and the room was very well kept. Most of the employees took a great amount of pride in their work and didn’t accept gratuities. I highly recommend the executive level as it includes an Android cell phone with free long distance and internet, access to the Executive lounge (20th floor) for a Western breakfast buffet daily, snacks and beverages throughout the afternoon and three hours of happy hour and appetizers every evening. The executive lounge is not a bar and there is no bartender, but they do put a variety of liquor bottles on the counter for happy hour, including snacks, soft drinks and beer. In addition, the views are very nice on the 20th floor. This hotel is conveniently located above the Hanzomon (purple line) subway line (Suitengumae Station is in basement of hotel) and the T-CAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) bus station (covered catwalk to station is on 2nd floor). The hotel offers discount train and bus tickets at front desk. For example, a three day unlimited subway ticket costs 1,500 yen and a bus ticket to Haneda airport was only 780 yen. The hotel restaurants and bars are nice and I really enjoyed the cigar bar in the basement, but they can be pricey, even by hotel standards. For example, a mixed drink (non-premium) was about 1,900 yen and their Chinese restaurant was over the top. They charged us 2,300 yen for a single serving size order of fried rice (we had to get 3 orders for 4 people), 1,450 yen for a draft beer and they wouldn’t allow us to take our leftovers with us, which I found a bit offensive. But, other than not recommending the Chinese restaurant, I would highly recommend this hotel and will stay here on my next visit. On a side note, if you feel the hotel’s bars are a bit pricey, go across the street to BarLey Suitengumae. BarLey is a fantastic little bar with a very large/nice selection of bourbons, whiskeys and scotches for about half the price of the hotel cigar bar. This bar takes great pride in every cocktail they craft, including using the proper ice (or ice ball) for the proper drink, custom cutting it when needed. You have to see it to believe it. Say hi to the owner Takeme for me.

Just got back from a few days in Tokyo and stayed at this wonderful hotel. The room was very comfortable with great views of the city on 17th floor. Shower was hot and had nice strong pressure. Breakfast each day on 20th floor Executive Floor had delicious selection of western foods, including made to order omelette. Staff was so helpful and kind! Location was great; Easy to get to subway stations. Highly recommended.

Tokyo may seem like an overwhelming city, but making the Royal Park your home base makes it very easy to navigate. The attached City Bus Terminal is the direct route from Narita Airport - an its also the Tokyo Metro station. The rooms were very nice - beds are the widest beds I have ever seen and incredibly comfortable. The toilets were fascinating to learn to use (for someone from North America)! I will definitely stay here next time I go to Tokyo.

Stayed two nights whilst on business in Tokyo. The reception area is impressive as was the friendliness of the staff. However, room was a big let down. Was very dated, particularly the bathroom which was in urgent need of renovation. I did not appreciate the 1980s pink suite and tiles which were horrible and in need of new sealant in many places. Worse was to come with a shower curtain that was covered in black mould. Furniture in the room was also a throwback to a different era. Whilst the hotel has a number of restaurants I was shocked by the extortionate prices which even though my business was picking up the tab were incredibly high. Closeness to the bus station to get back to the airport is a big plus and room was very quiet despite overlooking a flyover. All in all I rate this hotel as average and it really does need money spending on updating the rooms to have a more modern feel.

I have stayed at the Royal Park Hotel on many occasions. While Tokyo may seem like a very large city that is difficult to find you way around, the staff at the hotel are always helpful. The location of the hotel, just across the street from the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) makes for easy access from Narita or Haneda airports via the Limosine Bus. The rooms at Royal Park are comfortable, spotless, and quiet. If your Budget allows, Upgrade to the Executive rooms. They come with separate check-in on the 20th floor, breakfast, and evening cocktails. The Japanese restaurant Gengi-koh on the 5th floor serves excellent as does Sumida teppanyaki on the 20th floor. If you are at the hotel for several days, try the Chinese restuarant as well as the sushi bar on the lower floors. Restuarant Fontaine in the lobby serves very good Western dishes as well as Japanese noodle dishes. There is also a buffet opportunity. AS other reviewers have said, having the Suitengamae Metro station in the basement makes for seamless travel. The Royal Park hotel is also a short taxi ride to the Central Tokyo Train station if you are travelling further by Train/Shinkansen. Excellent location, excellent staff and excellent rooms at the Royal Park Hotel make for a pleasant and stress-less stay in Tokyo. I h ighlly recommend this hotel for business but also pleasure Travelers.

This was our second stay at this hotel and it is still a favorite. We stayed in an Executive Room and the amenities make the extra cost so worthwhile. Everyone we interacted with on the staff was helpful and friendly. We were able to purchase our Metro passes and TCAT airport transfers right at the hotel. The location is great.....10 minutes by cab from Tokyo Station, passage way direct from the TCAT terminal and underground Metro.Our room was very clean and efficiently laid out. There was even a cellphone provided for local use. the Bathroom had all sorts of upscale amenities, which was a nice touch.the Executive Floor lounge has great views of the city. Breakfast has plentiful items for all tastes and the evening snacks and drinks provided a relaxing time to unwind after a day of sightseeing.We think this hotel got better the second time around!

Very accommodating staff. Counter people decent in English making transactions much easier than most. Helpful in teaching us regarding the T-CAT airport limousine. Had 3 places for the complementary breakfast buffet making it more interesting. Will stay again for sure.

I stayed here during mu recent trip to Tokyo. The location of the hotel is excellent- subway access directly from hotel. Airport limousine station is also directly accessible from hotel. The restaurant and cake shop at hotel is good. However if you are staying for long there are plenty of restaurants including McDonalds nearby. Breakfast I found to be on executive floor may be more vegetarian hot dishes can be added.

Hotel is about five minute walk from CAT. Beautiful and spacious. It was interesting to see the bell hops were female in the day. Every one is friendly and attentive. Bathroom was decent size with great toiletries: all Shiseidō. Breakfast in executive lounge was my favorite. There were plenty of options. Cocktails in executive lounge were fine. The canapés did not impress. Subway line runs underneath hotel so it makes for a great convenient point of transportation. Nice neighborhood where you have choices of places to eat and/or drink

The rooms are modern, well equipped and functional. The toiletry selection is nice. There's a swimming pool and several restaurants. The executive lounge is pleasant, although the god-awful jazz music should be banned forever. Why inflict this pain?Breakfast is the real let-down. That might pass in the US as a decent breakfast, not however in Japan. Mediocre at best. For example there are just two sorts of tea. Dare use the cups for tea and you'll burn your fingers for sure.The location is good transport-wise, not necessarily for lots of proper local eating places.

The free breakfast buffet on 20th floor is incredible. Cocktail hour (5 PM to 8 PM) in same area with breathtaking views and comfortable seating, has wonderful food and great drink variety. Incredible and super nice staff! Great housekeeping. Super comfy beds and spacious rooms. Bathroom is very nice. Shower and bath is wonderful. Great pool, sauna, gym, tea room, restaurants, open areas, smoking areas, fantastic location!

Hotel is situated next to the Tokyo City Airport Terminal (TCAT) and linked to the hazomon line of the Tokyo subway. Easy transport and a few surprising restaurants around the area.A slight walk up to ninghocho also has lots of shops to browse.

Stated in executive suite, from fifteenth to nineteenth floors. Lots of perks, including fabulous buffet breakfast on twentieth floor, and two hour complimentary drinks and good nibbles in the evening.Great ground floor bar, restaurants, shops, and excellent staff.Slightly old fashioned in the Grand Hotel style and would say to any traveller, stay here

I've been staying at this hotel for quite number of time and most of it during my business trip tat Tokyo Japan.What I like about this location, it was not as busy at central Tokyo, you can have a quiet stay while still able to commute easily by train because when you step out of the hotel there is Metro station Suitengumae just below the hotel.The room was comfortable considering with the price and location. I love the bed so comfy and always had a good relaxing feeling after long day of work.The staff are very friendly will alwaya try their best to accomodate your needs, even they not speak English very well but they will make sure what you ask or need will be fullfill your needs.The hotel also very convinience due to access to local foods and restaurang in just a walking distance. Moreover, the hotel just located beside the Airport terminal bus which make your travel to Airport very easy.Definately will come back to this hotel whenever I will be travelling to Tokyo again.

The service is excellent. From check-in to check out. The room was warm and cozy. The first time I checked in, I got a room that is very dated. But, the bed was cozy and there's hot shower. Breakfast choices at the Executive Lounge were included in my room and the food was fine. I checked out and checked back in after I returned from the suburbs two days later. The room was very warm and smelled like cigarette even if smoking is not allowed. I asked to be moved and they quickly found another room for me. I was surprised to find a very updated room and the A/C was cool. They were very apologetic about it.You can walk to the train station from the lower level so you don't get wet when it rains. That is really convenient. Lots of restaurants within the vicinity. Good location and price point

Been here many times.Superb service and lovely location.In the Suburbs of Tokyo, great walks nearby and lovely restaurants just down the street. Rooms are big and very comfortable Great Bar in the basement

Directly Bus Connection from/to the Airport Haneda & Narita. Also the Subway is very close! The Hotel is surrounded by many great restaurants but also the food in the hotel is very good. Nice Room with a soft mattress - like it! Friendly Staff! Will come back soon!

My second time staying at this hotel.Great location near TCAT and lots of good restaurants around the area.Best part of the friendly and very helpful staff. One can really feel the staff makes a big difference at this hotel.

Now 10 years I go periodically to Tokyo, and I always stay in this hotel. Location is perfect, service is good, and people are always very nice. Executive level is recommended, allowing to have breafast on the top level, with a wonderful view on Tokyo city.

My bf and I stayed here for a week (March 28 to April 4). The hotel was very clean and very business like. I love that this hotel has a subway line underground which can connect to main lines like Ginza, Shibuya, etc. At the front desk you can purchase a 3 days pass for unlimited rides to all Tokyo metro line for a discounted price. The location is great because it's not very busy if that's what you are looking for. There are some nearby restaurants as well that is worth trying out. I remember eating at this ramen place (I forget the name but it was yummy). There's a 7-11 around the corner and a family mart right across the street. The -1 star is for the extra charge to use the gym which my bf and I used 4x ($25 per person/per day). But all in all we had an awesome experience here. The room is definitely roomier compared to what we stayed in Osaka or Kyoto (bigger than your typical Japanese hotel). Another plus is the transportation bus station to the left side of the hotel, which had restaurants inside as well and for small amount you can take the bus to the airport and it's cheaper than a taxi that's for sure.

This is a luxury hotel in Tokyo. Slippers, bathrobe, pyjamas, team etc in room, full mini-bar, excellent sheets, very quiet, perfect sauna, pool, executive lounge, really this was flawless.Being built on top of the Nihunbaski subway, and located at 2 mins from the TCAT central bus status for airport limousine buses, it couldnt better located yet remain quiet and calm

I came here on 31st July and will stay until 30th Aug . We all colleague got room on same floor 1250. Staff​ are quite friendly.There is free Porter service from City air terminal you need to pick phone and call person will be there with trolly in 10 min . Checking was smooth we arrived at 11:55 and called for Porter service by 12:30 we a we're in our respective rooms. Breakfast is good but less option for vegetarian I will upload snaps of veg food . We were also provided with handy mobile which don't have any rental or charges we can use for data and calling however. India calling is not available.
user_name:
Priyadarshi Var... R
Petaling Jaya, Malaysia

review_body: Being located right next to the T-Cat Limousine Centre and having a link bridge to the hotel really makes this hotel a great and convenient location. It is also located on top of the Suitengu station on the Hanzomon subway line. Staff are courteous and speak English decently.
