The breakfast menu at the ground floor cafe is wide, with Japanese and Western food on offer. It does get crowded during the weekdays as it is a popular place for breakfast for he locals. The hotel offers a cocktails between 5-8pm daily for their guests staying at their executive rooms. Wines, liquors, sake and beers are offered as well as decent finger foods for the cocktail hours. The location of their executive lounge is fantastic - at 20th floor, you get to see Tokyo sunset skyline clearly as well as the river on the other side. Remember to go to the lounge as early as your schedule allow as the good window seats get taken pretty fast

Had booked this for three nights. We had the Executive Lounge access and breakfast included. Couldn't get into room and had a drink at bar on ground level. Bit dear. Room was a good size and we got a super king bed after expecting a queen which suited me better. The lounge on the 20th had all sorts of nibbles and drinks so could get a light feed. This has some good views. It is also where breakfast is done in the morning and they have a chef to do omelettes etc. All the staff were very friendly and aimed to help. The pool wasn't open while there. It is also close to the TCAT terminal which runs buses to and from Haneda and Narita airports. There are also many subway stations to use to get around Tokyo.

I stayed in this hotel for 4 nights in the middle of July. It had been 4 years since my last visit there. As soon as I walked into the lobby it was exactly as I had remembered it. Nice. Elegant. When I got to my room, I turned on the air conditioning because the room was warm. The room was clean and nicely furnished. I was trying to remember why I stopped staying here. I grabbed my stuff and headed to the executive lounge on the 20th floor. This was new. The old exec lounge was on the 16th floor and was quite small, tired, and kind of dingy. But this new lounge was an entire corner of the building and was fabulous. Open, airy, with some amazing views. I logged onto the free Wifi and checked the speed - 20 Mbps download and 21 upload. Pretty good. Why did I stop coming here, I thought? I worked for a few hours and had a couple of free drinks during happy hour, closed up, and went back to the room to get ready for dinner. That was when it hit me. I went back to the room and it was still really warm. It had not dropped a degree it felt like. Then I remembered. The air conditioning sucks here. I called the front desk to complain and they promptly sent up an engineer. He replaced the airtake filter because it was filthy and clogged. He tinkered inside the air vent, closed it, and said that would take care of it. It did not. All night, and every night I was there, I was miserable. I would wake up in the middle of the night, hot, and sweating. I told this story to a friend of mine who had stayed there and he said the same thing. When he complained, they sent someone up to his room to look at his unit, but it did not change a thing. He thought they were trying to do some kind of placebo effect to make us feel cooler.Later that night I met friends at the Chinese restaurant in the hotel. We had the hotel special for $50 a person, which was about half the usual cost we were told. With drinks it was ~$400 for 6 people. While the food was good, it was way overpriced, and I left kind of hungry. I was reminded of the 1 time I ate at the sushi bar in the hotel. I had 2 plates of sushi samples (10 pieces), 1 piece of sashimi, and 2 beers. Cost $180. Let me just say. The hotel is nice. The staff is very attentive. The free breakfast in the morning is good, but since it starts at 7 am makes it too late for me to use every day. I wish they opened it up at 6:30 or even better, 6 am. And now they have in-room cell phones for patrons to use that give you free international calls and internet. That was handy. And I really appreciated the late check out - 2:30. But I won't be coming back anytime soon.For me, a good night's sleep is the most important thing. And I did not get that there. Which totally surprises me because this is by far the most expensive hotel I stayed at while I was in Tokyo but had the worst air conditioning. I did see a letter from the hotel on the dresser asking us to pardon them for the noise while they remodel the rooms. I can only say I hope they fix the damn air conditioning. It's the one thing stopping me from coming back.

Very big hotel that offers everything to satisfy its clientele! The staff was very helpful and always smiling!The pool is lovely and a great way to relax after a long day at work or strolling through the city.. The rooms are big enough and well clean!Great place!

Rooms are average, but they are well above average for Japan but moderate by American standards. You can upgrade to an executive room that will have free Western style buffet breakfast and also access to the top floor lounge in the evening for drinks and small finger foods. Centrally located near the subway so you can access the city easily. Also next to the Tokyo Air Terminal (TCAT).

We were able to get transportation to/from the airport via shuttle right into the station there. They met us at the station and transported our luggage. Helpful and professional staff. Near subway, restaurants, stores, etc. The room was a bit worn/dated, but huge for Japan. The staff were a bit staunchy, but I think it is cultural, rather than anything else. You will be walking distance from several temples, the river, there is a beautiful Japanese garden right there, but you have to eat at the restaurant to see it. Breakfast was available for purchase at restaurant in hotel, but pricey, but unless you eat breakfast at McDonalds or the 7-11, you will pay a premium for breakfast elsewhere anyway. There is a McDonalds in the station next door and a 7-11 across the street. Absolutely loved the subway station downstairs. so convenient and kept us dry on rainy days. The concierge was helpful with maps of the city and you can buy subway passes right there.

My stay was brilliant at this hotel. Staff are very friendly, hotel in itself is big and grand. Rooms spacious and has everything you need. Many places around to eat. Easy connection to the metro. Would highly recommend.

Near 2 subway stations, airport bus terminal, and a nice park across river. Restaurants, convenient stores, various shops, over 100-yr old establishments surround property. Room key is a fancy old-fashioned room key that could be dropped off and picked up at front desk. Breakfast is very pricey. Eateries are nearby for breakfast, lunch and/or dinner. Room and bathroom are modern. Moderate space with mini fridge.

First time staying here but it was much better than a hotel I used to stay before.Rooms are spacious, breakfast very good and with nice selection and diversity. I took the club room as it has extra access to club floor and lounge with free drinks and snacks throughout the day.Location is one of a kind - direct access to metro and direct busses to Narita and Haneda airports.The only negative think - no flexibility. I have arrived early in the morning but could get the room only after 3 PM. Or order one for full day for the night before...

Was here for business and found this hotel just right. In a good location close to two subway lines so it's easy to get to most locations in Tokyo with only a few stops. Enough good places to eat within walking distance and the TCAT is connected by covered walkway which was great given the day I was heading back to Narita was raining and I was able to keep everything dry. The 7/11 in the tcat also made it easy to get some snacks or money at the ATM and there are also several grocery stores a short walk away. The staff was overly helpful so no complaints there.

I stayed here on business with a friend and while the location is a little inconvenient to Tokyo Station, the stay itself was wonderful. The property is a little older, but very well taken care of and the staff is very friendly. We ate within the hotel and liked that experience as well.

This is a good if sightly old fashioned hotel. Comfy beds, polite and helpful staff, rooms a good size and very quiet despite being next to the freeway into downtown Tokyo. Easy to get cabs from here but the cabs don't know the hotel, so unless you have a printed Japanese address getting home after a night in Ginza could be difficult! The cabs use the numerical code in the address for their sat nav, so as long as you have that its ok...or ask for the TCAT terminal - most know that and its right next door. The hotel says just use the connecting walkway between hotel and terminal...yeah right! If you can find it...its tucked by the side of the main lift on the second floor but once you locate, it is a 1 minute walk, so very convenient. The reason I am not rating this hotel higher is that breakfast is an eye watering £35 a pop - ouch!

The hotel is conveniently located next to the subway and a main railway station. My single room had a comfortable nearly king sized bed with down pillows.. I really appreciated the pillows. The room was quiet and the decor was attractive. The room included a mini-bar, a hot water pot for coffee or tea and a TV with English channels. The hotel entrance is quite lovely. All of the staff where very pleasant and helpful. There are several restaurants in the area......we ate in an excellent Chinese restaurant. The Family Mart, just across the street, is a good place to purchase snacks and wine to bring back to your room.

Hotel is very good located - direct connection to Narita Airport by Limousine bus. Subway is directly accessible from hotel hall. Also the neighborhood is full with good small restaurants, shops etc. where you can have a lunch or dinner. Prices are moderate.Service everywhere in the hotel is simply the best. Rooms are clean, a little bit small as to european taste, but ok. Sleeping quality is high.Breakfast is good, especially fresh pressed juices are very tasty. Everything you need to start your day - you will find.Hotel is highly recommended for any kind of stay.

Hotel old but well kept. Centra yo TCAT and lots of restaurants. Whiskey and cigar bar down stairs fantastic - great selection and prices are decent given it's in a hotel. Small selection of cigars, but have Cubans. Lobby bar good but expensive. Happy hour is a good deal. Service excellent. Rooms good size for Tokyo. Twin beds have to go.

The Royal Park Hotel is an ideally located hotel in Nihombashi, close to a main railway station, metro and to the bus service to Narita Airport. Rooms are clean but small and have all amenities a business traveller requires. Breakfast and drinks/dinner available at a surcharge at the Executive Lounge on the top floor with stunning views of Tokyo.Restaurants available in the immediate neighborhood.

Good location with easy access to subway, shuttle to airport (inexpensive and easy access!) and good service. The room was available early and was relatively roomy with comfortable beds. In hotel restaurants are pricey but there are so many area restaurants in walking distance. Also- Family Mart across the street has anything you need from snacks to ATM. Ask for subway map and walking map at Concierge and enjoy the area.

Stayed here meant times in the past. I can see elements of my experiences here in the other posts. First is it's an easy option. You can book easily online, the executive lounge is a good option as it means food and drink on tap which makes life much easier. I think the hotel restaurants are expensive. Catching the airport bus from Narita is very easy, happy smiling English speaking folks will sell you a ticket to the TCAT, buses run to the minute, English speaking folks will check your ticket and get you on the right bus. There is a discount for foreigners.The TCAT is right next door to the hotel. Note return bus is caught from level 3 which seems odd until you are used to it. Timetables and prices all online. I quite like the old grandeur of the lobby, they just need more places to sit. Check in, well UK flights can arrive in the morning well before the 3pm time, I've had mixed success in an earlier time, it's not a given. This trip I had to pay for the extra hour to check in at 2pm which seemed a bit stiff given how many times I've stayed there before.Rooms are a bit old, but to be honest doesn't worry me, pillows and mattress definitely "firm" rooms are accessed by a large conventional key, I was sad to learn that will be changed soon, never had a key not work, but electronic ones many times.Road down from the hotel has many restaurants, and one can walk to some of the sights with good directions. It's a quiet area, I've never felt unsafe.I've walked to Akihabara a few times but it's quite a stroll.I'm sure there are better hotels, but this one is predictable and easy. I'll likely stay again next time.If you take a taxi take the available card in Japanese, there are a few Royal Park hotels in Tokyo

Convenient location, but they haven't put any money into renovation and they need to modernize and upgrade rooms and service levels. Rooms, bathrooms, are old---same as they've been for a decade, and many still smell of smoke, beds are just a bit above bare utilitarian--no "dream beds" here. They are competing on price and location, not on quality, which may be fine for a short business stay, but I wouldn't stay here on holiday. In 2017, this is not a luxury property. It is serviceable at best.

One of the nicest hotels in Yokohama. Price is reasonable compared to other hotels in the area.Excellent service - from reception to checkout. Excellent breakfast buffet (for about a week then it get's old - understandable). About 10 minutes from YCAT if you want to take the bus to Narita Airport. You can run around the hotel block (3 rounds=5 kilometers) or you can go to Rinko Park.

Nice hotel, friendly and professional staff. Breakfast is okay but I would ask more variety of fruit and food to a 4-star hotel like this and the money you pay.I have stayed at this hotel for business purposes since 2004 and always got my room upon check-in, early in the morning (most international flights from Europe arrive at this time of the day). This time they said that either I had to wait until 15:00 (that is their official check-in time) or to pay some thousands of yen (honestly, I don't remember the actual figure) to get my room. When I told the receptionist that I had stayed there for the last 13 years, they didn't care at all. He just shrugged and said that the hotel has changed its policy.Then, when I was given the room at 3:00 pm, I had to wait for 15 minutes to get my luggage delivered in my room. The moment I called the laundry service to get, at least, one suit ironed they said that I had to pay extra (the express service) to get my suit back in the evening. The thing is that items taken before 3:00 pm are delivered the same day.So, I am sorry because I like the place and the service, in general, but I may be booking a different hotel next year.

The Royal Hotel Park is the place to stay if you need to be around the Chuo city.Direct lines to both airports via TCAT and direct access to subway from the hotel (Hanzomon line - Z)Excellent service and food.Large room with a dated decoration.Definitively worth the price.

The probably only positive aspect is the location next to the metro station. This hotel needs a renervation from ground up. The entrance hall looks very old and also our room hasen't been renovated or maintained for years. It was one of the unstilished rooms ever for me. The even don't have key cards to enter the room you only get one key. The size of the room was ok and you also get all required amenities in the room. The fitness center closes already at 9. So your working the is limited ;-) You also have to pay 2000 Yen for the usage, I never experienced something in a hotel yet. I would rate it as a 3-star hotel but not more.

I stayed here for one week in mid-April with another family member, and we both enjoyed our experience here. Although slightly dated (the bathroom in particular could be renovated), the rooms at this hotel are large by Tokyo standards (we stayed in the deluxe twin bed room), very clean, comfortable and are equipped with nice toiletries. The staff are very friendly and helpful (not surprising, considering this is an upper-end Japanese hotel), and we liked the fact that the cleaning staff would ask when we wanted our room to be cleaned. This hotel still has physical room keys, of which there is only one per room. We would need to leave ours at the front desk, but the staff made retrieval of those keys quite simple (you never have to wait in line). While most centrally located Tokyo hotels have easy access to Tokyo's excellent public transportation system, this hotel is unique in that it is right next door to Tokyo City Air Terminal, making arrival and departure from Tokyo's airports very convenient. I would definitely stay here again, if I can get a good rate.
user_name:
SoloFemaleTraveler11
New York City, New York

review_body: My husband and I stayed there for recent trip to see Cherry blossoms. I was very impressed with the size of the Double room. The hotel was very clean and probably the quietest hotel I have ever been in, despite being right next to the TCAT bus terminal, subway station and Hakozaki Junction. The staff was very helpful and the location is great with direct access to the Hanzomon subway line.

An excellent location and ease access by Luxury bus or train because of TCAT location right next and attached to hotel. Could not ask for a better location. Hotel nice accommodations, only issue across all hotels is room size for Americans

First time stay at this hotel with my family and booked a deluxe twin bed room. The room is really spacious, very clean and comfortable. Good supply of toiletries and air conditioning. We had good sleep during the stay. The staff are really helpful as a girl staff helped us the deliver our luggage to the bus station which is really impressive. The breakfast was at high quality though less variety. Really love the location as it is just above the metro and next to the airport bus terminal. The neighborhood is quiet but has a few convenient stores and 24 hrs restaurants. Overall a very good stay and will definitely come back again.

This hotel is so very convenient, the fourth exit of the Suitengūmae station (Hanzomon line) brings you direct to the hotel - you can even get a lift from the subway to your hotel floor. Tokyo's transport is very efficient and the location means you can be quickly anywhere you want, both business and tourist destinations - our trip was a mix of both.On check-in, it was disappointing that it took three attempts to get the room we had booked (not a specific room, but a double bed that had previously been confirmed) the room itself was large, especially by Tokyo standards. The style is slightly dated, but the rooms were obviously expensively commissioned at the time and the furnishings show no sign of wear whatsoever. No iron in the room but they quickly lent one to us - had we found the guest services brochure that was hidden in a drawer we probably would have used their service. Unexpectedly for a hotel of this standard, there was no English language television.The gym and swimming pool are both a good size. The pool is run very functionally, and not one for lounging around. The team really redeemed themselves with eating recommendations, and in particular Ayaka Obuchi worked hard to secure difficult reservations at a top restaurant, for which we will remain very grateful.

We have been there only for two nights but the hotel is amazing. We have chosen a room with access to the executive lounge (gym and swimming pool included, breakfast, caffè and sweets 10:00-17:00, drinks and appetizers 17:00-21:00 with free access). The metro stop is in the basement. There are 5 restaurants inside the hotel. Amazing! I have asked for a gluten free breakfast and they have been able to tell me all the allergens in the food available.

The Royal Park is an elegant hotel similar to a Marriott in quality, but with a tasteful Japanese decor. Rooms are comfortable, service is good, and breakfast room very acceptable. Clientele is pleasant.The hotel is is conveniently located next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal... not in the expensive "downtown" area, but a convenient taxi ride away. The express bus is the only way to travel to Tokyo from the airports. Comfortable and relaxing. Taxis are very expensive and rail can be a hassle.

Nice, large, and clean roomsImpressive lobby and breakfast areaOld fashion bathroom but still very cleanPerfect for a business trip, though not cheapGreat location with metro and taxi availableService and staff are excellent

Recently stayed here for two nights with my young daughter and thoroughly enjoyed it. The rooms are massive by Tokyo standard, despite needing some updating. However, the hotel is definitely luxurious, and their 5 star self description is merited. Location wise, the nearest metro stop is a block away and the hotel is directly connected to the Limousine Bus Service terminal. Additionally, taxis can always be found lined up outside the entrance, awaiting their next fare. Without question, I would stay here again, despite not having tried any of the onsite restaurants which have amazing reviews.

This is from a stay in late 2016 - great location, nice hotel. It could look dated but the perfect location considering a direct limo bus ride from Narita and back.The train station is right below the hotel which makes it even better for connectivity. There are great restaurants nearby - value and cuisines.

Right next to the Transport hub and subway underneath the hotel makes this very convenient for travellers. Our room was spacious with enough cupboard space to allow us to completely unpack our suitcases. The surrounding area is very flat allowing for easy walking to explore the local areas. The staff are very accommating and friendly. The amenities of this hotel are very good (pool/gym). It was our first visit to this area of Tokyo and whilst there is a lot to do, it is mainly the business side of Tokyo. Good food areas but not that much in the way of high end shopping.

I would not recommend staying at this hotel. I asked if they could hold my suitcases and no one told me that someone spilled some sort of greasy soup all over my suitcase. It leaked down on to my suits and I can't get the smell out. I get that accidents happen but I would have preferred knowing about it rather than the incident being shoved under the rug.

I stayed in this hotel for 8 days. Everything in it was great! It made our trip experience much more comfortable and exciting!The rooms are so clean, the room service is great and they helped us with everything we asked for. All the small items we needed in the trip were available in the room. The breakfast is so delicious and the staff are so welcoming and helpful.The location of the hotel is excellent with direct access to the metro station.If you're staying in Tokyo and thinking about a hotel to stay at, I strongly recommend this hotel.

The room was perfect in every way, clean and tidy with excellent service everyday.Every request that I made was actioned immediately with kindness and in a happy way.Assistance in obtaining a Taxi to an area that I was was not sure of was confirmed by the Hotel staff which ensured my arrival on time for my meeting.

Second best hotel I have been in Tokyo (after Shangri-la) . Very convenient , because it is above Bus stop from Narita Airport . The executive rooms are huge (for Tokyo standarts ) , with all the amenities you wish . The buffet Breakfast is very good . I highly recommend if you have to be near Nihombash or Tokyo Station . Location is not so lively as Shinjuku .

Service is outstanding. Got upgraded to executive floor. Breakfast there was outstanding with a chef on hand to freshly cook all your needs. cocktail hour was serve yourself, but nice display of appetizers. Room were very clean and well kept. Thanks

Have been staying at the Royal Park for several years and am always pleased with the quality of the staff and facility. It's location is excellent for our business and conveniently located by TCAT and the Honzomon line.

This hotel is in a great location, right next to the bus terminal for the airport. There's nothing wrong with the hotel, the staff is great, the rooms are a decent size (for Tokyo), and the food is good.The keys are unique, I can't remember the last time I received a real key for a hotel room, but it's not an issue because you leave the key with the staff when you go out.Downstairs has a smoking lounge which I haven't seen since probably the 80's, which is cool if you smoke.Other reviewers are correct in stating that the hotel does seem a little dated, but it's nothing to deter you from staying here.When I booked my room I got breakfast included, so you might want to look into that if the prices are high for breakfast (as some other reviews concluded).

Stayed at the Park Royal for 4 nights. The hotel rooms felt a little dated but they were definitely larger than the standard hotel rooms in Tokyo. Had access to the Executive Lounge and utilized it for happy hour...enjoyed some drinks and snacks which actually led me to skip dinner one evening. Breakfast was ok, not bad and not extraordinary...I guess it just works. Not sure if they do change the breakfast spread everyday as I only had one breakfast in the hotel given my early meetings.

I stayed here recently for several nights with my husband who was conducting business in Tokyo. We had an executive king room that was well equipped but rather small (although probably average by Tokyo standards).The hotel does appear to cater to foreign business travelers, judging by the many present the following morning at breakfast and the fact that breakfast items were significantly more western than Japanese.The overall level of service was excellent, with special recognition to Masaichi Yamamoto and Kotaro Takahashi for their assistance in helping us plan a day trip to Jigokudani (Snow Monkey Park). It was a wonderful day out thanks to them! Another plus of the Royal Park Hotel is its close proximity to TCAT (with direct buses to both Narita and Haneda airports. Very convenient indeed!

It's 1 month shy of 4 years since I was here last. The hotel seemed a bit dated then and it still does, but don't let that dissuade you. It has been impeccably maintained. I routinely write about the grime that accumulates in other establishments, sometimes in just months. Staying at the Royal Park it's as if I just left yesterday. EVERYTHING is impeccably clean and in working order. The executive lounge has been remodeled for the better. Service continues to be attentive. This is a relatively commercial part of Tokyo, but the hotel's location is exceedingly convenient to mass transit. Within 1-2 miles / 3-4 km walks are an a number of good eateries and simple though delightful attractions. No, this isn't Disney world; ain't that grand!

The staff were all excellent, but the hotel was super dated (at several points it felt like the Overwatch Hotel from The Shining) and the food/drinks were incredibly overpriced. We each had an omelette and potatoes for breakfast one morning and our bill was around US$55, and even for that money they were without a doubt the worst omlettes we've ever been served, while the lyonnaise potatoes were flat out inedible.That said, the location is great for transport as well as easy walking to many restaurants and stores, and the view from the top floor is excellent.

i have stayed in multiple hotels in tokyo, from the cheap and dumpy to the expensive and chic, Royal Park falls into the mid range. the hotel is very large, is spotlessly clean and well maintained, if a little dated in decor (1990's style). service is excellent, every staff member we encountered was flawlessly trained.the breakfast buffet was ok but i think for the price ($35), it should have been better, there are many very high end hotels in tokyo that charge similar breakfast prices but have a much nicer buffet selection. if you're looking to spend $250-300 a night in Tokyo, you could do much worse than staying here.

This hotel is located next to TCAT and thus trips to and from Narita and Haneda Airports are convenient. There is not much to see around the hotel, but Subway Hanzomon Line "Suitengu-mae" station is in the basement of this hotel, so it's easy to move. The hotel is a little run down, but it's generally kept clean. The restaurants are expensive.

Courteous staff, easy access to subway, rooms a little dated, on-premise restaurants heavily overpriced, area quiet but quick access to many external (good and cheap) eateries. Location not ideal for sightseeing: That always requires use of the subway - hotel sells 24/48h subway passes.

PROS- Check-in and check-out: fast and efficient- General cleanness: perfect- Amenities in the toilet: very good, wide kit available- Complementary and frees: free water available in the room all the time- Tv channels available: International channels available- Internet available: free and decent speed- Location: beside T-cat, in fact with direct walkway. very convinient- Breakfast: very good in fact, plenty of western optionsCON- Restaurants and bars: very expensive- Price value: very expensive considering what you get. the hotel is good, but too overpriced.- bedroom keys: old style a very heavyDO I WILL RETURN?- Maybe not, due to the price

The pricing is reasonable for Tokyo. The room was adequate with housekeeping doing a good job. Hotel is a little run-down and could use an update, especially when the key is a literal key which is quite heavy, compared to a key card, which I am so used to. The chair to the desk is very close to the bed and it makes moving around a little challenging.The buffet breakfast is good but only on the weekends. The weekday has a buffet breakfast but only western and no Japanese. Makes me wonder why Japanese food is passed over from western for a Japanese hotel?Strategically located next to the TCAT, making trips to and from Narita and Haneda airports really convenient. There is also a train station linked directly to the hotel basement, running through the Hanzomon line, which makes it convenient to drop by Tsukiji Fish Market. The Hibiya line is also just about 5 minutes walk away.

The hotel is in a quiet area of Tokyo, which is nice if that is what you are looking for. Really clean and the staff is very friendly. Take advantage of the fact that the hotel has a subway exit built right into the bottom of the hotel and ride the subway, very convenient,
user_name:
Andrew R
Irvine, California, United States

review_body: I've stayed at the Royal Park hotel 3 times now because it's near where I'm usually working.The hotel is super easy to get to from Narita airport - just buy a ticket for the Airport Limousine bus at arrivals (you need the T-CAT stop but they will know the hotel name too), go outside, and wait for the bus. It is very efficient with someone to take your ticket and luggage and tell you where to wait. When you get on the bus messages are in English and Japanese so you know when to get off. Once you get to T-CAT, the hotel is next door (although. Above hard to find without wandering around a bit first time).You can take the bus back to the airport too. One strange thing; you don't appear to be able to buy tickets for the next day - so if you have an early flight you feel a. It exposed. Never had a problem though.Although it's easy to eat in the hotel (most other places have very little English) it is very expensive. I'd advise taking a chance on any local restaurant and pointing your way though. There are lots of them - a number in the T-CAT building and loads on the streets. Find somewhere with a picture menu and you're away. Everyone very friendly.Hotel rooms very adequate. I always worry that the air con doesn't seem very powerful but leave it on a while and the room cools ok. Electronic toilet with gadgets and buttons is... interesting.Hotel is near metro lines so easy to get into rest of Tokyo. You can walk around the streets safely enough.All in all perfect for my needs.

Great hotel with good service and amenities in the heart of Tokyo. Great for the business traveller or tourist. Rooms could do with freshening up but apart from that its a great place to stay. Exceptional staff service throughout the hotel

Very central location for business, it even has a metro station on the basement. The room need to be updated ASAP but have decent space for being in Tokyo. There are many dining options in the hotel and the breakfast buffet is very good.

I always book a de luxe room, executive floor which is spacious, comfortable, and good value. Convenience of being next to TCAT, and above subway station is excellent. I like the fact that the aircon can be turned down to 18 deg C. The room is a little dated, I did not have an upgraded bathroom, but that is not important. Huge double bed, good quality sheets, and pillows. Service excellent, as ever. I still regret the decision to remove the bar on the 20th floor, which I think is a mistake. The basement bar is not good.

Very good option in terms of quality of service, location and pricing. It is very comfortable and classic - dont expect any etravaganza or design objects. It's convinient location allows for business trips but also for sightseeing - the metro station is located directly under hotel. Easy to reach from Narita - indeed city terminal is just next doors. Generally, worth of consideration.

For a 5 stars hotel...... very bad room. I will stay 15 days from 13 November to 26 of November2016 ......and has you can see on the photos it's not the same has you have on de website.... the room is dirty with dust very old decoration. I was aspecting a little bit more. I have to feel the bed this night ;).

Huge hotel, as I read in one of the reviews a little bit worn out, front desk personnel too obsequious for me and not really caring to solve your problems. For the pros, metro station is just under the hotel which is convenient and rooms are clearly big for Tokyo. I don't see a lot more. Given the pricing, I just find it a little bit short...

We stayed at the Royal Park Hotel in Oct 2016, for 4 nights. We also stayed at the Cerulean Hotel on the same trip for 4 nights too, so it is easy to compare what “luxury hotel” is about. The Royal Park Hotel is old, I mean, you can call it charming if you like, but it’s an old hotel. We could hear toilets flushing, people sneezing, and people talking. We had 3 women staying in the room next to ours, and we listened to their conversation all night long  - They’re trying for sure, but I find it way too expensive for the exact same thing offered to you at the Cerulean. I could describe the state of the rooms and hotel in details, but I don’t want to be mean. I think it is listed as a luxury hotels because of the amenities it can provide. What one needs to know though, is that the pool and spa is supplement, so is breakfast…it wasn’t the case at the other luxurious hotel we stayed at. The staff is nice, the breakfast buffet is good, and its easy access to the subway is a plus. I liked that the clientele is mostly Japanese, unlike at the Cerulean where I felt like being in the U.S. still
user_name:
MireilleNYC
New York City, New York

review_body: Fantastic hotel, I don't even know where to start. Excellent location, with a direct bus from the airport, an excellent modern gym, with sauna and a 20m pool, the rooms are very clean, there is an excellent fridge with the right amount of products in it, the bathroom does not miss anything (in fact you are given all kinds of amenities), iron, iron table, the laundry and dry clean service are excellent and the staff one of the best I have seen. The breakfast room has an amazing view of Tokyo, is friendly and the buffet although not too big, absolutely perfect. Excellent espresso available as well.

Very convenient hotel, right next to TCAT so getting to/from airports very easy. Good location within easy walking distance of shops, grocery store and numerous eating places. Rooms are fairly spacious very clean

I stay at the Royal Park minimum twice a year for the last ten years and one would think they would be more welcoming. Maybe its the language barrier but no loyalty program is offered. I have just found out that I can only get points using my airlines loyalty program as my bookings are under a corporate rate. If its not for the location, sizes of the rooms and the rate, the hotel could do with an attitude revamp.

The Royal Park Hotel certainly meets the expectations any traveler may have for a big-city business hotel may have. Friendly staff (have yet to meet any unfriendly customer service / customer contact person in Japan, very clean rooms with everything you need ( within a week, I stayed at the hotel twice: the first night, I had a relatively small room, but equipped with all necessities and with a real nice bathroom, the second night, I had a much larger room with a more "normal" Western style bathroom. The hotel is home of several restaurants and if that is not enough, many more eating places are within walking distance. The airport bus terminal is also within 2- or 3 minutes walking distance A large breakfast buffet with Western and Japanese choices makes the first meal of the day a real pleasure. Only surprise (and I am not sure how common that is in Japan); there was a 2000 Yen charge to use the relatively small gym. And yes: one more thing: the hotel has old fashioned keys..real keys..no cards.

I was booked here because of a business event which is held here. For the convenience of not needing to wait up early, Travelling and stuck in the jam, I stayed here for 5 days. The evening I checked in, I was shocked by the key which they handed to me. I have not had a large heavy physical key for room from all these years of staying in any hotel. As mine is a business executive room, I have access to the executive rooms for breakfast and meetings. They issued coupons for each day for breakfast and check out time is 3 pm( which is great for me as my flight is. 5 pm ). This is great ! The room is spacious as compared to other Tokyo hotel room.I like their porter service. The girl porter helped to push the 3 luggages from the room to the Tokyo City Airport Terminal and waited for me till I got my limo bus service tickets. She off loaded everything onto the terminal trolley before leaving. This is really some service since the City Terminal is 3 min walking outside of the hotel, crossing a traffic light. I also like the amenities for the room. Each is packed individually for hygiene reasons. Shower Cap, mouth wash, toothbrush and paste, a set of nail clippers, cotton buds and facial pads and nail filing board. There is a air purifier next to my bed. Hot water heater and bottles of water. The housekeeper came over the first day to hand me a pack of small bottles of facia Wash, toner and moisturer from the local high end ( elixir ) Shiseido ingredient brand With exception of the loud noise from the key opening door from neighbors, it is quite a quite floor for me . The corridor is a big dim though. The best is the ground floor connects to the Subway. Very convenient for Travelling on train. Breakfast at the executive floor has a good view. Highly recommend for those who has a temporary overnight or 2 stays in Tokyo as this hotel is about 15 min to Tokyo station and 15 min taxi to Tsukiji fish market. Taxi fare about 1000 yen each trip. It is 3 subway stops to Kinshicho ( young shopping area) and 1 Subway direct stop Nihombashi shopping belt where Takashimaya and COREDO and Mitsuikoshi Nihombashi shopping department stores.

I am staying at this hotel most of the time, when I am in Tokyo. Its a well equipped hotel, conveniently located next to the T-CAT. There were never troubles, until this time. At the reception was some unfriendly staff. I had dinner in the 20st floor (exceptional kitchen I must say) and was applying for their membership card THE CLUB. As I wanted to have also my stay credited with points, I was told at the reception, that this does not apply for cheap internet rates. Actually the booking was done by phone and then changed at the reception with a night for more than 200€ without b/f.Then they asked me for a surcharge of about 40€, as I arrived at 4:30pm at the hotel, but I was told, that rate applies only from 7pm onwards. The hotel was maybe half occupied on check-in. It just appeared, they wanted to make some additional money. After hefty discussions, they finally refrained from charging me.Last but not least, they did not grant me access to the SPA on the second day - the first day they did. I was told, access is not included.So all in all a rather unpleasant stay this time. I still hope, this was an exception as otherwise the hotel is ok. Some of the reception staff seem not to understand, what customer loyalty and authentic hospitality means.

Loved that it was above the subway so very convenient to transportation. Airport limo from Narita stops directly there- nice after travelling. Staff extremely helpful. Buy metro passes right at hotel. Room nice size. Executive lounge has nice appetizers that actually filled us up for first night dinner. Free drinks, too. Great view from lounge. We had nice room with view of city. We recommend for service and convenience to city.

Not bad but quite impersonal. Not one of those quaint hotels that tourists who want the real flavour of the place would select. It is convenient though and has a nice executive lounge on the top floor which offer a very nice view (telling you that Tokyo seems to be a never ending city!). The rooms are large enough, furniture impersonal again and a bit aging, bathroom is fine and all is clean (that's Japan!). All in all it is decent value for money in Tokyo but not an unforgettable experience (hotelwise only... as Tokyo is fantastic!)

A regular type room at the executive floor is not very large for two persons, but the guest lounge at the top floor is wide enough and you can stay comfortable with various kinds of food / drinks and good view of Tokyo.Room rate is reasonable compared to other five star hotels nearby. Access to the hotel from Haneda airport is very good if you use the shuttle bus to TCAT within one minute walk from the hotel. The negative thing is that number of elevators are not more than enough and a little slow.

Whilst the rooms were on the warm side (78-80 f) and the rooms are a little on the worn side...aged a bit. The services and food were spectacular. The staff are definitely 5 stars.And The hotel is right across the street to the city airport terminal for fast and easy transit to Narrita.

I use this hotel now for more than 12 years, it is very convenient as the TCAT station is right next door. This time I had a renovated room which means the bathroom has been totally renovated and the rest of the room had a "soft" make over. I generally like this hotel, the staff is excellent and helpful. On the negative site however I was disappointed due to my early check in they have charged me an additional 193 Dollars. The room was ready and this just plain rude to charge a loyal customer this amount of money just for an early check in. The hotel is in bad need of a total renovation as it is just very dated and some of the carpets look very bad.

Think of the 1950's, slaves to rules and a lack of any sense in hotel management and you have this hotel.No food in restaurants after 2150. Only bar food on room service after 2150, which you can't eat a lt a restaurant. No iron available half the time and useless tabletop ironing boards. All tv channels (even CNN and BBC) in Japanese only.This place is really bad.

The Royal Park hotel in Nihonbashi was very nice, and an enjoyable stay in Tokyo. Staff were welcoming the facilities were nice and accessible, and the rooms were tidy presentable and well kept by the staff. Thank you for a great stay. Cheers

We always stay at this hotel in the center of Tokyo with direct access to the metro and 10 minutes from Ginza. It is a traditional hotel with all modern comfort including spa at very reasonable prices. It is also right next to City Air Terminal - therefore easy to reach the airports. Needless to say that the service is immaculate.

Stayed for one week on business. Enjoyed great service from helpful, friendly and professional staff. Room, fitness, pool and restaurants were all very nice. Close to Subway station. Bus to airport next door. Recommend it highly. Different types of restaurants from sub level to 20th floor. Breakfast on 20th floor was excellent (only if your room is on executive floor).

I have stayed at this hotel several times last 15 years and I am always pleased with the comfort and service provided. Breakfast is excellent as well as the (expensive) Teppanyaki restaurant on top floor with nice view of the Tokyo skyline. You need only 2 minutes walk from the Hotel reception to the TCAT bus terminal in the next building, where you find frequent air shuttle connections to Haneda (30 min) and Narita (60 min).

The room facility a bit run down and it may need a refurbishment.Overall desk service is very good.Really convenient to travel to Narita airport as the shuttle bus is just next building to it.In front of hotel is the Suitengumae train station.

In Tokyo for business. This hotel is ideally located next to the TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal), which has regular Limousine Buses to both Haneda and Narita airports.The hotel provides a 5 star service.The room are old fashion and probably would need some updating. However, they are in excellent state and maintenance. If you wish to relax, the TV selection is relatively limited if you don't speak Japanese.I had an executive room with access to the business lounge on the last floor. I would recommend you visit even if just to get to see the great view on Tokyo City, Tokyo Tower, and on the other side of the building, you can see the Tokyo Tree Tower.

I've stayed at Royal Park at several occasions over the last few years and think it's an excellent choice in terms of value for money. It's not exceptionally cheap, but the service is really good. The neighborhood is nice and friendly and you have a large selection of restaurants if you car for walking a block or two and/or up and down the side streets.When it comes to transport this hotel is hard to beat - right next door is the T-CAT bus terminal and in the basement there's a subway station. You will also find plenty of taxis right outside the main entrance at virtually any time of day. If you arrive really early from an overseas' flight you can almost always get an early check-in for a decent fee.The hotel is a bit old and could do with some renovation, which in fact was under way during my last visit. It's also a bit sad that they replaced the really nice sky bar at the top floor with a restaurant that could not recreate the same feeling.But I really like this hotel because it has a distinctly Japanese feeling, as opposed to the global chain hotels.

Stayed just for one night at this excellent hotel for a quick business trip. Had to travel quickly to several locations including from Narita airport and to Haneda airport. Hotel is very close to T-CAT center for buses and has a metro stop in the basement. Its also within walking distance of the Skyline rail line. Very good restaurants within the hotel and some nice local restaurants and shops in surrounding neighborhood. Business ate gave access to the executive lounge on 20th floor where Western style buffet breakfast was served. Pool was shut for maintenance and fitness room is a little small for size of hotel.

Talking about the hotel ...I was upgraded thanks to IPrefer membership. Bigger bedroom - with twin beds. Bathroom out of the 1970s not avaocado green but "peach". Old fashioned except for the mixer taps ... shower curtain needed a deep clean. Aircon worked fine. Housekeeping staff were nice. But overall, nothing special.

The room was well done, and the hotel was convenient to the bus service from the airport. It sits over the subway station making travel to any part of the city easy. The food in the hotel was great, and when you wanted local cuisine the choices were fabulous. I look forward to staying again.

This is a very nice hotel with a nice selection of in-house restaurants. The staff are always available to help you and there is no tipping in Japan. The rooms are good sized with free Wi-Fi and an executive desk for a workspace. The bathroom is typical with a fully automatic toilet and a walk in shower with a tub. Room service is friendly and there are plenty of meals to choose from that you will recognize. There is a mini-bar in the room for cold drinks and ice can be ordered from room service. When I was there, one of the elevators was not in service which made for longer waits. In addition, the two sets of elevators are on different circuits so frequently both sides are chosen and the elevator will stop at floors with no people. While the room is comfortable, they need to work on their air conditioning. I had it set at 20C or 68F and it was nowhere near that temperature ever. This appears to be an older hotel that has been renovated so I would encourage them to upgrade the AC in the next renovation. The lobby is spectacular with a gigantic set of chandeliers and polished marble everywhere. You feel like you’ve entered a palace more than a hotel lobby. Everyone speaks Japanese of course but they make a real effort to make a Westerner feel comfortable. Morning papers are delivered to your door. The TV has the usual few English channel and it takes a while to figure out how to get the English working if it’s a dual language channel. You probably didn’t come to Tokyo to sit in your room and watch TV so it’ll be CNN, Fox, Discovery and a few others to choose from. They also had the ability to play your iPod or iPhone through the TV which was nice.

I have come here over the years for business.The last time in 2008. The hotel has not been updated since I started using it many years before. It was lavish before but looking older and a little worn now. I stayed on the business floor which has extras such as a provided breakfast and appetizers late afternoon. Before, this was catering business travellers but now some travellers use it as an alternative for dinner. The Japanese level of hospitality has slipped a little, probably due to the higher ratio of out of country guests to Japanese guests.Although this has been my favourite place to stay previously, I think I will consider alternate accomodations in the future.

This is a very good Hotel and met our expectation. Staff were extremely good and helpful. One Italian staff at the Hotel Mr. Paolo was good enough to take us to a restaurant about 400 meters away. He was also good enough to suggest us to visit Shibuya which has a direct metro connection and station No. Z-1 on Hanzomon line. No Tokyo visitor should miss this place. The Hotel is also on the same metro line and station code Z-10. The hotel is within 2 minutes walk from Central bus depot for Airport. The hotel staff was again good enough to carry our luggage to the bus station (T-CAT).Nearby shopping places are Ueno (pronounced as Ooeno) and Asakusa, but the best shopping place was Shibuya. I particularly liked the store "Flying Tiger" which was very reasonably priced and had varieties of things to buy from.Renkoji temple which has an emotional value for Indians (as it is associated with Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose) is also easily accessible. From the hotel station Z-10, one need to go to Z-8 and from there cross over to M-18 and then travel to M-4.Inspite of its great value for excellent staff and great location, I must say that the hotel was overpriced. Few sofas at the hotel lobby needs replacement as I found them dirty and with damaged cover.A good place to recommend .........

I love to write great reviews when i find something special. Then if nothing special, I'd rather not bother because i have nothing to add to average. When more than 3 very frustrating customer service complaints go un responded/ignored then i want to provide information to the community that there is a problem at this hotel. 1)From check in the woman at front desk was determined to embarrass and insult me when i wanted to upgrade due to my iprefer membership2) i had not paid the very lowest rate but actually paid more for executive floor/club access special. A major rip off. Breakfast at club level is so poor and staff are fake polite and egg chef must hate Americans. Only when i complained was i told the nice full Japanese breakfast and western breakfast was downstairs and that for a special rate of only 15,000 yen i could upgrade my breakfast coupon 3)Housekeeping refused my request for 8 body lotion by occitane and wanted to negotiate on how many i could have. I said forget it and they gave me 8 tiny plastic bottles and shame. This is a truly outdated hotel. The rooms are very ugly and the bathroom is from the 1980's. The owners treat their staff poorly and then the staff treat the guests the same way. This hotel was very badly run and you should stay away. While sone hotels can be given credit for how they handle their mistakes, this hotel deserves Rotten Tomatoes for their arrogant insensitivity when attempts to comment/complain/provide constructive feedback are seen as hostile attacks by un welcomed paying guests.

Very nice hotel with good connectivity to both the airports since the Airport Bus Transit is next door. If you walk out there are many options to dine. Even found an Indian restaurant next door, about 5 mins walk. Did not get a chance to use the gym or pool. Did not get a chance to dine at the hotel.Staff is conversant in English, but please speak a bit slow.

Great location right next to the TCAT terminal so to and from airport is a breeze.So if you have many luggages, this is a good place to stay.Room I got was on the exec floor which has assess to the executive floor benefits like breakfast, tea and cocktail. Great view, clean room and great offering of buffet spread.Small affordable eateries nearby so you dont have to have your meals in hotel which can be expensive. There are 2 mini convenience stores just across the street.Service level is typically Japanese which goes beyond and has great focus on details. When I requested for a small room for conference call at the last minute, it was done effortlessly without any fuss.Would I stay here again... definitely.101%

Everything is great until you want to try their gym. They were charging me Y2000+ even for a 30 minute usage (as it covers daily rate). The roof deck restaurant also wanted to charge me for taking pictures even if I was a guest at the hotel. The things I enjoyed were the room view, pillows and bathroom as it has a shower and bathtub separately unlike in most Japanese hotels.

While this was my first trip to Tokyo, from what I am told, I got an AMAZING DEAL (via Tripadvisor) in finding this hotel as my first place to stay there. It was very reasonably priced (for Tokyo), was very nice, and even has a full sized, standard, 25-yard, indoor pool for lap swimming, with a full natural light ceiling above it! Best of all, the Executive Floors include (at no extra charge) an extensive, complementary, WARM, western breakfast with everything that you could want (eggs, bacon, fruit, cereals, juices, coffee, fresh made omelets, etc.), all served at the top of the hotel with huge windows and a great view of the city! What's not to LOVE? :-)

Though this is my return visit to this place, this time around, the stay was much better, as the rooms were looking brand new post renovation. Though still renovation work is on and one of the list has been blocked for the same, If your work place is near to this hotel, then this is a highly recommended place.Service wise, the place has been good always, quick response and they are english proficient. So communicating with the staff will not be a problem.Also, next to the hotel, there is temple, which has now been renovated, looks classy and expecting mothers do throng here with Kimono's on during April month.Overall a nice place to stay now, post renovation and comfortable as the hotel is well connected with metro trains and Airport bus to airports

I find the Royal Park to be one of the best hotels in Tokyo.The location is great and a 1 minute walk from T-CAT.The rooms are good and service very good and efficient.Plenty of restaurants including outside the hotel.

We were very pleased to arrive at a Western-style hotel for our first days in the country. The accommodations were comfortable and familiar. The service was outstanding; from the very first greetings to the sincere apologies for our four-second wait at check-in. I called room service for ice for my evening cocktail; on the second, third and fourth nights I simply said "hello" to room service and they immediately responded, "some ice for you, sir?" When we returned nine days later, they upgraded us to a spacious suite on the tenth floor (even though we had booked at a reduced rate through Expedia). We were very impressed.

Very nice hotel. Staff were very nice and helpful. Had questions on traveling on the Shinkansen and helped me navigate on the Tokyo subways. Had the daily breakfast included in my stay and glad that I did. Room was nice with the usual amenities. If a corner room is available get one. Much nicer and more room. Throughly enjoyed my two stays there.

I'm the type of business traveler that likes no frills and flexibility. If I need to change plans, I don't want to get hassled by the hotel staff about leaving a day early. I also like warm, friendly, and personal service. I also like a hotel where the facilities are well maintained and up-to-date.This is my company's "preferred" hotel, yet for the last two years I have been avoiding staying here due to my own personal preferences (and loyalty program). I had occasion to spend a night at this hotel--suffice it to say that I won't be changing my loyalty to the Royal Park for the following reasons:- The location is next to a major expressway intersection and close to Tokyo City Air Terminal (which used to be a useful place when you could actually check your bags and check in there). It isn't a pretty neighborhood and doesn't have much charm outside the entrance.- The lobby was probably state of the art when it was built--that time has long past--it is dated.- On the topic of warm, friendly, personal service--having spent a lot of time in Japan--it was very "Japanese" in its degree of feigned warm and very impersonal service. Typical of Japan's style retail and travel establishments, everything is formal and rigid--you won't get much in the way of casual pleasantries in the conversation (and yes I can do it in Japanese as well).- More than how I am treated, I have a hard time with the indignity of having the bellman wearing uniforms with a cap that reminds me of something you would see a monkey wearing with a organ grinder at an amusement park--sorry, not my thing.- One of the reasons I wanted to try out this hotel was I wanted to check out the pool as a way to exercise on my frequent visits to Tokyo. They wanted to charge an extra $20 for the pool, and add $10 to that if you also want to use the gym.- As I got out of one of the 3 out of the 4 elevators that was functioning, there was a very musty and stale smell in the long hallway as I walked to my room.- The hotel isn't allied with any of the other hotel chains where I have a loyalty program, so there won't be any points to be earned here.- I had a reservation for 2 nights and decided I didn't want to stay another night at this hotel. When I went to check out a day early, they told me that there would be an 80% fee to make this change--they wouldn't have said boo had I made a reservation that same day--I could have cancelled any time up until 6pm. To their credit, I refused to pay it and they capitulated. The excellence of Japanese customer service is limited to customers whose desires fit inside the established rules--go outside of those rules and you will pay (unless you make a stink).So I find zero charm or attraction to this hotel, there is nothing exceptional about the location, the facilities, the services, or the flexibility or friendliness of the staff--especially if you ask for an exception to their precious and all-important rules.

This is my third trip to Chuo/Japan in the past 12 months. The Royal Park Hotel is located just 5 minutes walk to the IBM offices. It is also right beside the Tokyo City Air Terminal - TCAT) which is one of many Bus routes from Narita. The hotel has a Subway station in the basement so you have easy access to the city and there are a lot of good local restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. I am in my room right now getting ready to head to Takamatsu this morning (Southern Japan) for a customer meeting. This hotel works well for my business needs

As well described on TA the location is perfect for airport connections with a lift that takes you straight down to the Tokyo metro station (Suitengamae) ticket office. The rooms are big by Tokyo standards, small by western, but spotlessly clean and well appointed. It was a little odd to find the safe just simply placed in the cupboard rather than fixed, anywhere else in the world I would have been concerned!The executive room benefits are superb as one gets free use of the excellent spa and pool, but most importantly a fantastic lounge on the 20th floor with a good view and 3 hours of free flow alcohol and savouries. The service, particularly the executive lounge, is outstanding. We will return.So why not 5 stars? Due to the timing of flights from UK you arrive in Japan early in the morning. With the efficient transfers from Haneda to the TCAT terminal we were at the hotel just after 9.00am. I fully understand the check in time is 14.00 and don't expect the room to be ready before this time. But as we often arrive in Asia at this time most hotels where we have booked an executive room, and in this case 6 nights, they will either offer the room for a sensible supplement if available or allow use of the executive lounge until the room becomes ready. We were charged the walk-in daily rate divided into 5 incremental hours which seemed excessive especially as we couldn't use the lounge either until 14.00. Given that the room was made up and empty and we had booked 6 nights surely the supplement charged should be the room rate we paid per night divided by the 5 additional hours or something sensible and notional. So that's why I can't give 5 stars - shame.

Ideal location next to TCAT. Well appointed hotel, with the excellent service you expect in Japan. The executive lounge is a real bonus for breakfast and afternoon drinks. The fitness level, the bars and restaurants are all well run and easy to use.

If you come in by bus from either airport, then they stop at the TCAT (Tokyo Central Air Terminal) and the hotel is next door, you can't miss it. You are also a 5-10 easy walk to two stations, which open up the Metro system to you. The staff are really friendly throughout and nothing is too much bother for them. I only ate breakfast here, and it was fine. The room was also very comfy and while the fittings are a little dated, I am knit picking a bit. Free Wifi, excellent as well and of course, spotlessly clean.

I stayed here for the Tokyo Coin Show ( I am a professional coin dealer) and enjoyed this stay overall, Every effort has been made by the staff to make it an enjoyable stay, definitively will come back, also for leisure.

Stayed at this hotel for business. Executive lounge has a great view and excellent breakfast buffet selection. Room is nice sized and I don' t know of any hotel that has all these bathroom amenities. I forgot my nail clipper and Lo and behold to my delight, they actually had one in their little kit with a nail file and sewing kit. The Hamonzon line of the Tokyo Metro has a station in the basement of the hotel and that is so convenient for business and for sightseeing.

I've stayed at the Royal Park a few times over the last several years. It's a reliable hotel with more pros than cons. It has 4 or 5 restaurants, including a nice rooftop that serves excellent Kobe beef. Rooms are good, nice amenities, a bit in need of some updating which the hotel seems to be working on. Staff is efficient, located a bit off of Tokyo's main attractions but within a couple of miles from Ginza and the Imperial Palace. The Tokyo air city terminal is adjacent with convenient bus transportation to Narita. Fitness club costs extra (a ridiculous 2000 yen), used to include breakfast but now extra $40 for the (nice) buffet.

Convenient location next to the airport bus station. Stayed two nights on business. Classic but well maintained room Quite spacious. Nice in room breakfast. Requested an iron, but the board was very small and the iron almost impossible to use (for a non japanese speaker) as the settings were only in japanese. Nice bar and good front desk service. Would come back.

Nice (4.5) hotel which is next door to the Tokyo City Air Terminal where buses depart for Narita International Airport.Do visit the 20th floor hospitality lounge both for breakfast and snacks/drinks. In the basement there is direct access to the Z10 subway station

Big hotel above six floors of shopping arcade and very popular conference and events center,Very good service,variety of six restaurants and big metro station in the first floorVery convenient with mean prices

Stayed at this hotel as I was in town for a meeting and had previously stayed in the sister hotel in Yokohama a month or so ago....This one is better in my opinion....breakfast is organised and not as chaotic as Yokohama.Staff here are all very friendly but language can sometimes be an issue...All in all a very good quality hotel.

I was staying with my son. The room was a spacious twin with a decent desk to work at. The swimming pool was very nice and the gym was never full. The breakfasts were good. There are lots of restaurants in an easy walk and the hotel has a map and list of those with menus in English. 10 minute cab ride to Tokyo station, directly over a subway station (an all day ticket is 800 yen from the hotel) and next door to the bus station with the bus to Narita. Convenient clean and courteous staff.

This stylish hotel is situation within a 2 minute walk from the bus station which is a fabulous plus after. Long flight and confusing bus transfer. The rooms are spacious and very well appointed. The staff incredibly helpful and courteous. We ate in the hotel's Japanese restaurant which was a little pricey but delicious and more importantly required not travel!

The sole purpose of my visit was to view the Cherry Blossoms in full bloom in Tokyo and I was not disappointed. Having started from Osaka-Nara-Kyoto-Mt Fuji etc, where only a few trees were flowering, our tour group finally arrived at Tokyo where tree-lined roads with Sakura in full bloom welcomed us! After 'roughing it up with one night stays at Ryokens (traditional hotels), we were all most pleasantly surprised by this grand hotel. We still had to lug our own luggage around though as this was peak season. Nonetheless, we were bowed all the way to the lift. The room was nice and spacious and towels, toiletries and beverages abundant. Bedding was most comfortable and I slept soundly. Interestingly the local pillows in all the hotels were smaller and there was always one filled with some kind of seeds. Nevertheless, these too were surprisingly promoting of sleep! Perhaps it was the walking everywhere on the tour. There were plenty of small cheerful restaurants serving a wide assortment of foods along the main road outside of the hotel and good meals did not cost a bomb. Except having to queue up, breakfast was otherwise a most civilized and pleasant 'fine-dining' experience with loads of goodies to choose from. Wish I could have stayed longer but I had to return home the following day and so put up at an airport hotel near Narita Airport the following night.

Strategically located nearby the main transportation services (subway stop Z10 is right below the main hall) Kind staff, comfortable and spacious room with all the required facilities you are expecting from this hotel category.Perfect choice for a breathtaking Tokyo visit.Arigatou!

I was put up in a twin-sharing room. Room was comfortable, but the placement of lighting controls and phone-charging outlet/point was extremely inconvenient. The room cleaning staff couldn't understand even basic English, which created a lot of communication issues. We requested for the next day's complimentary bottle of water, but instead we were told that complimentary water is only given on the first day and hence any additional bottle will be billed. But the next day, there was a complimentary bottle of water in the room, and we had to unnecessarily pay for the bottle of water we had asked for. Best aspect...very conveniently located for to-and-fro commute from both Haneda and Narita airport.

This hotel is next to T-CAT buss station, so very handy for arrivals from Narita airport. The bus is direct and good price. I arrived in the late morning and was informed rooms are only available from 2pm so it was a long wait for me as very jet-lagged. The lobby area has very few seating areas, even though there is plenty of room, which is annoying when you got time to kill or waiting for someone. The rooms are fine, noticed a renovation of the bathroom since last visit. Room service forgot to bring me an iron so had to call a second time for it.The best of all is however the top floor breakfast for the executive rooms. The omelettes are to die for and view is great. It is also a great meeting point during cocktail hours. Overall okay business hotel but could improve on some of the services.

I booked the Royal Park for a week or work and leisure. The hotel is near Tokyo station, a quick cab ride away. It is in a quiet neighborhood, however there are a few good restaurants a stone's throw away. It is serviced by the subway line and one of the stations can be accessed directly from the hotel.The Hotel has a glamorous feel about it, from days gone by. The decor is dated, but everything is immaculately kept. It feels from another era, clearly architecture that was in vogue a good few decades back, and i liked it! Not the usual glass and stell, all the same feel to it. The rooms are decent sized. make sure to get the non smoking room. In Japan you can't smoke on most street sections, but you can smoke in restaurants, bars, and in your hotel room as long as you book one that permits this.The staff at the hotel as exceptional, but then again it's Japan and the level of service is great no matter where you go. It's all smiles and extra helpful staff with any need you have. Please remember tips are offensive, so don't pull out a bill. Everyone takes pride in their work, if only Japan could export that to other places.Overall had a pleasant stay. Would i come back? Why not. Nothing glamorous, but a very dignified, clean, efficient hotel.Arigato!

First of all when I arrived, I let someone talk me into taking the train to Tokyo station and then a cab to the hotel. If you take TCAT you literally arrive next door to the hotel, it is a bit longer, but easier.This hotel is billed as a luxury hotel. It is really not, but it is a decent hotel with clean but outdated rooms. They fell apart for me with customer service. I requested a room near an elevator because I have problems walking and they literally refused me. They gave me a room at the end of the hall and they would not accommodate my requests to change it at check in. (After I complained loudly, they offered to change it the next day, which was inconvenient).Also, I waited for a friend in the lobby by leaning against a wall while waiting. A hotel employee came up to me and told me that I was not allowed to lean against the wall and if I wanted to wait for someone, I had to sit in chairs by the front desk. WHAT???I just did not like this hotel, from check in to my general experience. They do not know how to accommodate a customer, and a lot is lost due to the language barrier.One more tip, leave the front door of the hotel and turn right, the first restaurant that you encounter is a small Japanese restaurant, the food is great and they speak english.

I'm a regular (4x a year, long stays) and they usually don't know that HOWEVER, on this trip they saved the day when I arrived unexpectedly and needed a place to stay. They were especially accommodating and made up for the usual annoyances associated with the property. Hotel is very good. And with minor tweaks it could be excellent.

very nice hotel, check in and check out process was fast, the room quite big considering usual size of the hotel in tokyo quite small. this hotel connected with subway, very convenient after a long walk around tokyo. a bit old, but still clean and tidy. they should have renovation for the room. near with convenient store and also a lots of food nearby, so no need to worries of sturfing. the price of this hotel also reasonable.

Great location for business travel. decent size room for Japanese hotel. excellent service and most staff speaks English. breakfast selection has a wide variety of both Asian and Western style. easily accessible from Narita and Haneda airport.

Actually for the price I paid, this hotel can be better. The room is outdated and have kind of unpleasant odor. But the lounge is excellent. I enjoyed it very much. The location is superb, right by the TCAT city terminal. Awesome.

Centrally located, close to the Bus Air terminal for a quick recover from jet leg. With a convenient metro stop inside the building. You can book without worry.Just outside many small restaurant and inside and excellent teppanyaki with good view.The only weak point is the cost that make it not convenient for families but suitable for business.

Old hotel, very nice building, pretty lobby. Old fashion key (not plastic card). No food allowed in the lobby area. I was approached by a security guard while snacking in the lobby area.Great location, connected to the subway and TCAT, short walk to ningyocho station. A lot of good restaurants around.

located strategically near the terminal that you can take direct bus to Haneda and Narota Airport. Selling 2-day metro pass for room guest at discounted rate that can help to save cost for travelling around Tokyo

I often stay this hotel.There are many restaurants od Japanese traditional foods.Sukiyaki, Chicken Hotpot and sukiyaki, Teppanyaki, Udon etc and of coursr Sushi.Many good restuarants if you want to enjoytraditional Japanese foods.Gym of this hotel is one of my most favorate gym in Japan.Good facilities.

I have stayed at this hotel twice in December with my visits two weeks apart, traveling with my parents and my niece for a short vacation both times. The service is professional and friendly and the staff do speak English, no worries and they are happy to help you, with anything you can think of. The Royal Park Hotel is a domestic chain with locations in all the big cities. The RPH at Chuo is very conveniently located to TCAT and the subway so the Airport Limosine drops you at TCAT and you can go to level 2 by elevator to go on the covered overpass directly leading into the hotel. The rooms are comfortable and lay out well, for 3 in the room the sofa pulls out to the third bed, a bit tight up against the corner of the big desk but manageable. Some of the rooms have been updated which are even nicer. The beds are comfy and I had no problems sleeping. Beware some of the rooms will have some street noises so if you are a light sleeper request a quiet room. The hotel has free wifi. Don't know if they have a gym or not, you'd better check. We love the breakfast (Viking) buffet and enjoy the service of the serving staffs as well. We will definitely come back and stay again. It's definitely a solid 4 star in my book.

Good size rooms with free Wi-Fi and very good breakfast at the executive lounge. The lobby was beautiful and the hotel was very conveniently located with easy access to TCAT and the subway. Even though it was my first time in Tokyo and I don't speak Japanese it was extremely easy to get around on the subway from this hotel. The best thing about the hotel was the people that works there. Everyone was very polite and happy to help with any requests, questions, etc. I stayed a week and will definitely go back if I'm ever in Tokyo again. Excellent service

Great rooms with free wifi and a good breakfast. The hotel is very well situated just next to Tokyo Central Air Terminal with limousine buses to and from both international airports. There is also a metro station just below the hotel making access very convenient.For relaxing after a long day there is a very good whisky bar downstairs in the hotel.

The rooms are not large for American standards but the hotel and the restaurants in this hotel are very good. If you are staying on one of the executive floors you have free access to pool, gym, jacuzzi, sauna and the executive lounge on the 20th floor with complimentary full bar!

Tokyo is a fair distance from the airport and a cab can cost $800-$900 one way. Alternatively, there is the TKAT, a bus service right outside the airport that you buy the ticket for inside the airport at a very reasonable rate. The first stop on the bus is the Air terminal, which is directly across the street from the Royal Park Hotel. That alone makes this an ideal location for travelers. Add in the very friendly & accomodating staff, breakfast buffet and evening snacks and drinks with beautiful skyline views and you have a very pleasurable stay. Oh, there is also a subway entrance downstairs in the hotel making it very easy to get around the city.

The hotel is relatively old but they charge a premium for its strategic proximity to Tokyo City Air Terminal. The room is spacious and with plentiful amenities. Breakfast menu can be improved to accommodate foreign visitors.

This hotel has a refreshingly unique charm, very different from the usual chain hotel. Clean rooms, great staff, quality food - I enjoyed the top floor view for breakfast each morning. This location is connected to the subways and makes for an easy starting point to travel anywhere in Tokyo.

The rooms were small and the breakfast quality was poor. There was only pork meat so not good for Muslims or Hindus. The location was really good but everything else was not convenient at all. It also has a subway station under it so it was actually good if you want to discover the city like me.

I last stayed at Royal Park Hotel's Deluxe Twin Room in April 2015 during the Sakura Hanami and was impressed by the excellent experience then.
