In November 2015, I decided to visit Tokyo again for a short getaway and stayed at its Executive Standard Double Room - it's a smaller room (26 square meters) than the hotels Deluxe offering (42 square meters), but was more expensive as it comes with full club benefits - buffet breakfast, coffee, tea & snack service and evening cocktail with free flow of alcohol.The service at the Executive Lounge were great and while the quality of food was reasonable, it was not outstanding and the range was rather repetitive - I was bored by day 3 and I was staying by 5 nights. I was also probably not making full use of the club benefits since I do not take alcohol.But back to the room, not sure if it's because it's on the executive level, the amount of complimentary amenities was mindblowing (see my attached photo). Besides the usual toiletries, there's even mouse rinse, hair brush, hair gel, hair tonic and even fabric freshener among the many other stuff!Wifi was very fast at something like at least 10Mbps upstream and down. And it's location beside the Tokyo City Air Terminal (T-CAT) and on top of Suitengumae Metro Station makes it a joy to get around.If I am visiting Tokyo again, it's highly likely that I will be staying here again.

This is my second stay at Royal Park Hotel, Chuo-ku, Tokyo.I stayed for 5 nights from Dec 6-11, 2015.I arrived at about 10 am for check in but had to wait 4 hours till 2 pm for my room. During room reservation, I had indicated early morning check in; but was denied a room. At Ritz Carlton Seoul, I was given a room upon check in at 9.00 am. That made a difference to this hotel. Having travelled long haul flight overnight, most guests were tired and needed a good rest to recuperate. But Royal Park was indifferent towards guest's needs at check in.This was the downside for those arriving Narita in early morning for check in at this hotel.The hotel is located only 2-3 minutes away from the TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) for limousine bus to and from Narita. This made it very convenient to arrive and depart from airport-hotel-airport.The hotel is about 10 minutes taxi ride (JPY 1,000) from Tokyo Station for the Sinkansen or Metro.The room was clean. The bedroom was comfortable and quiet. I had quality sleep every night. I woke up fresh each morning for customer meetings.I enjoyed evening drinks with finger food (5-8 pm) and breakfast at the executive Lounge on the 20th floor.The view from the lounge offered a spectacular view of the city and its skyscrapers.The concierge staff were very friendly and polite when approached for assistance.I wish to put on record the excellent service level extended to me by Pagnozzi Paolo. I have asked for direction to TCAT the night before I checked out.He went above and beyond his duty to walk me personally to the TCAT and back. He even warned me that there would be heavy shower forecast the next morning during my check out. He advised me to take the covered walkway on 2nd Floor to the TCAT to avoid getting wet. Again, he went out of his way to escort and show me the way to TCAT.What Paolo did was an exemplary customer care. He is a true model for front line customer service. He is certainly a great asset to the service industry.Should there be a reward or recognition for staff high performance, Paolo Pagnozzi should be the prime candidate.Despite the downside at check in, Paolo has redeemed my faith in Royal Park Hotel.I shall certainly return as a guest again in my next visit to Tokyo.I recommend this hotel for business trips.

The best thing about this hotel is the convenience to TCAT which is the bus terminal for the airports. Other than that, there is really nothing special about the hotel. The hotel is connected to only one subway line, Hanzomon Line. Not one of the more convenient lines within Tokyo. However, if you want to go to Skytree, this line will take you there in less than ten minutes. Yet, still have to make one transfer. We had the breakfast buffet in the lobby restaurant. It was not bad, but the food is so-so. Of course, the hotel service is good like most hospitality in Japan. The big hotel lobby. The room was decent; nothing really impressive to write home about. We had one facing the highway, but you wouldn't know it unless you look out the window. That was good. The hotel is within walking distance to Ningyocho, an older area of Tokyo but very interesting to walk about. There is a shrine nearby that is undergoing renovation. There is a small grocery store about two blocks away. Of course convenience stores abound. Overall, an average place to stay.

very clean and spacious room come with good services. the hotel is just above the Tokyo metro and very near to Tokyo city air terminal which you can take your bus limousine to haneda airport and narita airport. Besides that, the staff was very helpful by helping us to bring the luggages to Tokyo city air terminal since we travel with the baby and toddler. Just make sure you check out on time because they will charges you for late check out.

Very good hotel, comfortable quiet room, excellent welcome on reception, the young lady who showed me to my room was extremely polite and helpful. Food in the restaurant was excellent. The only complaint is the charge to use the swimming pool was excessive. Plus I was made to remove my watch, wear a swimming cap, you have to stay in the lanes which didn't make for a relaxing swim.

Safe and good hotel to stay , less crowded than central Tokyo , staff can speak good English and going back even late at night is safe and fast due to metro station nearby . Only gripe is there is a lack of convenience stores nearby only 1 7 eleven a wal away but they were constructing another convenience store opposite the hotel when I was there.

We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights and the experience was great! room was very large (Executive Deluxe), actually more of a mini-suite than room. The bed was simply huge and one of the most comfortable I ever had on any hotel. Everything was super clean, and I really mean SUPER CLEAN. Location is top notch and the best part is that the hotel is maybe 50 meters from the T-CAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) which is where our "Limousine" bus headed from Narita (less than 1 hour and only Yen 1,900). Same thing when we went from the hotel back to Narita.Breakfast on the 20th floor lounge was really nice, and the 17h-20h light meal was also a nice touch - almost too nice, as you can replace a dinner with this, but not going out to have a dinner in Tokyo is not fun... The view outside from the lounge is a bonus.Staff, at all levels & functions were helpful and we encountered zero problems during the entire stay. Very recommended hotel if you are looking for something in Tokyo around this price range.

This hotel is a reference in terms of kindness and professionalism of the staff, beauty of the hall and lounge, guest rooms comfort, quality and variety of the offered services. It is also directly connected with both Narita and Haneda airports through the Tokyo City Air Terminal at which is directly linked. Probably you can't have a better combination in Tokyo. I suggest this Hotel to all foreigners, especially to the ones at the first introduction in Japan.

Muzak and scant seating in the lobby mean it is not ideally suited for a business venue. Check in efficient and wifi excellent. Room comfortable and good views. Tiny pillows, slightly impair sleep quality. Breakfasts a little limited - no local options.

Amazed how much of neighborhood Ningyo-cho restaurants have English menus - very helpful. And, a quaint old-town feel to it. So convenient to Tokyo City Air Terminal across the street, to and from Narita airport.

Fantastic location of the hotel gives you easy access (just a few meters) to the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) from where the Airport Limousine busses are available to both Narita and Haneda airports.The hotel is situated in the heart of the business district with easy access to train/ taxi and is truly one of the better business hotels in Tokyo.

I stayed at this hotel a couple of weeks ago while visiting Tokyo. It is located in the Nihonbashi district which is pretty quiet at night and on the opposite side of Shinjuku and Shibuya. The hotel is classy but dated, immediately known the moment you step inside. Despite that, it is very warm and welcoming, and the staff are very helpful and courteous. Unfortunately, the room key is an actual metal key, and there is only one key per room so you have to coordinate with whoever you're sharing the room with where you are going unless you want to be locked out. The room itself is a good size and the beds are comfortable. The air in the hotel room is very dry, but fortunately each room has a humidifier. The bathroom is dated, but very clean! The best part about staying here is definitely the extra amenities. When I booked my stay, I got the executive package which included breakfast, coffee, and cocktails. I also had a spa and gym package, but I didn't use those ... In terms of location, it is convenient from the airport provided you take the limousine bus. The hotel is across the street from the City Air Terminal where all the limousine buses stop at. It is also on top of the Suitegumae station so you can take the metro to any part of Tokyo! Also, the hotel offers day passes for the Metro. One downside though is since the station is pretty small, you have to make a few transfers and it is not connected to the JR lines. Also, since the Tokyo Metro closes before 1 am, you have to either go back to the hotel early or prepare to empty your pockets for a taxi.

I have stayed at this hotel for almost every month as the location is closed to my office.Normally, I would go to breakfast on the exec floor. However, today I must leave at 7am, therefore, I went to breakfast on 1F. THe hotel denies my entrance to the breakfast because I wear a beach sandal. I talked with manager, they did not even apology and said that this is their policy. They also dont care that I stayed here everymonth. I will never ever set foot on this hotel ever again. THe hotel is not even on Marriot standard. Room is small and old. The only one reason is it is walking distance to work but now they lost all my interest to stay. We paid more than 300$/night but got this ridiculous treatment.

An "ok" hotel close to the financial district of Tokyo. Most of the staff is very friendly, rooms are clean. WiFi is free in rooms and public areas. Despite multiple sources (incl Internet), there is no foreign TV station offered. Compared to previous stays (2013 and 2014) the breakfast buffet offered has lost considerable variety. Given that the price went the other way it is probably not worth it.

Enjoyed our stay there and were impressed with the excellent service provided by all of the staff. They did whatever they could to meet your needs and were always friendly and welcoming. Good location with the TCAT centre next door to get to and from the airport. This was our first visit to Tokyo but found it easy to get around the city on the subway from this hotel. Room was comfortable and quiet. Executive lounge amenities were very good. Only minor complaint was that the lounge closed at 9 pm - would have been nice to have it open a bit later in the evening to have a quiet place to relax.

Good hotel in great location. Very convenient for airport shuttle to Haneda and Narita. Executive rooms give access to lounge and evening bar area, as well as free breakfast. Rooms are relatively large and well proportioned. Only down side is the lack of English channels on the TV, which wasn't a major problem as this was a business trip.

It was my second stay at the Royal Park and nothing less than perfection just as I expected! Beautiful spacious room, the biggest I've seen in Japan, great shops and restaurants within the building. Stunning decor. Friendly and helpful staff. Perfect location for amenities nearby and easy to travel to other parts of the city from local underground stations. I will definitely stay here again next time I'm in Tokyo!

The location is ok because the transit line is basically at the hotel and it's easy to get around on it, but the neighbourhood itself doesn't have much going on. The bus from the airport is about an hour and goes to the station right beside the hotel, so that was a bonus. Busy place as its more of a business hotel, and they have weddings going on during the weekend. The rooms are dated, but the staff are all super nice and want to help with anything they can. A bit pricy for what you get for a room, but I think Tokyo is expensive in most places. Overall we would have wanted something closer to the action, but getting around on the train was pretty easy.

I stay there few days to work in Tokyo. The location of the hotel is very convenient to discover the city, with the tube underground the hotel. The rooms are wide enough but not crazy and the Japanese restaurant offer a kind of discover menu that was really great. Will definitely come back there next time.

This is my second time staying here for business and have gotten used to the fact that the hotel looks a little trapped in time from the 1990/s. That said, it is right next to the T-Cat bus terminus which means an easy 30 min ride from Haneda airport and also right above the Suitenguemae subway station (Z10) along the Hanzomon line. There are also plenty of restaurants right along the street though it can do with a decent cafe. All considered as a creature of habit, I probably will come back here.

I stay here whenever I have business with a certain company in Tokyo. The place exudes old world luxury. It provides 5 star service at 4 star prices. There are numerous restaurants of all ethnic varieties. Several nice shops as well. The spa and gym are well equipped, if sometimes over crowded. Rooms are comfortable if a bit small. Book with the executive club floor package and a very nice breakfast is served on the top floor with a great view of the city.

Nice but a bit too expensive hotel for Europeans. Old style luxury with very professional staff. Clean and huge rooms. Especially good organized and equipped for people on age. Don't forget to take a swim and sauna (pay extra). Excellent breakfast. Haven't seen much bars around the hotel.

This hotel is fabulous, they think of absolutely everything! The amenities are amazing, and the gym is the best I have ever seen (especially the locker rooms). The location right next to the TCAT makes it so convenient to get to from the airport and then to get to subway, buses, etc.

I has there for three nights and stayed in a club suite. The club floor is nice, also the spa is good. The room was a bit small, but good. Most taxi drivers dont know where the hotel is, so if you dont know Japanese, take a map

I stayed in this hotel in October 2015 and it was a really solid choice and offered good value for money. The staff are all very helpful and most are able to speak English well. Generally, the hotel is well-located and is very close to metro stops to travel around Tokyo. The hotel is in the Nihonbashi district, which has loads of restaurants and sushi bars to visit in the evening. The hotel is extremely convenient for getting to and from the airport via the shuttle bus (the hotel is situated adjacent to the Tokyo City Air Terminal) and buses leave to and from each airport around every half an hour. The hotel rooms and the hotel itself are dated and in need of some updating (especially the bathrooms), but it is clean and comfortable enough. I would definitely recommend upgrading to the executive rooms to take advantage of the executive lounge, which offers free breakfast in the morning and cocktail service in the evening. The views from the lounge are superb and the service is impeccable.

The good: Well located for the TCAT & Narita bus connections, directly linked to the Tokyo Metro, free wi-fi, and friendly, English-speaking staff.The bad: Non-smoking rooms were not available when I checked in, until I told the front desk staff I would cancel my reservation & stay elsewhere and one became available. The rooms are old & tired. You get a huge key to carry around! The Executive Upgrade (Y8000) gets access to a nice view from the 20th floor, but a mediocre breakfast.There are far better hotels in the Tokyo area in this price range.

If you wondered where the 80's went, you'll find them here! Overall, the hotel is very nice, with a friendly, helpful staff, and moderately convenient location with direct subway access from the basement, but the rooms could definitely use an update. The tile, fixtures, furniture, etc. just seem old. However, free wifi, a great club level lounge with American style breakfast, and afternoon cocktails daily are great. It is definitely worth the extra cost of the club level.

Loved this hotel. The staff were really friendly and helpful. The hotel is well positioned with easy access to the subway and airports! As stated on other reviews the rooms are a little dated but they are clean and well maintained. If you are looking for a hotel that is well connected but not right in the centre of Tokyo this is ideal. there are loads of bars and restaurants within easy walking distance which are a lot cheaper than shibuya etc.

Having read other reviews; outdated rooms, having a big key instead of a key card, the staff not very nice??? my expectations where a little tuned downwards. But arriving at the hotel my expectation where met, to say the least. Friendly staff really trying to make you feel like a valued guest. Sure they key is on the heavy side, but how cool is it to get a key nowadays :), the room could be seen as old fashioned, but is the right size, the bed is great. The breakfast on the 20th floor has a really nice view.The bus terminal and metro station is next door and other metro stations near. Also a lot of nice restaurants in the vicinity.Typing this on my second day in, looking forward to the other 10 days.

Very good hotel, well located. Close to many restaurants and nightlife. Maybe a little too big which makes it a little impersonal. Continental breakfast could be improved. But over all, it was a good stay.

Good hotel in Tokyo. Well located and easy to reach. The airport shuttle arrives 59 m from the hotel and the metro station is basically in the hotel. The hotel has a nice gym and swimming pool and the executive lounge has a great view. Staff is always friendly. I go back year in year out

I got a good deal on a website and I stayed in this hotel for 2 nights. Location is super conveniet, the hotel has both subway station (direct access in the basement of the hotel) and direct access to the bus station to Narita and Haneda airport (I took the bus to Narita, 50min and 1800 yen, departs every 10min).Rooms are nice and quite big for Tokyo, with very nice views of Tokyo financial district. The gym is correct, and there is a 20 meter swimming pool, good for swimming. In the deal I got, breakfast and gym/swimming pool was included, but I think you usually need to pay for these, ask beforehand !The hotel is near an elevated road, ask for high floor if possible.

I like to stay at this hotel because it is next to TCAT. Staff always helpful and very pleasant to deal with. Clearly a well run hotel. Rooms very nice and I like their executive floor rooms and service. I gave the hotel 5 stars but I have one complaint. Each time I have visited I stayed on the executive floor which gives you a no charge breakfast. I have always enjoyed their croissants which in my opinion made you think you were in France. On this occasion the croissants were soggy and tasteless. A big disappointment. Nevertheless I highly recommend this hotel

We stayed in the executive room for 2 nights and the room is very spacious and new. We did have very high expectation about the room as we read some reviews which mention the hotel and rooms are old. It was indeed a very pleasant surprise to us that the rooms are so well renovated, clean and nice. The executive lounge is excellent too as it serves lots of snacks and food throughout the day. especially during the evening cocktail time. The alcohol selection is also very good.The hotel is connected to the metro station and is located very near to nihonbashi, which made it very convenient to travel to places like Ginza. Shibuya is also 20 mins by metro away. All staff we met are extremely friendly and helpful. The staff who cleaned our room even left a nice japanese fan as a gift to us and also provided us with weather information. We were really surprised to find out those little gifts when we returned to the room that day. Will definitely stay again when in Tokyo

We regularly stay at the Royal Park Hotel for business for a few days at a time. Located next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal makes it extremely convenient to travel to and from the airport. Their Executive Floor is the highlight with a superb views of the city all the way to Tokyo Tower and is open all day to members for breakfast, afternoon tea and evening drinks and canapés. The recently renovated rooms on the Executive Level are extremely well presented with a combined bath and shower room and they provide every bathroom amenity you could possibly need during your stay. This hotel combines Japanese traditional character and service whilst providing all the modern comforts one would expect from a hotel of this calibre. It's actually hard to leave!

This hotel isn't my first choice in Japan but for an approved business hotel near the office, it was fine. It is right across the street from the City Air Terminal building which is where the Limo Buses from Narita come which was super convenient. The hotel is a semi-traditional Japanese hotel, moderate in price and amenities. A bit old school in some regards including the physical skeleton keys they give you for the doors. The facilities are nice overall. They only had a twin room available for my reservation and I was a little grumpy about that. Breakfast was not included. My room looked out over the on ramp to the freeway so you couldn't really sit with the drapes open but nonetheless it was quiet. The beds were fine. I went to the Sushi restaurant the first night and it was great. It has a long standing place in the hotel and is as authentic as it gets. The first taste reminded me of how much better sushi is in Japan than the U.S.There isn't a good coffee shop in the place and I paid 850 yen in the breakfast restaurant for one small cappuccino which was annoying. The hotel connects directly to the subway from the lower level and that was super convenient. One stop down is mitsukoshimae which is an upscale area with the grand department store of the same name and many other nice shops and retail. Overall the hotel was fine and I had no complaints.

I recently stayed here for 4 nights on business. The location is very convenient, especially to and from the airport. It is locate across the street for the TCAT and getting back to the airport was very easy. The lung at the top floor is very nice. It's a great place to replace with a drink and snacks in the evening, the view is very nice and they had a good selection of snacks. The same lounge has breakfast in the morning. It had a very good variety of food included and omelette station. The only complaint was that the omelette tended to be quite runny.Dinner at the Symphony restaurant was very goodAs always, service is impeccable. The staff was very friendly and helpful.

We visited in a small group of 3 very late in the night. My office colleagues ordered spirits while I ordered coffee as I am a teetotaler. The cigar humidor was requested and was brought over with a flourish. Nice collection of quality cigars. (In Japan cigar prices are the same wherever you may be). The waiter snipped of the ends to our satisfaction and left us with a table lighter and an over sized ashtray.What a wonderful experience. We left around 1.30AM all agreeing that it was time and money well spent.

Hotel is located directly by underground a and Tokyo city air terminal with direct access to both of them. This offer very easy commute option either from the airport (s) or city.Hotel is good and offer anything that business or family will need.My room was located on the 12th floor. It was quite small compared to some others business hotels I stayed in the past. It was big enough though to sleep and work behind the computer.I'm guessing due to the hotel age AC didn't work properly, it felt like it that there was more humidity in the room that should be because my towels didn't dry properly but it was nothing like outside :)Would I stay here again? Yes I would.

Stayed for business, very efficient and polite staff. Good facilities and business center.Conveniently located next to airport bus station and directly above subway.Good food and bars all within walking distance.

Stayed here again and it was consistently good. Staff are friendly and will do their best to help you.Bathrooms are a little outdated but functional and a great range of toiletries etc are left for you to use.I had 2 Chinese meals from the room service menu which were delicious and very reasonably priced.Location is excellent for subway and TCAT.Wifi is also excellent, although you need to log in every day, the speed is very good. Managed to use FaceTime with no problems at all.

This hotel is fabulous. It is in a very nice, quiet location, right next to a subway/bus station. There are many wonderful restaurants around the hotel, but the food in the hotel is also delicious. There is a buffet breakfast that included all kinds of delicious food (Japanese and Western) which will definitely get you going right on your visit. The rooms are comfortable, large, and very beautiful. The staff is very helpful. Overall, it's a wonderful hotel to stay in and comes highly recommended for its convenience and comfort.
user_name:
TiffanyT1103
New York City, New York

review_body: Because the MRT station is directly below it made for an easy hotel to stay at. There was a good selection at the buffet breakfast. The bathroom has lots of amenities - hair gel, hair tonic, shower cap, disposable razor, toothbrushes and paste, body lotion, facial wash, hair dryer, sewing kit, cotton buds and wipes, comb, emery board, nail clippers, hair brush, shaving gel, air and fabric freshener, tissues and breath freshener liquid. The shower is over the bath and the toilet is heated with fan and bidet built in.

I stayed in Royal Park for several weeks on business. It is right on subway line so extremely convenient to get about. Rooms and Executive Club were excellent. Hotel and local restaurants where great. Would definitely use Royal Park again.

I stayed in this hotel for 8 nights for business trip. Top 3 good points about this hotel are:1. Comparable 5-star hotel and room amenities 2. Convenient. Next to Tokyo City Air Terminal - good to travel to/from Haneda and Narita airport via limousine bus. Hotel is also connected to Suitengumae station (Hazonmon line)3. Variety of food, both in hotel and outside hotelHave one thing I hope the management can take note. My flight was 930am so I had to leave hotel before 7am. But the hotel breakfast lounge opens from 7am. I made a request for breakfast room service but it is chargeable. IMHO, hotel should provide in-room breakfast service if the guests have morning flight to catch.

I recently stayed at the Royal Park for business. The location is ideal, located close to 2 subway lines and directly across the street from T-CAT -- the express airport bus line. It is the first stop from Narita in Tokyo. Much more cost effective and comfortable than a taxi. The hotel has several excellent restaurants, and the rooms, though not as nice as the rest of the hotel might suggest, were comfortable and clean.

Royal Park is situated on top of the Hanzomon Line (purple Z metro) which makes it extremely convenient as a base for your stay in Tokyo. I recommend asking for a room in the newly renovated section of the hotel, which features a soaking tub and the newest Toto toilet. The older section has bigger rooms, but I preferred the smaller space with better amenities. With stay in the "Executive Rooms" you get free western breakfast buffet (delicious) and happy hour on the top floor of the hotel which has phenomenal views.

Excellent service by the Executive Manager. Standard room size was quite small if you are travelling with a family but more than comfortable for business travellers. The location is very convenient by train, however, there isn't much entertainment or shopping around the area unless you travel out. If you are looking for a quiet environment, it will suit your needs though.

I can not say enough about how great this hotel was. After a very bad experience in Beijing and with our travel company Friendly Planet not responding to our calls for help, this hotel was a welcomed oasis. Right next door to a major subway line and shuttle service from the airport, you can't beat that. The breakfast buffet was wonderful with American, British and Japanese items. I wanted to take the cute omelet guy home....I wanted to try the hotel spa but couldn't make time to have someone come to my room to do a massage, 30 dollars 30 minutes, 60 dollars 60 minutes, 90 dollars 90 minute....darn...next time....The hotel was very clean, staff very polite and helpful and it is located in a great spot for day or night exploration of Tokyo.

Overall, a good experience. Rooms were clean and bed was comfortable. Service was excellent. I had access to the executive lounge which had good breakfast options (the cook made a great omelette). There was a nice, quiet bar downstairs where I enjoyed some excellent local Japanese whiskey. I would stay there if I returned to Tokyo for business.

The Royal Park Hotel is a good base in Tokyo with a feel of luxury and good links to transport.Rooms are comfortable, spacious and well equipped, with possibly the best range of bathroom amenities anywhere!Japan is full of surprises and while this mammoth hotel sits beside a busy flyover there it still feels tranquil. To my amazement there is a tranquil traditional Japanese water garden on the 5th floor, complete with coy carp.One of the many bonuses of the hotel is that you can access the Suitengumae subway station directly from the basement.It is certainly somewhere I would stay again when I return to Tokyo in the future.

First let me get this out of the way - the hotel was old. But it was old in an old world charm kind of way where one can see that based on the decor and layout, the hotel had been around for quite a while, but everything was extremely well-maintained and still in tip-top condition.Second, I need to mention the location of the hotel - it's just perfect! I was a little apprehensive that the what looked like a non-central location, but everything worked out great. I was especially impressed with the hotel's direct connection to Suitengumae Station - basically, the moment you exit the fare gates and turn left, you are are the second level basement of the hotel. And not only that, the hotel's also directly connected to Tokyo City Air Terminal (T-CAT) on level 2, making getting to and from Narita Airport (55 minutes away) or Haneda Airport (25 minutes away) by the Airport Limousine Bus extremely convenient. The hotel had also thoughtfully arranged for special rates for international guests using the Airport Limousine Bus. Besides Suitengumae, the hotel was also within reasonable walking distance to Ningyocho and Hamacho Stations. Note that all these metro and subway stations were all non-JR for those relying on JR pass.The hotel's location was also pretty quiet despite it being near the hustle and bustle of Chuo City - good food was always nearby. It's also directly opposite 2 convenient stores, 7-Eleven and FamilyMart, which made grabbing that midnight bite all the more convenient. In all and all, I was honestly quite surprised that I liked this hotel's location far better than messy and noisy Shinjuku, where I stayed a week before my stay here.I stayed at the Deluxe Room which was very roomy by Japanese standards at about 42sqm. Wifi was fast, although it adopts one of the daily login kind of system that resets at midnight and so if you are doing any electronic transactional stuff over that period, do be aware of that.I booked the room without breakfast (I am late starter kinda of person and so find it a bother to wake up early for breakfast) and so is unable to comment on that, but the housekeeping quality was top-notch. The hotel's front desk also spoke excellent English which made communications a breeze.

The hotel is five star. But it doesnt mean the rooms are any larger. They are not. Its a nice hotel but could improve. Its removed the spa area for men which is disappointing. However any issues were wonderfully dealt with by the staff all of whom simply wanted to help. Sooo good.

Not the first time staying in this hotel, each time at least 5 days. This hotel is conveniently located next to bus station. Only required me to cross a small road and will reach the hotel.Check in at the Executive lounge, which was fast. However, the breakfast spread at the Executive lounge was limited. For guest who is entitled to Executive lounge breakfast, was not allowed to have breakfast at the 1st floor café. Unless you pay. If I remembered, during my last year stay, I was allowed to choose between these 2 options. The breakfast spread at the cafe was so much better than the Executive lounge. Ordered room service, the service was prompt but the food was average. Outside the hotel, there are many small nice shops along the road.

Grand lobby with nice lighting decorated. Spacious room with Comfortable bed that make you sleep all night long. Full set of amenities provided and you can even ask for a basic face wash in case you forgot to bring yours! Staffs carry their smile always and make my day! Metro line just beside the hotel and make you easily reach anywhere you like. Tokyo City Air Terminal also just right beside the hotel and its very convenience for you to reach the hotel from Narita airport or to Narita airport.Very nice and antique room key they have but it is a bit heavy. Just to make sure you don't leave it anywhere but can always drop it at the front desk when out from to hotel. Thank you so much to the bell man who help us carry our big luggage from the hotel to TCAT! Love the hotel!

Our first family trip to JapanThis is an excellent HotelSome comments where made about the Hotel being dated , but it is in perfect condition none the less.The subway below is an absolute bonus ,15 minutes and you are at Tokyo Station.The area where the Hotel is fantastic , after a busy day and the hustle and bustle of Tokyo you go back to the hotel and walk the pleasant streets with resturant options galore.The Hotel has fantastic sauna spa & pool facilities. The employees at the Hotel where just so great and helpful.Being next to TCAT its a bonus to simply get off an international flight onto a limo bus that brings to the Hotel.Rooms are spacious and clean , showers are awesome. I cant recommend this hotel enough and for Tokyo was good value for money.We went with the executive floor package.Well worth it ,great breakfast , evening cocktails etc from the top floor viewsLooking forward to our next trip back to Japan where we will stay at this hotel

Great location and central to the region. - One block from train station that easily takes you to airport. Good business hotel for the weary traveler w excellent restaurants within a 5 min walk from nice sit down shabu shabu dining to quick and crowded ramen shops.

The hotel is well located close to airport transport services and directly above a subway station easily accessed via escalators. Room size is big for a Tokyo hotel and also very competitively priced. On the down side probably a little dated décor with very dark wood panelling which make the corridors very dark made up for some extent by the very bright Executive Floor. Staff were very friendly and helpful.

The hotel overall is a bit outdated. Rooms are very european,, small with very little space and older style including carpets, wall paper paint etc... however... if you are not looking for newer style and furtiture this hotel's service is amazing and is fairly well located. near a service to the airport and subways and the area is quite nice with a lot of great restaurants including a great restaurant at the top of the building

I have stayed here 4 times in the last year, the politeness of everyone is noticeable for a Westerner. Very convenient location, a short walk across the road is a regular and reliable limousine bus service to the main airport. The metro station is just down the escalator from the hotel lobby. Small shops and a wide range of many small restaurants are within a few minutes walk, which suits me well. With an 'executive' booking, the room is a bit better and the breakfast on floor 20 is very good (especially at the weekend when there is Japanese traditional breakfast available). For the location and hotel quality, the price is reasonable.

I found this hotel to be a good value. The room was comfortably-sized and clean. The view on the side where I stayed, looking toward Shiodome, was ok but not special. The transportation access was better than I expected. In addition to the Hanzomon line stop at the underground level, the Hibiya and Asakusa lines are only a few minutes walk away, and JR Tokyo is only a few minutes from the Hanzomon Mitsukoshimae station if you find the right exit. I also enjoyed walking around the Ningyocho area and across the Sumida to the Kiyosumi area. I expect that I will stay here again. I had some minor problems getting my boarding pass printed, but the hotel staff was helpful in resolving that.

The Royal Park Hotel Lifestyle in Chuo prefecture advertises itself as a five-star property. At 22,000 yen per night, the price is quite good for the location. The location next to the TCAT terminal makes it an easy destination to reach from Narita Airport by comfortable limousine bus. Also well situated in the financial district. The rooms are rather cramped, but the beds are comfortable. I find it annoying that there is an additional 2000 yen charge just to use a treadmill in the gym. This is an anachronism. Staff are friendly and accommodating.

I have stayed here 6 times in 18 months and will be back in Sept. I take a large, exec. room which is ample for a 12 night stay. Facilities and restaurants are good. Great pool and sauna too. My irritation: I pay, in my room rate, for breakfast on the 20th floor - Exec Lounge - but, it does not one until 07.00. The Lobby breakfast opens at 06.30, but that's extra. Sometimes I need to leave before 7.00, but why should I pay more? Also, Saturday, neither place opens until 07.00. No good at all when I had to leave at 7.00 for a flight out. Surely something can be done to help here?

Stayed here last year on our trip..just across the road from the airport shuttle service and a walk to the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Station, stayed on the executive floor which included evening drinks and breakfast. staff are very helpful and the restaurant is nice, if not a bit pricey. tons of small restaurants and bars just a short walk from the hotel, would recommend this hotel for any one looking for a place to stay in Tokyo.

Hotel is in Nihonbashi right next to the the airport city terminal in a great location. There are many great local places to eat and the Staff is beyond friendly and polite. Had a room on the executive floor so enjoyed the lounge on the 20th floor which was great. The rooms are very spacious and the housekeeping service is great. The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is that the Hotel is dated. It needs an update. It is not shabby but just feels like you are in the 80's. Would definitely stay again though. Highly recommend.

I have stayed at The Royal Park several times over the last two years, and find it a very good place to stay. It's very convenient - located next to TCat and with a subway station underneath - and staff are very friendly and helpful. Dining choices in the hotel are good, but there's also many good local restaurants within easy walking distance. Hotel is always clean, and no hesitation in recommending it to anyone.

We stayed at this hotel for three nights, the hotel is very good, comfortable rooms, good breakfast, it is on a very good location just over a subway stop. Staff was very helpful and we had a very pleasant stay in Tokyo/

We recently stayed 3 nights at the Royal Park Hotel. It was our 3rd or 4th stay in the past 5 years. When we checked in we were told they had no non smoking King bed rooms that we had reserved. The reception agent (who told us she was one of the managers) proceded to argue with us about our requested bedding. She said all their records showed we had requested twin beds (not true!). I asked them what a club room with a king bed would cost and she informed me it would be more than $100 more a night, which we declined;. We did take the twin room (no other alternative offered). The next day we were offered to move to a king room but we had been out all day, were tired and did not want to pack up, so we stayed in the twin room; By contrast, we had been in Singapore 10 days earlier and stayed at the Crowne Plaza Hotel at the airport. They did not have a non smoking room, but completely sanitized the smlong room they had available and offered us a complimentary breakfast when we agreed to the room. They were also very apologetic as they were completely full due to 2 large cruises leaving the next day.Bottom line: Great location, airport express bus across the street, subway under hotel but need to be more gracious to returning guests. Also, food in the hotel much too expensive. Breakfast was $37, dinner about $55 and up) Needless to say, we ate elsewhere.

This is a great hotel in a fantastic location. Easy connection to Narita airport by bus and metro station right under the hotel. Breakfast is good although pricey, and there are several good restaurants within walking distance. All the staff speaks English and there is free Wifi. The decoration needs some revamping, but it is highly recommended for short stays in the city.

excellent location within walking distance of CTATGood connection to airport and local train servicesome good restaurant within walking distanceoverall cleanliness is good as expected from a Japanese hotelHowever staff service is just "standard" Japanese - they will not go beyond call of duty to offer help - just standard service

Location is good and it is a quiet hotel. The bad, it's pricey for a hotel that has seen better days. They need to do a remodel as they are stuck in the 80s. The ugly is that the restaurants are so crazy expensive. The Chinese restaurant provided literally enough food for a child and it cost me over$50.00 US dollars.......never again. Go out and turn right down the street for a myriad of food options, but hardly anyone takes credit cards......weird. I stayed in the Executive Level and the breakfast buffet is standard, but the view is truly marvelous! So all in all, it's like I said, Good, Bad, and Ugly......deppending on what is important to you!

This hotel is very good , the room are good size , bright, very clean and very calm. Free Wifi which working perfectly and quite speed actually.Staff is very kind and ready to help whatever you ask. Special mention to the massage ladies who done an incredible deep Japanese massage. Try an hour and you will be born again.The best is to be able to go straight to the metro station from your bedroom with the elevator. There are many restaurants and mini supermarket and shop around it, where you can buy whatever you need and as it is far from tourist place , price are cheaper.

Hotel is good overall. The room is spacious for Tokyo and the location is unbeatable if one is to connect with Narita due to the direct access to T-CAT. The metro station access in level B2 is also a plus. On the downside, breakfast options are somewhat limited in the executive lounge and the rooms are a bit dated.
user_name:
HelenaGuerra
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Booked two executive rooms way ahead of my trip and ended up in a fairly dirty room (for Japan!) on the 12th floor - plenty of dust, dirty mirrors, stains on the bed cover and scuff marks all over the place.I stay at this hotel twice a year and never had an experience like that before.Hopefully rooms like that won't become a habit...Everything else had been mentioned before, convenient location, friendly staff and so on.Might need to look for an alternative in the future.

Its hard to be upset when you take the bus from the airport, arrive next door to the hotel and everything just goes smoothly from there.The rooms are generous, staff are very friendly (a little officious but that is expected) and, if you turn right out of the hotel, there are great little places to eat, to explore and to enjoy.I would happily recommend this hotel!

Have stayed here a few times now. The hotel itself is obviously not new but it is well maintained with as high standard of amenities and excellent service. The health centre overall odd good although the gym is a bit small fur the style of the hotel. Hard to get a treadmill in the morning.

I have stayed at the Royal Park Hotel 10 times so far (I go 3-4 times a year on business). Advantages- it has a great location. It is across the street from the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT), which is a bus connection from both Narita and Haneda Airports. The hotel also has escalators to the Hanzomon Subway Line, allowing quick connections to the rest of Tokyo.Disadvantages- It seems to be tiring a bit. The rooms could use a "freshening up". The equipment in the fitness center is ok, but not state of the art. In addition, if your room is not on one of the Executive Floors, the charges for the Fitness Center (approx. $20/visit) and breakfast (approx. $25-30) are very high.All in all, a good hotel for business.

Stayed one night in late April, before flight from Narita, and paid JPY 17,900 (USD 153) for a standard room, including tax and service and free wifi, but not breakfast. I’ve previously stayed here for maybe 40 nights in the early 1990s, shortly after the hotel opened, and while it has been maintained well and is still good by international standards, within Tokyo it’s starting to look a bit tired - not just the decor but also the fading stained marble in the lobby, scuffed furniture in the room, etc. The room itself has had some sort of refurbishment over the past 25 years but, overall, the place is not what it used to be.That said, everything was clean and worked as it should. Service standards have definitely fallen - nobody even tried to help me with my luggage when I arrived (I didn’t need help, but there used to be 2 or 3 bell boys race over to offer assistance); when I checked out and commented that no English language newspaper had been left outside my room whereas there were Japanese newspapers for the other rooms, the reception staff just seemed to give a shrug of the shoulders. There’s no turn-down service offered in the rooms now, as there used to be. Small things, but overall give the impression of a hotel that’s lost it’s way a bit. This includes the food. I always used to enjoy the Symphony restaurant food and atmosphere. This visit’s meal was very mediocre in taste, service was no better than one gets in a Tokyo coffee shop, and the prices are ridiculously high compared with the market outside - JPY 1,050 + tax (USD 10) for a small (300ml) glass of draft beer (much of which is foam) - a 350ml can in 7-Eleven would cost JPY 210.The hotel still has the key advantage if being connected to the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) so if, like me, you had an early flight and needed to be on the limousine bus to the airport at 6:30am, then this might still be a worthwhile hotel choice.

This hotel is just above the Suitengumae subway station that conveniently connects you to any part of Tokyo. The T-CAT airport bus to Narita airport is just opposite the hotel. There is an overpass bridge connecting the 2nd floor of the hotel to T-CAT so no need to cross the street with your luggage. After checking out, you basically can board your airport bus within 10 minutes. The hotel also sells very cheap 1, 2 or 3 days subway passes. If you are going to get more than 2 rides a day, the subway passes of this hotel is really great value. It is a lot cheaper than buying the day passes in the subway station. Try to book early in this 4 star hotel as the price can be value for money. If you don't feel like spending for their breakfast, there is a 24h convenient store call Family Mart just across the street. The room, service and the rate are great value but most of all it is super convenient and easy to travel around.

I stayed here for a week on business and it was a comfortable, easy place to stay. Do whatever you can to stay on the Executive level floors -- the included western breakfasts were a nice way to start the day, and the ability to mix yourself a complimentary cocktail while overlooking Tokyo at sunset was a nice perk. I would absolutely stay here again and look forward to returning. Having the metro station just downstairs was fantastic.

This was by far the best hotel that we stayed on this latest trip to Japan. The rooms were spacious and well laid out. Beds very comfortable and the bathroom was really nice. The staff on reception really polite and so helpful.

We stayed for a total of six days at Royal Park Hotel. The rooms are not overly spacious but perfectly maintained. We were on business in Tokyo and for that Royal Park is perfect. The business lounge is on the 12th (?) floor, has magnificient views and is perfect for a quick business meeting , also breakfast is served here, although the selection, especially regarding Japanese fare, is limited when compared to the main restaurant on the ground floor. We did not have dinner in the hotel except for one night - be aware that the main restaurant closes at 22h. The hotel is situated next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal from which busses go to Narita airport, also T-CAT is a familiar location so Cabdrivers for once know what you're talking about. Still, do not leave the hotel without a their card detailing in Japanese the hotel name and location (and never, ever, try to get to a business meeting without the exact address and building name written down for you by the concierge in Japanese). Next, the Suitengu Metro station is basically below the hotel: thus very convenient access to public transport. As the metro system is (despite urban myth) easy to use and tickets are cheap (a 2$ ticket will take you across town basically) this really comes in handy! Next to the hotel is a 711 store which I believe is open 24h so groceries or a even a business shirt can be bought a step away from the hotel. All in all great value for money.

Why would you choose this hotel: Close to the Japan Exchange and excellent bus connections to both airports. Also excellent service.Why you wouldn't choose this hotel: Not a whole lot of conveniences for families nearby, subway stop is not a major stop (but it is connected to the hotel).There are a lot of plus and minuses for this hotel. I liked the service. I fell and when I asked for ice (hoping to make an ice pack for my knee), they understood right away what I needed and brought me a real ice pack. They also have a lot of other things that make your stay comfortable (like 5 different pillows) and they bring them to your room very quickly. They have multiple (5?6?) restaurants in the hotel, but all look a bit expensive, but the one night I had to have room service, the food was very good. Reception and concierge staff were all pleasant and helpful.The subway stop they are on is not a main one so you will have to transfer to just about anywhere else, but the subway connects directly to the hotel. The neighbourhood is a bit more "local", so no Starbucks, but if you venture about 10 minutes away and go down side streets, there are plenty of local restaurants and bars. Also a few convenience stores within 10 minutes walk. Most attractions are 20 minutes away (easy by subway).

Picked a week to go to Japan when all my regular haunts were closed. Checked out Expedia and came up with the Royal Park Hotel near the city air terminal. Never tried it before but decided to give it a go. Was not disappointed, check in was brisk and easy, the room was a little dated but everything was clean and worked. Lots of light and very quiet room. Internet was free and very fast. Location was really good plenty of restaurants around easy access to a couple of metro lines. Would definitely go there again!

This is a business hotel in the business district that caters to business travelers not leisure/tourist travelers . The service is excellent and access to airport and public transportation is perfect.
user_name:
Bob M
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here twice and never been disappointed. Nice location, clean rooms and helpful staff. Also right next to the T-CAT for buses from and to Narita and Haneda airport. Suitengumae Station is in the basement for easy access to other parts of the city. Will stay here again on my next trip back.

Standard room was small but clean. The hotel accommodated all my requests when I reserved online, the view of Tokyo tower was good at night. Very quiet even though next to major motorway. It is right on top of the Sutengumae station. TCAT is across the road for bus access to both Narita & Haneda airport. The restaurants nearby were fantastic & much cheaper than Ginza or Shinjuku.

I stayed at the Royal Park Hotel on a business trip. Although the hotel is a bit dated the rooms are well appointed and the staff are helpful and friendly. It is conveniently located to the metro and the airport bus terminal. The executive lounge offers great views of the city and has a good selection of food and drinks. The in room massage service is also great value. The hotel also has a good selection of restaurants to chose from after a long day if you don't wish to venture too fa. Most impressive was the selection of products in the bathroom.

Nice hotel in a quite area, yet very well connected to airport ( Tokyo City Air terminal just next block ) and subway station in front. Very good sevice. Rooms are a little bit old furnished. Executive level it's a good. Deal for what they offer.

I wouldn't really give this hotel 4 stars more of a 3.5 frankly. I had to book 3 rooms as with a family of 5 Tokyo lacks hotels that will accomodate 3 people in a room. I paid for 3 executive floor rooms as we had lots of luggage from our previous week of skiing in Niseko. Rooms were ok size wise but bathrooms were small and in dire need of modernisation. Despite requesting adjoining rooms when booking, upon check in we were offered 3 rooms on various floors which I rejected as we had 3 kids with us. We were given 1 room 30 mins later but had to wait several hours for 2 further rooms (next door but not adjoining). We were not given any details about the executive lounge facilities until later that night which I was not impressed with. Breakfast in the lounge was just about acceptable but it was busy and choices very limited. Lunch downstairs was good but way way overpriced. Location was the best part of this hotel. Above the subway station it was easy to get around and the Italian Concierge was most helpful and I am sorry I cannot remember his name. He gave us an excellent itinerary of places to visit. Not sure this was alone a good enough reason to stay again frankly though. In parts it was fine but in others not good. Having 1 pair of jeans pressed for Yen 1000 was really over the top. Most luxury hotels provide irons and ironing boards in my experience.....plenty of room to do better

We were a bit overwhelmed by the sheer size and scale of Tokyo after being to the Japanes Alps and Kyoto but the Royal Park Hotel was a lovely hotel and well situated which definitely helped!The staff were very friendly and helpful and the room a good size and comfortable. If you stay in the Executive floors they also offer free cocktail hour which is a definite plus.The hotel is only 10 mins from Tokyo train station and right next to the City Airport hub for Express Buses to Narita & Haneda as well as being above one of the metro stations.

My wife and I stayed at this hotel for a week. The service was excellent and the room comfortable. The bed was very large but the pillows could have been better. The breakfast in the lounge was good with plenty of variety. The pool was a good size for a hotel at 20m. If you stay at the hotel you can by a metro pass for 1,2 or 3 days at a discounted price.If you stay at this hotel you can use the coach transfer to the airport from the terminal In the adjacent building. The one disappointment for me was the number of signs and documents inenglish provided with the hotel logo that had spelling mistakes. The managers need to correct this if they want to be considered as an excellent hotel.

Royal Park was nestled in a quiet area of Tokyo but still close enough to enjoy the city. A subway line is in the basement of the hotel so after you figure out the lines, it is a quick train ride to anywhere in the city. Rooms were western-style, very clean with lots of amenities I wasn't expecting. Don't worry about packing anything extra like lotion, robes, a brush, shaver or toothbrush/paste because they come supplied.For my first time in Japan, I did expect some more English but I understand I am in their country. I was impressed with how friendly everyone was and understanding that I was trying my hardest to speak their language. Hotel staff helped direct me to nearby landmarks I could enjoy before I had to work. I was 14 hours different so I'd wake up at 4am, well rested but still hours before I had to work.A FamilyMart is across the street to grab soda, water and light snacks for the room.Ask the hotel for the map of the 7 shrines in the neighborhood. I played my own version of CBS' Amazing Race and hunted down each one. I felt immersed in their culture.If you're craving a western breakfast, the breakfast restaurant in the lobby although expensive hit the spot. The steak house upstairs, again expensive but delicious!Wasn't overly impressed with the beds but after long days, I am not picky.The Airport transfer to Narita was nearby so that was helpful not having to lug baggage around the city to get to the airport.I would stay at this hotel the next time I travel to Tokyo, no doubt!

I have stayed in this hotel for the last 10+ years every time I come to Tokyo for business which is at least once a year. The hotel is conveniently located next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal where you get of the bus from the airport. Below the hotel is a subway train station therefore perfect to get around Tokyo. The hotel staff is very professional and helpful, all is organized perfectly. The rooms are of a good size especially for Japanese hotels. The only reason I have not given this hotel the maximum rating is the fact that the rooms are in need of renovating, they are dated and could be modernized. But all in all this hotel is perfect and I will continue to stay here every time I come to Tokyo.

My first visit to Tokyo and I must admit that it was a memorable experience @ Royal Park hotel. Situated at a stones throw away from metro and TCAT, the hotel also offers day pass to metro and tickets to Narita airport from TCAT. Check in and check out was seamless. I would have preferred to have a choice of breakfast either in executive breakfast lounge on 20th floor or at the ground floor but hotel gave only 20th floor since I was staying in the executive floor (17th). Food was decent. Overall, the hotel has all that it needs for a pleasant business trip. Will surely visit again!

I would rate this as a pure business hotel. Good location - Next the Narita and Haneda airport city terminal, where a limousine bus service directly takes you to both the airports.In the basement is located the metro which is well connected to the city. The check in and checkout are pretty swift, the staff also very helpful. The lobby is well appointed. The hotel is a period wonder. The room key is a object of antique.For the thrifty traveler a convenience store is located opp. the entrance. There are decent restaurant and bars around the corner.The rooms are of average size, wifi free, very well appointed bathroom. Well maintained rooms.The lobby is generally occupied by business people. Caution : for the merry makers the bar shuts down earlier than average.

The hotel offers 5-star experience overall, service is great; rooms are normal size and has all the comfort; location is very good, you can take a limousine bus from the airport and it takes you directly to the hotel; free and good wifi; plus it comes with amazing views on top floor and really good restaurants.

The hotel is very well situated just above TCAT and the Tokyo metro.Great views at breakfast from the 20th floor.The room was a very large Executive Room with free wifi and desk.Great restaurants in the hotel especially the Sushi restaurant.would definitely stay again when I am next in Tokyo.

I have been staying at the Royal Park for more than 20 years, my hotel of choice in Tokyo. Why?It is next door to Tokyo City Air Terminal so you can take the bus from Narita and walk 50 meters to a first class hotel. The subway connection is under the Hotel so very, very convenient and well connected to all parts of Tokyo.The accommodation is first class, several restaurant on site and an above average breakfast buffet.

When I worked for a Japanese company, they always put their executives up at this hotel so when it was time for a 'long weekend' trip to Tokyo, this seemed like going home.The hotel is connected via Sky Bridge to the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) that provides direct bus service to/from Narita and Haneda airports (ask for the Tourist fare, which is 1/2 the normal fare). The hotel is also located directly above the Suitengumae metro station (B2 on the elevator floor selector gets you almost at the door step). Suitengumae Metro is 1 stop from Mitsukoshimae, 2 stops from Otenachi (Imperial Palace Access, connect to Roppongi, Akihabara, Shinjuku, Tokyo, Ginza, etc.), direct to Shibuya and Sky Tree, etc., so perfect location.We opted for the Executive Level package that included separate personalized hotel check in on the 20th floor, extensive and excellent breakfast every day, an afternoon tea, as well as an evening cocktail reception (drinks/beverages, light snack food, etc.), all on the 20th floor Executive Lounge. Great place to just show up and grab a coffee, tea, etc.The service staff are very attentive and were helpful in all respect of our stay. They spoke excellent English and were able to make/confirm some of our requested dinner reservations. They were very responsive to difficulties (i.e. locked key in room). The room was a very large Executive Room with two double beds, a closet, a vanity area, in room bar/coffee service with complementary bottled water everyday, large desk, separate sitting area, audio/video, free Wi Fi (in room and in Executive lounge), typical small bathroom (with heated toilet seat). Very comfortable classic room for a very good price.There are many food options in this hotel, from a lounge bar, to a cafeteria style dinning venue, to Chinese, to Italian, to Japanese. We only dinned in once, but it was quite expensive for what your got - high quality, but small quantity. Taking the 2nd floor Sky Bridge over to TCAT provides more options, including McD's for families and a 7 /11 directly across the street. I also favor a little noodle house that is the first thing you come to as you exit the front of the hotel and turn right onto the main street - been here for ever. Walking further up the main street toward Tokyo downtown finds many, many shops and more restaurants, both on the main street and the smaller side streets - all very safe. There is also a temple in the next block (temporarily relocated for seismic retrofit).

Best part about the hotel is that it is connected underground with the TSAT bus terminal which has direct connections from Narita and Haneda airport. The lobby is magnificent and rooms are good but would have desired a little more in terms of working space from the rooms. The breakfast has lots of variety even for a vegetarian. Overall, nice hotel due to its location but a little overpriced considering the amenities.

This hotel is very convenient. Above the tokyo metro makes getting around easy, but you have to spend the effort understanding the metro. Next to city Airport bus terminal makes it easy to and from Haneda and Narita too.The hotel is old, but well designed. So the rooms are nice with a good view.The upstairs breakfast has a nice view of the city.Downstairs garden japanese restaurant has a beautiful zen like garden... nice place with good food.

This place was first class. You would be very happy staying here. The rooms were modern, very clean, and had a Japanese flair to them. Right in the downtown area. Beds were very comfortable. Nice bathroom with the Japanese multifunction toilet. The lobby is stunning, and the restaurant served a breakfast buffet that was a feast. The staff is what made the hotel for me. I have never encountered a staff that was so pleasant, efficient and professional.If you can find something wrong with this hotel, you need to take a long hard look at yourself. Something is wrong.

stayed for a week during last business trip and this place is chosen mostly because of its convenient location, not too far from my office. Rooms are average size, not too small or big, i did not like the fact the working area is cramped between the bed and the table which hardly leaves any space to move around. I had access to the their exec lounge and buffet breakfast. Exec lounge was on the top floor and had great skyline view of the tokyo city. Being a vegetarian, i usually don't much choice when it comes to food but compared to other international hotels that i have been to, i found the choice of breads and fruits quite limited in this hotel. service was good, whatever little i made use of. Lastly, they really need to upgrade their reception area - it looks aged and worn out.

Sadly, i am writing this reviews months after my actual stay so i might miss a few things but overall, i know that the Royal Park hotel was a great experience! After a long trip by train and attending some meetings, checking into the Royal Park was exactly what I needed to relax. The hotel is classically designed, the decor is more elegant but when you check into the room, the technological add-on's are complimented to suit the new age traveler.The staff was very professional, spoke English well and very knowledgeable about places to visit. The path to the closest subway stop is directly underneath the hotel so it is convenient especially if you are traveling with children. You can buy daily or weekly passes from the front desk for the trains, which are the same price as the ticket office so it is convenient.The in room dining was excellent, good food if you are out all day and need to just stay in for a meal before going to sleep. They even have an in room massage option if you like such amenities, i did not use it but good to know nonetheless.The location is close to most of the happening areas, Ginza is not very far from the hotel i would think a 10 minute drive. Rappongi street seemed further away but then again there was traffic in the evening.The Wi Fi was fast enough (I cannot remember if it was paid or free), but i was not in the room long enough as Tokyo has a lot of sights to see! There is a 7 eleven right across the hotel for those who need to buy some food/snacks and not spend too much on in room dining, although i found the prices were reasonable. The room was quite big, i had a twin bed room which was quite large. I think a king size or Queen size bed in one room should be spacious enough if you're traveling alone. Restaurants - i did not try the other restaurants in the hotel but i did visit the Royal Scots bar which seemed to be popular with the upmarket crowd and business people. There were quite a few people there in the evening, the bar was more of a quiet lounge , food was good so you can enjoy a meal there as well. A wonderful experience overall, i am planning on visiting Tokyo again with my family so will certainly stay at Royal Park again, this time maybe try the restaurants!Have a good trip and enjoy Tokyo, it is an exciting city to visit!

The Royal Park is exactly what you expect from a big city hotel in its class at this price. The lobby is magnificent and lovely, there are thick terry bathrobes and yukata in the room, the toiletries are high end and the staff is attentive and speak English. Rooms come with coffee/tea service. It's certainly comfortable, but I found it rather impersonal.While the hotel is literally on top of a subway stop, there are few restaurants in the immediate area except for the hotel. We did eat in the Chinese restaurant there one night and the food was quite good but definitely pricier than we would have chosen. Likewise, the breakfast was a little over the top price wise so we decided to skip it in favor of food we could pick up at the market (My Basket) on the corner.) The location on top of the subway was very convenient, though, as the Tokyo subway is insanely easy to use and the best way to get around town. And since it's really a business area, the neighborhood is very quiet in the evening--which also means you're not near fun in the evening.
user_name:
Shariann L
Somerville, Massachusetts, United States

review_body: Stayed here for three nights with family in adjoining rooms. The reception area us splendid but sadly the two adjoining rooms we were allocated on the tenth floor were a bit tired looking. Furthermore, on checking in at 4pm we had a short wait while the rooms were prepared.There are other hotels closer to Tokyo central that will provide similar rooms with breakfast for the same money so I doubt we would ever go back.

I had a standard room on the 9th floor room facing the main entrance. It has everything you'd expect from a 4-5 star hotel: safe, bar fridge, coffee, tea, with a few bonuses like a universal light switch by your bed, free Wi-fi and a bidet in the bathroom :-). The room is a tad smaller than what you'd get in NA. My room was very clean. If you plan to make your own coffee, get the bellhop to show you how to operate the hot water dispenser. If you like to run off that jet lag, I suggest taking the quickest route to the river as there is a path that runs along the river. If you're looking for snacks or just tired of paying hotel prices there is a Family Mart across the street, and a 7-eleven and a McDonald's in the T-CAT building next door.If you have unlocked phone, you can pick up a pre-paid sim card at the Mobile Center at Narita airport. 6500 yen gets you 3GB for 60 days on a LTE n/w. The nice girls at the info desk can guide you to the location.

The Royal Park has exactly what we look for in our trips to Tokyo: 5-star service and a location convenient to transportation to and within the city. The hotel's focus is on Asian and European travelers which appeals to us as it's a refreshing change of pace; most of the staff does speak English though. The Executive Floors are desirable as the rooms are larger and there's access to a superb breakfast as well as cocktail hour. Our room was quiet, comfortable (king bed), and warm with a welcome humidifier (winters can be dry). Yes, the room keys are large and the decor is Tokyo-modern from days past but to us that's all part of its charm. The hotel sits atop the Suitengumae Metro (Hanzomon Line) and is adjacent to the Tokyo Central Air Terminal (TCAT) thus making it the first stop from Narita on the bus (after the flight and the 50 minutes from Narita we don't want to spend yet another hour or crawling across town just to get to the hotel). We especially enjoy the environs which, unlike much of the more well-known parts of the city, is not a concrete canyon or Times Square redux but an area that rewards repeated exploration on foot. But above all it's the staff and service that keeps us coming back. Everyone: front desk and lobby employees, executive lounge staff, housekeeping, laundry, are 5-star in their comportment and responsiveness. By the time we left we truly felt we had been pampered, even spoiled by their attentiveness and care in all details. We'll return without hesitation.

We have stayed at the RPH in Nihonbashi since 1994 and have always appreciated the old world charm and service in a modern setting. The changes over the years have reflected advances and some reflections of the economy of financial capital.The subway underneath the hotel is very convenient and there are little restaurants around the hotel we visit from time to time. We will be back to enjoy the excellent hospitality.

I stayed here for a few nights from the 29th of Dec., 2014 until the first few days of the year, the hotel is quite old since they still do not use key cards, but the old bulky steel room keys, but the hotel is still charming, seems like the old Japanese rich frequent this hotel, the staff is excellent and very attentive and it seems everyone knows how to speak a little English, Downside though are the rooms which are quite small, the bathroom looks at least more than 15 years old, clean though, and the whole hotel could use a renovation. Location is very good though, just below the hotel is a metro station that can take you to the key points of Tokyo, another station 5 mins away called the Hibiya line also very convenient since it also gets you to most of the points in Central Japan. There are quite a number of sushi, ramen and japanese restaurants and coffee walking distance from hotel, there is a family mart and a 7-11 convenience store just in front of the hotel, and the Tokyo city air terminal us just immediately next door. We stayed at the executive floor but opted to take the breakfast buffet in the coffee shop, the selection was not that extensive, but the quality of the food, from the bread to the fruits and juices was very very good. I am just studying how to get to this hotel from the airport so that I can stay again at this hotel

The hotel is connected via underground passage to a subway station so it is very convenient. The room is spacious and clean. The gym is a bit dated but acceptable. The breakfast provided in the coffee shop is marvelous.

There is marble, there is gold and there are chandeliers to spare. Wedding events happen here apparently in that over the top meringue style. But we enjoyed the extras for our one night stay before our evening flight home. These included breakfast, lounge drinks, late check out and private check-in with refreshments. The rooms are large although the decor is brown circa 1990. There are towels and gowns and slippers to drown in and the spa with pool and hydro bath is large and empty! Good quality excessive bathroom bits and pieces round off a stay where it is about the hotel and what it can offer. We did not try the restaurants as they seemed pricey but room service was yummy and generous. Will recommend to others as well priced with these inclusions.

All was clean and quiet. I do not require a lot from a hotel, but of course, I like things clean and if possible, new over old. This hotel is pretty well maintained, while the furnishings are not dilapidated by any means, everything just seemed a bit dark and.....well, not new! To start, I was given a skeleton key to my room! (I took a picture of it, because I have not seen one for decades.. I felt very secure at this hotel and the staff was EXCELLENT and second to one let me say, but just wonder how secure a skeleton key is if a crook wanted to get into my room. For some reason, I had two twin beds in my room......didn't know hotels still used twin beds. Amoire and bathtub were all in shades that were popular many years ago (dark brown and tan color...respectively). Again, very clean and all things worked, but unless this hotel is TRYING to look this way for ambiance sake, then it might be time for an upgrade or renovation....just saying. Buffet breakfast was fine and again, the staff is very nice and helpful.

I am forced to stay here on my many business trips to Tokyo because of a Corporate rate agreement. For the price it is not a totally bad hotel. But they are not very kind to English-speakers (not just my view, my team stays here as well). They do what they do and if you like it, no problem. If you want anything outside of their automatic approach, you will be frustrated. Room service is often slow with cold food. They still actually use big brass keys. One visit I accidentally took the key on my check out (mailed it back soon as I got home). For the next several visits I was 'scolded' for forgetting to give them my key back and reminded to return it on my departure.

This hotel was so beautiful and clean and close to all the best of Tokyo. Walked to Mitsukoshi and many nearby stores. They also gave us a pouch with samples of Shiseido make up enough to use for a week :-) Nice little perk. There were a few weddings that day so I was able to see part of what a Japanese wedding ceremony looks like. Litle shops in the hotel as well. I would definitely stay here again!

Stayed three nights for business. The rooms were clean and well maintained but had the general feeling the decor was past its prime. The service, restaurants and bar were all pretty average. Location was convenient to transportation and walking to some sites.

I was very much looking forward to staying at the RPH for an important business trip to Tokyo, and I was underwhelmed. The room was nice and clean, but the service at the executive lounge was not good, and the meeting room experience was disappointing and embarrassing. We had two meetings set-up, one before lunch and one after lunch. when we returned after lunch with our second set of suppliers, we discovered that the room had not been cleaned by the RPH staff, as promised, and the dirty dishes and glasses from the first set of suppliers was still there. Overall, I think the management needs to improve overall.

Stayed two nights while on business and for a first time visitor to Tokyo this is an excellent choice. The airport bus drops you right next door, the hotel staff are top notch, and prices are lower than in the Financial District/Tokyo Station area (15-20 minutes away by taxi). The Sumida river is very close by if you are looking for a morning jog or a walk. The hotel room I stayed in (18th floor) had a slightly older feel but was well equipped and included access to the Executive Lounge for complimentary breakfast overlooking the city.

I enjoyed my stay at the Royal Park. Friendly staff, nice accommodation. I received an upgraded room with my Executive Package. The hotel location is convenient with subway on site and great local restaurants within walking distance.
