Nice hotel very convenient, if you like walking. The hotel is spaceous, nice views and very thoughtful. They have slippers, toothbrush, nice shampoo etc for you. even for my toddler. We enjoy our stay here. Staff are helpful and polite. We would like to stay here again.

Stayed Oct. 17 to 20, 2014: Location; Infront of Tcat terminal, 2 mins walk. Nearest subway beneath the hotel, 5 mins. Quiet community with family mart ( 24/7 convenience store ) across the street. Ramen, sushi, cookie, grocery shops within the main street, 5 mins. Breakfast; buffet not the best, just something to fill you up. Room: a bit dated but you got all the basic needs, clean and tidy though. A/C is adequate and room free wifi is not really fast. Viber connection is poor. Bathroom; very clean towels everyday and very comfy and convenient Toto washlet. Concierge; they will try their best to answer all your queries. The only negative is for you to drag your luggages in and out of the hotel to TCAT by yourself without any assistance offered from the porter. Will stay here again if and only if good price will be offered. Paid around 90,000 yen with iPrefer member, visa offer with free breakfast.

Stayed in the Royal Park Hotel for 8 days in October 2014 with my partner in a nice twin room. The hotel offered an excellent service and is located close to Ginza, the Royal Palace and Garden, the Skytree. Very good and convenient connection via public transport including transfer to Narita Airport. I used the gym three times which has all the standard equipment but didn't try the pool. I recommend the upgrade to an executive room with lounge access which offers stunning views especially in the evening/night. The only negative point is probably the decor of the rooms and the interior design which seems to be a little old fashioned and might not be everyone's cup of tea, but had a lot of flair and good quality. Service was excellent and above average for a five star, all staff members did a great job to make our stay special (Stayed in the Hilton for a couple of days as well and in comparison the service in the Royal Park Hotel felt more friendly, more attentive, more customer and service orientated.) Would recommend for solo, couples and business.

The Royal Parkl Hotel is conveniently situated right next to the TCAT (Tokyo City Terminal) with buses to and from Narita and Haneda every 20 minutes. There is a direct passage from the TCAT to the Hotel on TCAT floor 2 very convenient if it rains. Below the hotel the Suitengame metro station connects you to places like Akihabara (electric town) , Asakusa or Oshiage (Sky tree) even thought i sometimes choose to get off at Nihsonbashi (Ginza line). The hotel is fully "classical" and offer all the services you can expect from a good hotel, the business lounge at the top offers a great view. One remark, breakfast starts at 7 am only which is sometimes too late when you have to leave early for work outside Tokyo.

My recent trip to Tokyo I stayed at the Royal park hotel, Stayed in the executive suite and the service was fantastic right from arrival to departure. All executive suite carry great extras such as the piano bar with free drinks and snacks and other such as free breakfast which was a great spread of both Japanese and international cuisine.The extra cost was really fully worth what we paid. It has the subway located below and the TCAT service from Henada Airport is next door.I will definitely stay at this hotel on my next visit.

The hotel is connected to the tokyo metro's Suitengumae station on Hanzomon line and just next to the TCAT. So, it's very convenient to go anywhere. Amenities in the bathroom are mostly Shiseido's. Fitness club is well maintained and well equipped. There is also hot bath with jacuzzi set beside a cool bath well. So that guests can take hot then followed by cool bath for the full benefit of blood flow. Love it there. P.S. Nobody take hotbath in the early morning so people who are shy can go at early morning.

Booked the Royal Park Hotel as a special treat for my daughter and me. Problem once I checked in was that my daughter was not recognised in the pricing, even though I booked a room with twin beds and entered her age on the website. So I had to pay extra for her to have breakfast, use the pool (at ~$25 the most expensive swim she's ever had) etc. For such an expensive hotel (paying $317 a night) I thought this was quite greedy. So beware of the unfriendly pricing for children.

This hotel is superbly sited next to the bus station for both airports. It is conveniently connected to the underground railway as well. The restaurants are very good with good deals for hotel guests and friendly great service. My room was modest but comfortable. I missed only a safe.
user_name:
Peter V
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: The Royal Park Hotel [RPH] offers good value for your money. You can take the Airport Limousine bus service [excellent staff service] directly from the airport to the hotel, which is about 45 minutes away. RPH is literally and strategically located across the street from the Tokyo City Air Terminal, where the bus will drop you off. A Bell Hop will walk to come and get you from the Terminal - it is that close.RPH has a warm and inviting atmosphere. The hotel staff have good English which make it easy to communicate. The piano bar was wonderful - listening to live music makes a world of difference.Sure the rooms may be a little dated, however, the amenities are top-drawer i.e. classy which never goes out of style. The WIFI was great and fast; easily accessible and no password needed to log on. Be sure to use your international electric converter [even though RPH has two-prong] to ensure no power surge.RPH is situated directly above the Tokyo Metro subway lines, which will take you all over to the various 'precincts' and have good connections with the other subway lines. The station names are all written in English. The subway maps are easy to follow; take the time to understand them. The ticket booths have a tab to change the purchase instructions to ENGLISH. We did not find that out until the day before we left - it would have made navigating the subway much easier.NB: travelers can purchase a 2-day Tokyo Metro subway pass for only US$9.00; use as many times as you wish - excellent value for your money. Ask for them at the Front Desk.Be sure to try the SKY Hop on Hop off open-air tour buses. There are three routes which will give a super tour of the city. The tickets are US$25.00 for a 24 hour period or you can choose to purchase a 2 day pass; you can change from one route to the other as many times as you wish. Again, super value for the money.After touring Tokyo above ground and below, it was wonderful to return to the hotel via Metro and be able to go directly up the escalators to the lobby. Your warm rooms will embrace you for tomorrow's adventures.Rob [Jamaica] & Denise [Calgary, Canada]

This hotel is in a convenient location, near a subway station and the TCAT for the airport. I stayed in one of the older rooms, with the pink toilets and sinks in the bathroom. To access the room you need to cary a big key around. The breakfast selection was nice and the staff in the restaurant were very friendly and attentive. I found the bellhop staff to be a little standoffish, but it could have been a language barrier. The room itself was spacious, with a quirky central lighting control system. The room and bathroom were clean, amenities were plentiful, they thought of everything that you could need or may have forgotten. The location is great for exploring Tokyo, with some good restaurant options a few streets away. Overall, a good option for Tokyo. With some room upgrades it would be fantastic.

Stayed at this hotel a few times, always very welcoming and professional. Rooms are great, especially business floor. Location is very good, great for walking the neighborhood and discovering. TCAT is steps away so trip to and from Narita is easy.The Scots bar is typical Japanese , western style library with a Japanese touch on service and attention.

The Royal Park ticks all the boxes for a high end business or pleasure visit to tokyoThe location sits right in the heart of Tokyo - right on top of the Tokyo City Air Terminal ( with its airport shuttles) and the subway. For a Tokyo first timer like myself it's a perfect jump off location The decor is fresh and reflect a wonderful feeling of comfort. There are staff in every corner ready to do anything they can to make your stay more pleasant There are least a dozen excellent restaurants, Japanese, Chinese, casual, formal, tempura - and all decent value with high qualityAdd good sized rooms (for tokyo), great beds and free wifi and it's a real winnerLove it!

Stayed here for 5 nights recently and had a very good stay. I arrived very early from the UK and managed to check in my room early, this was so good as I was desperate to shower and have a rest. I stayed on the Executive Floor, and enjoyed the breakfast buffet. The hotel was quiet at night time, my room was also quiet and the bed and all the amenities were very good. Wifi throughout the hotel was excellent and I managed to use it to FaceTime my parents back home, it never once dropped out or froze when loading. The staff were very friendly and helpful. I used the TCAT to get here and that was so easy to get to from Haneda. I agree that the rooms especially the bathroom need modernising but there was a card in my room about modernisation so this sounds like something is being done. I will be back, and look forward to seeing the improvements.

Spending a week here for business, the service level was as you would expect from a Japanese hotel, very professional and efficient. Breakfast was nice and my room had a great view. Size was more than enough, and the hotel was close to subway, TCAT to airport and many restaurants in the Ningyocho area.

Stayed here on business because of the location which is wonderful. The service you get at Royal Park Hotel is also top-notch. The rooms were another story. I first had to carry around a heavy key vs most hotels that give you a key card. I could see it being a cool thing for someone on vacation but I HATE to carry anything extra in my pockets all day (esp. if they might scratch my smart phone). The room itself was also lacking. I feel like I transported back to the 80s or something. Otherwise it was a typical stay.

Getting around Tokyo is difficult, especially when you do not read Japanese. The subway and trains are complicated. Make life easy and stay at the Royal Park Hotel, with easy access to Narita Airport and major Tokyo destinations. 1) Airport Access. Next to Royal Park is TCAT (Tokyo Central Air Terminal). There are busses that run every 20 minutes to and from Narita Airport from here. Cost is $30 for one trip. Outside of Narita baggage claim is TCAT ticket and the bus is right outside. Royal Park is the only hotel that is connected to TCAT. 2) Tokyo Access. Below the hotel is the Hanzomon subway line by Tokyo Metro. You can buy a 2 day pass at the hotel to use on this line ($9 for two days). I hate switching subway or moving to the JR Rail on the ground level, it can be crazy and getting lost is not good, so you can use this ONE line to get to 4 places you should visit in Tokyo - Shibuya, Ginza, Nihonbashi (visit the new COREDO buildings) and Tokyo Sky Tree. They are all on this ONE line and you can catch an elevator from your room floor directly to the station. That is convenient, and non-Japanese will be able to move around. 3) Other - all staff speak English and service is impeccable. Make sure you try to eat dinner at Sumida Teppanyaki on the 21st level with commanding night views of Tokyo Sky Tree and Tokyo Tower. The meals start at $120 per person, but they have a course dinner for hotel guests only that is $55. Highly recommended. Bring you running shoes too, next the hotel is the Sumida River and there is an amazing jogging path that runs on both sides. This place is the ideal location in Japan for non-Japanese.

I stayed int his hotel with my wife for 6 nights. I attended a convention at the Tokyo International Forum and Imperial Hotel. First off, getting there from Haneda airport was a breeze because the hotel is right beside the TCAT where bus limousine makes a major stop. Also there is a major subway station directly connected to the hotel (Hanzomon Line via Suitengumae Stn). I have to walk about 10 minutes to the nearest subway line to take me directly to the convention centre (Hibiya line via Ningyocyo Stn). Going back to Haneda via bus limousine was also a breeze. Since it is directly connected to a main subway station, going around Tokyo was easy for sight seeing. Room was small as well as the bathroom. TV channels are limited. Nevertheless, stay was pleasant and we expected Tokyo hotels to be small. I would not mind staying in this hotel again. Food was expensive in the hotel but there are several Ramen restaurants, 7-11 and Family Mart in the area. I would not mind staying in this hotel again.

Comfortable rooms,comfortable bed, good breakfast, quiet quiet quiet, love this hotel. Fast wifi. Easy access from Narita. Views of the Tokyo sky tree from my room - hotel's back side. Ver friendky staff. Real room keys - hot water kettle in room.

This was my second visit, except for the location, nothing is good in this hotel. The rooms this time around were very basic not even coffee sachets and sugar!!!The rooms are now worn out and this should either be blocked out for renovation or ready it for demolition. Even the bed was hard like a log and i was offered twin bed room..The keys to the room is a antique ones which weighs atleast 100 grams and made of pure brass!!!! This takes back the hotel into a age of its own. They dont even provide you with water bottles and its charged. Luckily we had supermarkets opposite to the hotel and everyday at 7am we used to go to the super market to buy water. When your neighbor slams the door you feel like you just faced an earthquake. The only plus point is Tokyo city air terminal bus service is located next door, or connected from the 2nd floor of the hotel and connects directly to the terminal. Subway station is easily connected from the hotel through the 2nd sub basement which goes to Suitengumei station(through exit 4)

The location of the hotel is prime and it is connected to the Suitengumae Metro station which makes it even more convenient for a first timer. Metro is the most ideal commuting mode in Tokyo and having a station attached to your hotel is more than what you can ask for. Service is excellent and Rooms are clean; my only complaint was regarding the TV channels as they have very minimum English channels (3 news channels to be precise) broadcasted. Staff at the Concierge and Front office are excellent and will go out of their way to serve you.

The hotel is currently celebrating its 25th anniversary, and does appear a little bit dated in places (decor etc) but still very smart. The location is great (link to TCAT for buses to the airports), directly above a metro station and convenient for the Chuo business district. Service is excellent and staff are fantastically helpful. Buffet breakfast has a wide selection, with something to please almost everyone. There are a number of restaurants in the hotel which seem expensive, but which offer resident discounts. Tried the Japanese restaurant which was excellent. Have stayed here before (in 2011) and will probably stay again.

Good hotel, good services but no complementary water bottles in the room even in the executive rooms and very bad extention policy (asked to keep my room 3 hours more due to a late flight, one night more!)

2nd time staying here and drew a very small room on 12 floor with virtually no view worthy of writing about. good wifi access which was important for early morning and late evening IP phone calls back to US and Europe. staff very attentive and pleasant. had breakfast on executive level which was great. good location for TAT and connections to/from Narita.

Very good hotel .Easy to get from Narita . perfect for subway location .A bit old fashion looking .It is the fourth time we stay in this hotel Each time we travel To Tokyo we stay in this hotel. Beds are excellent

I am into my second long stay (8+days) here and, obviously chose to return after the first visit. It's a nice hotel with friendly staff and reasonable facilities, especially in the Exec. rooms which give access to the 20th floor lounge - all day tea, coffee, snacks, etc. evening bar and nibbles. My room is not huge, but it's adequate. The over-bath shower is not great as I am tall. But it's powerful and hot! Breakfast downstairs is very good with a wide choice. Proximity to the subway is very handy.

The Royal Park in Chuo is my Company's pick for a hotel inTokyo and I have stayed there about 6 times. Every time I am struck by the fact that given the location, this hotel could be so much better than it is! However it is a clean and relatively comfortable place for a few nights.The decor and rooms could do with being a bit more modern, and the dusky pink decor is a bit of a 1980s throwback! Rooms whilst comfortable are far from modern, and the beds are on the spartan side!However you can't fault the courteous service from the staff, who are always great. Breakfast options are limited but I use the Executive lounge on the top floor which is a bit more calm than the lobby restaurant.The Japanese restaurant is, as other reviewers have said, good quality but very expensive!

As always the entire staff at Nihonbashi Royal Park Hotel continue to provide outstanding customer service and go far beyond guest expectations!A tremendous thank you to the executive staff of the 20th floor...always a real pleasure to deal with.I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone conducting business travel in the greater Tokyo area. The hotel is located conveniently to all transit access points and offers everything that a business traveler would require.

Stayed here twice in May (for two periods of 3 days each time). We were delighted to have chosen this hotel, over many others of similar price, based on Tripadvisor's reviews. The rooms are large and kept very clean, good quality bed and pillows and the amenities found in the bathroom include everything one might need- with even a kit of shaving cream, lotion and skin moisturizer. Totally sound proof, the large windows have Japanese style light curtains that allow light as well as very heavy curtains for the early morning sun.The location is excellent: the TCAT (with airport transfers to both Haneda and Narita) is next door (50 meters) and on the basement floor is the entrance to the tube station. The area is safe to walk around at night with many restaurants and shops and spotlessly clean- like the rest of Tokyo.The breakfast is outstanding with a great variety of Western and Japanese food and the executive club, with its three and a half hour Happy Hour, just perfect to end the day. Located on the 20th floor, it has excellent, unobtrusive service, with good wines, beer and spirits. Varied 'tapas' such as nuts, olives, cheese, crudites and hot finger food is available every evening from 5.30. The view compliments the calm and relaxed atmosphere of this special place.The lobby, the lifts and all the public areas are very clean. Excellent service all around and tips are not expected nor accepted. We would most definitely return to this hotel when we next visit Japan.

High Quality Business Hotel, Just located next to TCAT a plus for airport Transfers. Ask for Higher Floors, to see beautiful Tokyo City through your room windows. Courteous Staff . Excelent guest service. Stayed there for 10 days. I Would like thenm to change their door to have electronic card ones as keys are too heavy and chance of misplacing is higher. I was staying alone so would have preferred Double bed rather than Twin Bed which was allocated to me.

Stayed for 10 nights end April early May over Gold week. Great hotel, excellent, helpful courteous staff and location was perfect for our needs. Easy to get to from Narita airport as drop off is at the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT), which is located next door to the hotel and has a connecting bridge. Had a small issue purchasing return limousine bus tickets on arrival at airport ie it wasn't offered until asked for (Visitors can get a return for 4500 JPY, normal rtn 6200 JPY) the assistant spoke good English so sorted quickly . Stayed in an Executive Floor room which offered access to Executive Lounge with complimentary coffee, tea, cocktails and snacks and very helpful staff. Complimentary breakfast buffet and complimentary access to the fitness Club, pool, and sauna. Two hours complimentary use of the meeting rooms if required and extension of check-out time to 3 PM Room size ideal for two adults, especially compared to many Tokyo hotel rooms. Had Breakfast in the 1ST floor restaurant as better selection sellection of food and still included in the executive room rate, one thing on busy weekends and Holidays it gets full and you have to wait to be seated due to Gold Week we has to wait 3 times to get a seat, same for the Executive lounge 5-7pm cocktail time is very busy on Holidays

Like all Tokyo hotels this is very well presented to a very high standard and is exactly what you would expect from this quality of hotel. Modern and very well fitted. You will not be disappointed. Traffic is very busy in Tokyo.

Luxurious hotel on a good location, next to TCAT which can easily be reached from the airport by bus. Hotel is located directly above a metro station which makes it a good location for exploring the city.Only disappointment is that you have to pay separately for the gym, pool and sauna. From my point of view that should be part of the price you pay for the room.

Great hotel with top of the line service, tasty (Western) breakfast, and good location. If you like Japanese food, there is a restaurant in the same building. The place is great for business trips, would love to stay there again.

We stayed at the Royal Park Hotel mid April 2014 and found it to be awesome! The subway is directly beneath the hotel, so we were able to go anywhere in Tokyo. We even took public transport out to Tokyo Disneyland, just like a real local. This hotel is well maintained and the front desk staff were courteous and very helpful. We would definitely stay at this hotel again.

We stayed here in March booking through Hotels.com. We booked an executive double which Hotel.com says is on floors 15-18. That didn't happen and a lot of the facilities listed didn't materialize. We realized later when we made bookings for two more nights and stayed on those floors...It was superb. When we questioned them they said that hotels. com had got it wrong!! So be very careful when you book- my recommendation is to go for the Deluxe double on the higher floors .On the positive side, the complimentary lounge access was very good. Great tea/coffee through the day and great breakfast. In the evenings excellent wine, champagne, sake and a host of alcoholic beverages served with a superb view of the Tokyo skyline. This was a terrific deal.I must mention that their concierge was extremely helpful. The one at the lobby guided us so wonderfully..thank you . He recommended some superb small Japanese restaurants close by. He made our trip!Should you stay here? I would say book early and stay in Ginza or other areas. This is a dead neighborhood and you have to take the subway to get to the other places.. The subway is right below the hotel but it still takes time!

Upon making the reservation for this hotel the rate included breakfast. When I arrived, it does not include breakfast. Instead the buffet cost $33 US. Mistakes happen, but the worst of it was the treatment I received from the staff, especially at the front desk. I should them where the reservation included breakfast and they failed to honor free breakfast and they were very rude. (Which may I add is very unusal in Japan!) I understand problems happen, but being rudee is unacceptable.On the positive side, the rooms are very modest and clean. It is not a luxury hotel. I will never stay here again.

Stayed for four nights early April. Great hotel, excellent, helpful (even lent me an umbrella for use during my stay) courteous staff, and location was perfect for our needs. Easy to get to from Narita airport as drop off is at the Tokyo City Air Terminal, which is located on the lower floor of the hotel, or an easy walk to the hotel from front entrance of the City Air Terminal. No issue purchasing limousine bus tickets on arrival at airport. Stayed in an Executive Floor room which offered access to Executive Lounge with complimentary coffee, tea, cocktails and snacks. Complimentary breakfast buffet and complimentary access to the fitness Club, pool, and sauna. Two hours complimentary use of the meeting rooms if required and extension of check-out time to 3 PM Room size ideal for two adults, especially compared to many Tokyo hotel rooms.

Older hotel, but service is great!Right next subway station so access to anywhere very convenient.Also directly across the street from bus station so access to/from Narita airport is a breeze.Location near many restaurants and small village shops.Morning breakfast buffet had great choices.Hotel older/dated but clean and customer service is top notch!Would definitely stay here again if in the area!

Its been many years since I stayed at RP. I probably have hundreds of room nights from back around 1994 thru 2000 when we had a joint venture company with Kirin Brewry in a nearby office building. But even though the time has gone by, the hotel remains excellent and coming back gave me many fine memories. The service of your people is the MOST impressive and it is reflected in all the places. Scotts, Restaurant, Gym and of course check in and so forth. Congratulations to you and I look forward to a return trip in June of this year.

I did not have a choice in a hotel as I was here on business and the company chose it for me. But it was a good choice all around. Walking distance to the Tokyo Stock Exchange where I had to be for 4 days. The Metro station is just at the lower floor. The staff are courteous and helpful. There is a good ramen and gyoza place at the corner for a quick bite. And just a five-minute walk away is a quaint traditional Japanese tea house. Fifteen minutes walking leisurely you find yourself in a small park where you could enjoy cherry blossoms viewing. And, about the same distance away, is a bevy of restaurants. One had a choice of Japanese, French, Italian and even a McDonald's shop.

This was out 2nd stay at this lovely hotel. We spent 5 days exploring Tokyo and the location could not have been better. The Tokyo metro station is via the hotel lower floor and the Airport bus is just across the street.(Be sure to purchase a discount unlimited metro from the hotel before you go to the metro downstaris as it will save you money) The 7-11 market (for snacks, water, etc) is 1 block away across the street. McDonalds (for a cheap breakfast or lunch) is in the bus terminal across the street on the 2nd floor. Several restuarants are on the 2nd floor as well. Walk a block or two and you will find lots of little resturants. The hotel staff is very accomodating We will definitely stay here again on our next visit to Tokyo!

Just spent 3 nights here. The access to the subway is just underneath the hotel, the bus from Narita is just outside. The service from the second you enter is perfect. We stayed on the 17th floor an exec room. The view was out towards the Tokyo tower. The breakfast buffet had both western and traditional Japanese, I do have to say though at breakfast the coffee doesn't come around often enough but there is a espresso, latte machine in the buffet. On the 20th floor with a beautiful view of Tokyo there is afternoon tea and evening drinks til 8 P.M.On the 5th floor is the fitness centre with lane swimming, a small studio for yoga and an exercise centre. The sauna was hot and the jacuzzi was hot with strong jets.We really enjoyed our stay here.

Great location - especially of you need to travel to Narita or Haneda. There are regular buses to and from both airports several times each hour. There is a covered walkway to TCAT from the hotel - not that you really need it because the walk is less than 50m. Or if you prefer the Metro, there is actually a Tokyo Metro station (Suitengumae) in the basement of the hotel. You can easily walk to Nihonbashi and Ningyocho, and the surrounding neighborhood is quite charming - with excellent restaurants & cafes everywhere. The rooms at the Royal Park are larger than average for this price range in Tokyo, the hotel is clean, and the staff are efficient & helpful. My bathroom was modern & in perfect working order. The internet service is excellent too. Well worth considering this property if you need a bit more space during your next trip to Tokyo.

Conveniently located immediately next to the TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal), which allows users to go directly to or from Narita Airport (about 1 hr away), the Royal Park Hotel is a easy accessible location that puts you in the heart of one of the oldest neighborhoods in Tokyo. Sitting on a street lined w/Cherry Blossom trees in full bloom in the spring (like right now in April!), this is a great location if you want to check out the Amazake Yokocho area (main street area with lots of boutique and old world craft shops and eateries). There are also the Seven Lucky Shrines of Nihonbashi - and the hotel will provide a walking tour map that includes the shrine trek for those wishing to attain more wealth, luck, longevity, prosperity, and more! If that interests you, then also check out a shop that makes cookie-like pastries ("sweet bean cakes") in the shape of the Seven Lucky Gods (which doubles as a good gift idea for taking home to friends and family!) Interestingly enough in this area of specialty shops, there is also a shop that specializes in making toothpicks (and that is all they have been making "for generations"!).

Right next to the TCAT (Tokyo Air Terminal-not a plane in sight), this is a very convenient location if you are working in the Chuo area. A relatively quick and inexpensive ride from Narita, the service at this hotel is excellent, and the rooms are quite comfortable, and nicely sized. The hotel itself is 25 years old, but has been pretty well maintained. Great shower and bath(careful with those extra buttons!) and great internet access as well. The A/C is the one real gotcha-in summer it's really not going to cover it if you are used to US hotels. The hotel restaurants are quite good, if more than a bit pricey, although the coffee shop in the lobby was good, and pretty reasonable for Tokyo. Would definitely stay again, but would avoid the 'sunny side' of the hotel next time.

The hotel is located right next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal which has frequent "limousine" buses (just regular buses) to Narita airport. Inside the hotel you have direct acces to "Suitengume" metro station which makes it easy to travel around Tokyo.The rooms are a bit small and the bathroom is really outdated. The hotel restaurants are expensive but most of the restaurants have a special menu for hotel guests which is a lot cheaper (almost half the price of the regular menus).

They closed Orpheus. No late check-out--rude desk agent when I asked about it. $350 for the night and the manager wouldn't even look me in the eye when he directed DA to deny my 2PM checkout. Spend you money at Hyatt or ICH or Hilton. I chose to be a repeat customer and their response was to be rude to me.

My 2nd stay here - last time was 2 years ago. Very comfortable hotel next door to TCAT and linked by subway to the Tokyo metro system. Eating in the hotel is quite expensive even on business but a 5 minute walk provides lots of options. Had dinner in the Teppanyaki restaurant with a client on the 20th floor which was very good - look for a window table with a view of tokyo tower and the city skyline. A modest dinner was 25k yen for 2 of us (including a 20% hotel guest discount). Comfortable beds with a reasonable size room - very quiet and good for jet lagged travelers...

The location is great if you have business near the hotel. The hotel is conveniently located right next to the TCAT so airport transfers are a breeze. The gym and pool are great too as are the views. Challenges, yes. .Let's face it, when paying 50,000 JPN a night, top notch service and conveniences are expected. The room furnishings are tired, but I really rated it lower for the breakfast service. They don't open their restaurants for breakfast until 7:00 AM, which sounds workable; however their service is such that it makes it very difficult to be able to get in and out to catch that early train.

The hotel is in an excellent location - right next to TCAT the Tokyo City Air Terminal to which frequent "limousine" buses bring you direct from both Haneda and Narita airports. It is also above "Suitengume" metro station which makes getting around Tokyo very easy.It is only a short walk from the hotel to the banks of the Sumidagawa river and a walk along the promenade by the river is a wonderful experience as it provides a feeling of space and a breath of tranquility in what is a very crowded city.The rooms are spacious - comfortable and the hotel service is exceptional (by European standards - but perhaps more of a norm in Japan).Eating in the hotel is expensive, but then it is at most hotels. The Royal Park has many local restaurants of all types within a short walking distance - the guest rooms start at about level 6 in the hotel - so they are generally well away from the city traffic noise.I have been visiting the hotel for the past 8 years or so and although there have been some changes it still maintains its standards - comfortable beds, clean spacious rooms and especially important, quiet efficient airconditionning systems to help provide an undisturbed sleep.Both wired and wireless internet connection is available and it has worked to my complete satisfaction.I norrmally stay in the executive rooms but have in the past used the standard rooms - both are confortable but the access to 20th floor executive lounge (especially during the early evening cocktail hours) and for breakfast is worth the extra cost.Also the ability to easily extend one's stay to a 3pm late check out can at times be useful depending on your onward travel plans.I ceratinly recommend the hotel.

The Royal Park Hotel is located in the heart of the Nihonbashi business district and was a short 5 - 10 minute walk to my daily place of business, thereby making each start and end of my business day that much easier. Other than one minor negative that I describe in my review, I will definitely stay at the RPH during my next business trips to Tokyo. Location - Four points worth noting regarding the RPH's location: 1) If I was lucky enough to catch all "green" crosswalk signals, I could be at my office in 5 minutes, and no longer than 10 minutes otherwise. 2) The TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal - http://www.tcat-hakozaki.co.jp/eng/index.html) is the bus service that links Tokyo's two main airports (Haneda and Narita) to the Nihombashi district, and it's literally right next door to the hotel. I flew in and out of Narita, and door to door was about 1 hour. 3) You can access the Tokyo subway from the hotel lobby by going down the escalators to the platform. 4) Taxis are always on the ready outside the hotel's main doors. Cleanliness - They are maniacally focused on many things at this hotel, and cleanliness is at the top of that list. Guest Room - I stayed in room 614 which had two twin beds, workspace, and bathroom. This room faced East and overlooked a number of elevated highway ramps, but the traffic noise was non existent, and I slept soundly on the very comfortable bed. While the entire room was spotless, the bathroom pretty much needed gutted and replaced. Everything was circa early 90's w the commode being some kind of hybrid of sorts that included a bidet, and the tub was somewhat raised which meant that the shower head was placed at a height suitable for someone 5'6" - 5'7". All things considered, I chose not to dwell on the negative aspects of the bathroom, but wanted others to be aware of what to expect in this particular room class of service.Restaurant - I'm not sure if this was a promotion or a standard offer, but all restaurant meals were 20% off for staying guests. Previous to this stay, I rated the breakfast at the Athens Hilton to be the gold standard by which all others are measured. Well, the Royal Park is now the new gold standard for their outstanding service, selection, quality, and taste. I also had a great dinner in the restaurant, and the only negative would be the high price, even w the 20% discount. That said however, few things in Tokyo can be considered a bargain, so I'll chalk this minor point up to location.Staff - Outstanding in every aspect, and spoke excellent English.

The Royal Park Hotel in Minato is average price for Tokyo, about $250 per night and that might be lower than usual since there was a promotion while they were doing some construction. The rooms are in decent condition, just need to be modernized a bit. There are some small points, such as no coffee, just tea in the room. The service is uniformly good. The gym is on the small side for a hotel this size and equipment need of updating but the full size pool is fine, well heated. Do not eat here unless someone else is paying the bill, since all the restaurants are very expensive...for example a scoop of ice cream will cost you $9.00 and cup of coffee over $10.00...ridiculous. Location is good, in central part of Tokyo and subway can be reached right from inside the hotel. One other issue, the lobby is fairly large but there is seating only for about 10-12 people, very strange for a hotel of this size.
user_name:
Rich1913
Hawthorne, New Jersey, United States

review_body: Tokyo (& Japan) these days is a holiday destination, my annual fix of skiing and Sumo. After 40+ visits over 16 years I still choose to stay at the Royal Park. The family and I view it as our Tokyo home. Whilst there have been a number of changes to the hotel over the years, it has maintained the same comfortable feel, even with a variety of referbs. It is a 5* Japanese hotel, as distinct from the US/other hotel chains. The lobby area and rooms are smaller, but perfectly suitable. One advantage, many of the staff have been there over all the years I've been staying and it is wonderful to see them each trip. All are friendly and efficient. The location is excellent, one can never underestimate the convenience of TCAT and the two subway stations at hand. If you walk around the area, there are wonderful places, small shops and restaurants nearby.One call out - many thanks to Shimizu-san for all his support during our visits !

Very clean, great service, spacious and with good inside restaurants. Gym is nice and offers several amenities. Walking distance from TCAT, makes this so easy to reach from the airport. Might benefit of a larger lobby area, with more sofas. WiFi connection is a bit spotty. I find this place very convenient and will certainly come back for business. For vacation? I might choose something smaller and more charismatic.

Fantastic hotel in this lovely quiet part of. Tokyo. Just staying here for one night after being in. Shizuoka on business. Great location as it's a 2 minute walk to the TCAT centre which makes getting to. Narita airport so much easier. Also go down two floors and you are on the subway network. Restaurants are great and breakfast was top quality too. Well worth a stay and hopefully when I am back in March it will be for longer than one night. Oh, staff were so helpful and polite - then again we are in Japan. Lesson to be learnt there!!!

Royal Park hotel was lovely - I stayed there for 8 nights and I was very happy. The service is outstanding and hotel amenities are excellent. Only negative is a long wait to be seated for breakfast - other than that it was a wonderful hotel. Located in a quiet but nice part of Tokyo.

We stayed at the Royal Park Hotel between Christmas and New Year. The hotel is situated next door to the Tokyo City Air Terminal which is about 80 min’s journey on the Limousine Bus from Narita Airport. The hotel is very well appointed and the staff were extremely helpful. In most cases the staff could speak English, if not; they always managed to find someone to who could. There were a number of restaurants which catered for a diverse range of tastes. The Japanese restaurant was great although slightly overpriced for my liking (averaging at £90 per head). The bedrooms where very well laid out and the bed was very comfortable. If you book to stay in the executive rooms you get access to the Executive Lounge where they serve breakfast, snacks throughout the day, and evening cocktails. The cocktails were DIY as long as you could decipher the Japanese recipe book provided :o) . The snacks were excellent and prepared fresh throughout the evening. The Executive Lounge also boasted a fantastic view of the surrounding skyline, worth a visit!!. I only have a couple of gripes!! – Firstly, for the room price I would expect bottled water and coffee making facilities to be available in the room. Both were provided but only on a chargeable (mini bar basis). Secondly, the air-conditioning in the room was extremely inefficient. The lowest setting was 18 Degrees (C). At night it could just about cope, but during the day with the winters sun shining the air-conditioning seemed to pack up. On a number of occasions we had to leave our room and wander down to the lobby to cool off. What would it be like in the middle of Summer???.The hotel is well connected to the Tokyo Metro (Underground) system with most parts of Tokyo being accessible via a 15 minute ride. Tokyo Central station 10 min’s and Tokyo Disney 35 Min’s.

We stayed here at the end of our trip to Japan (including New Years Eve) and got a very good deal with an upgrade to the Executive Floor levels, which meant a bigger room and access to the lounge on 20th floor with free food / drinks etc.Excellent large room, well equipped for a business room, big bathroom and all toiletries provided. The access to the bar / lounge made a big difference to spending, as we were able to have a glass of wine and nibbles before dinner or going out which did save a few pounds. Staff very helpful and attentive without being overbearing.Breakfast also included, which was a buffet with Japanese and Western foods available.Metro station is accessed from within the hotel, so you can't get any more convenient than that really, and a supermarket just over the road for bottled water and beers (which are very expensive in the hotel / mini bar).Could not fault really, there was a smell of smoke, but as many places still allow smoking that is just part of being in Japan really, it didn't really impact on us.Would recommend based on the deal we had and the benefits and for location perfect.

Convenient to the TCAT and Metro...lots of taxi's nearby.Great excellent floor. Wish they had better snacks at night and a single malt whiskey, or maybe a Canadian Whiskey :)Room was spacious enough with great amenities. Good value for price of room.Will totally stay here again.

We stayed here for 4 nights during my husband's business trip and felt that it was way overpriced. The beds were stiff and uncomfortable- left us with sore backs. Everything was extra- coffee, tea, water, etc. Most hotels at that level should offer coffee if nothing else. Very few amenities in the bathroom. Not a bad hotel at all but just not worth the price, many others in the price range that offer better beds and amenities. On a positive note, the breakfast buffet was delicious and the service was good.

Have been here many times-always enjoyed the hospitality . The real secret is the location- I love to walk and the neighbourhood is great- fantastic restaurants -simply Japanese at its best.The Club lounge is really nice with great views of the city.

Stayed here for three nights on business in Tokyo - good location - bars and restaurant were all good - have no complaints - rooms were spacious albeit think they could do with a bit of upgrading. Restaurants and bars were fine - nothing exciting but all fine .- wireless was excellent and free - which is always nice -

Stayed for a couple of nights, connection via TCAT was excellent. Very comfy bed and I managed to get four bits of hardware all on wifi at the same time (and free). Restaurant on the top floor was fabulous.

Stayed on business. Strangley, seemed like a quiet part of Tokyo, if that is possible. Conveniently located right next to TCAT and Suitengamae station which goes to Shibuya and also Skytree.Room had everything needed and was spotless. Good choice of in-house eateries. Service was first class and English-speaking.Spectacular breakfast with a view!

Many times I go to this hotel, may be more than 10 times. I stayed again 8 nights this december. I got a room smelling tobacco. I booked for a Deluxe room at Executive level, and they tried moving me to a small room, Not nice. I have been also disappointed by the reservation. I contacted directly the hotel, booking my room, but they asked me going to Internet. Strange. You don't feel as a customer, just a reservation number.I'm member of I Prefer program for a long time but it seems thy don't care anymore about it. Executive breakfast is also reduced compared with my previous stay.

Great note, friendly service, reception lobby looks fantastic. Rooms are a little dated but very nice all the same. I stayed in this hotel for 4 weeks in November, I was in the executive floor so that made a huge difference to the quality of my stay. If you are booking here I would strongly recommend the exec floor 16+, for the little extra you get breakfast and access to the exec lounge thrown in. Do not underestimate the value of this, the exec floor is so nice, with free wine, cocktails, aperitifs, beer, coffee, etc it really is great value for money.The staff are the friendliest I have ever seen in any hotel in the world, they go out of their way to make sure you know you are special, I cannot fault the staff one little bit.Only reason I marked this hotel down is because it does need some modernisations, I think they have started to do that as when i was staying there was some noise during the day on the 16th floor.Well worth adding to your list.

This place is a nice place but suffers from what manner places in Japan do i.e. they charge for everything. They charge for attending the gym. Rooms are dated but if you like the historic feel and look then this place is good. Centrally located near the TCAT so easy to get a bus their from Narita.The location is not that close to many things so really not that great.I have stayed here numerous times but it is normally the last on my list of 3 or 4 corporate hotels. Good views from executive lounge but limited choice once in the lounge.

I was pleased to stay at the Royal Park Hotel for approx. 1 week. It was a close walk to the client and everything was very nice. The room was clean and comfortable; if I needed something, it was supplied quickly. I ordered room service and there was a misunderstanding; the man that came up ran back downstairs to make it right.If I return to Tokyo, this will be my hotel of choice.

Good location - near suitengumae train station and Tokyo City Airport Terminal Service - meet expectationGym - close at 9pm, which is ridiculous, everyone in Japan have to work until so late, doesn't make senseHotel environment - Room is clean but the entire hotel is very old, time to refurbish I will rate this as a 4 star hotel that meet expectation

I returned to the Royal Park after a two year absence from Tokyo. It still has all the advatages of old: next door to TCAT; subway in basement; good swimming pool and adequate Japanese Bath; convenient location (for me); clean serviceable rooms, excellent service, really good value. Yes there are some issues. As reported earlier, making half the floors executive floors means overload on the executive services, delay checking in ( I had to wait 15 mins), and delay in breakfast. A recent decision has been to abolish the Executive Lounge on the 18th floor and relocate it to the rooftop 20th floor. I do not see the logic for this, there is not much more space, tho' better view, but breakfast is as crowded as ever, and there is no rooftop bar in the evening. Also you are checking out in the midst of a throng of people having breakfast! The bar was a real selling point, great nightime view, busy, always, and sitting in the lobby, last orders 10.30, with a large TV is hardly the same. Also breakfast on the 20th floor has last orders at 08.30, which is unheard of in my 40 year experience of business hotels.I usually have a deluxe room, which is large, like a junior suite and really good value. Some of the floors are a bit tired, true, but they are clean, beds comfortable, and everything works. Electronic aircon means you can cool your room down to 18deg, which is great. Great array of free bathroom kits, as ever. Laundry etc efficient and chaep, about 25% of the NY hotel I recntly stayed in. Free use of gym, pool etc, which is good. I agree restaurants are expensive, but this you expect in Japan. The 'Staying Guest' option for the teppanyaki restaurant is good value.All in all a few points to complain about, but overall the Royal Park is good, convenient and value for money. It was also full, and my colleague had to stay in a nearby hotel that sold rooms by the hour!

I am traveling with my husband as he is here in Tokyo on business. Upon checking in we were informed we had to pay an additional 4000 Yen per day as the room was booked for one person only; in all of my years traveling all over the world I have never encountered such a policy. Once we were shown to our room we have two separate beds in the room and are informed by the front desk that there aren't any available nonsmoking rooms with a single bed. They were unable to inform us as to when there would be such a room available. We then decided to make the best of it and ask the concierge for some help in finding a place to have lunch. We had a bit of difficulty in communicating with the staff as we don't really speak Japanese and they didn't speak much English, he was kind enough to provide us with a map of nearby places which allegedly had menus in English. The restaurant ended up only having menus in Japanese though the waiter luckily did speak English and was able to translate the menu for us. Overall this hotel needs an update as well as staff members who can speak English well enough to communicate with its guests.

I stayed here for 1 night as I was returning to the States from a business trip. Its in an accessible location as its 10 min by taxi from Tokyo Station and right next to the TCAT (bus to NRT). Its also a short walk to the Tokyo Metro, so you can get to major sights easily.I had executive floor privileges that entitled me to the top floor lounge for cocktails and buffet breakfast. This doesn't seem to be very 'exclusive' as both the cocktail hour and breakfast were packed with folks. The food was OK, but one can do much better. The rooms are highly outdated, but I didn't care as I was just here for the evening.

We ended up in this hotel by mistake and should really have booked the Royal Park in Shiodome near to where our daughter was staying!! However, our stay here was excellent and we could not have had better service. The staff are very friendly and helpful especially on the concierge desk where they helped us find out way on the metro to Shidome and when we left took out cases on a trolley to the bus depot and checked them in for us, wonderful service.The room was clean and very comfortable and big by Tokyo standards. The food is very good and the breakfast is first rate with so much choice and very well cookedEvening cocktails and nibbles in the Executive Lounge on 20 floor were very enjoyable.All in all, despite the 5.5 quake early one morning during our stay, I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel and would love to return to Japan one day.

Stayed at this hotel for the first time in many years, after first staying here in 1997. Hotel is "good", but not "very good". Hotel is very well located, next to Tokyo City Air Terminal, so short walk to hotel after arrival from Narita on Airport Limo Bus. Stayed in room with Executive Club privileges. Room was clean and larger by Japan standards, but was unchanged since many years ago, is "tired and worn", and in need of being refurbished. Even had an "old and musty" smell. New Executive Lounge recently opened in September, very nicely done. Western breakfast in the morning had limited choices, but good quality. Disappointed when I hosted a business associate in the lounge for a brief morning meeting. He only wanted a cup of tea, for which I had to pay the "visitor" fee of 2300 yen. No accommodation at all by the hostess, said the charge was necessary regardless of whatever he had. A bit ridiculous to pay $23 for 1 cup of tea, even by Japan standards, and the lack of flexibility was not at all what I would expect from a "luxury" hotel. Otherwise, service is good, staff is very friendly and English-speaking skills have improved signficantly since I was last here. I would not rate them as a "5-star" or "luxury" hotel - as they rate themselves on their website - but rather a good option.

I went to Japan to spend just 4 days, all of them in Tokyo, for business. This hotel provided me impeccable room, as people told me, a good size for Tokyo pattern, and it was quiet and peaceful for the hard time with jet lag. I found very friendly staff, the breakfast was different from our occidental style, but I was able to find everything I wanted, the variety of the food was amazing and delicious! Also, it is very well located, next to bus station and subway. I want to come back!!

This hotel is conveniently located for those who have business meetings in Tokyo. Next building is bus station and metro station so it is very convenient to goto Airport. The customer service staffs are very polite and excellent service.

As a place to stay in Tokyo this is hard to beat. Easy access from the airports on public transport. Once you've arrived then the metro is right below the hotel so you can get around easily to all points of the compass. Plenty of places nearby to eat at. Which is where the hotel defeats itself. The restaurants are really expensive in the hotel. So I'd avoid them as you can get better for less on their doorstep.

We stayed at the RPH towards the end of our stay in Japan, the RPH was recommended by a friend for it's proximity to the Airport Bus Terminal (TCAT). The staff were friendly and helpful, the check-in was quick and easy. Our 12th floor room on the north side was a bit dated, however, it was clean and comfortable. The north side also provided us with a pleasing view of the Tokyo skyine at night, to include the tower. Bathroom area had decent space and all the ammenities, very nice. We took a cab to the Ginza District for the day, a $10.00 ride each way, not bad. Additionally, the Tokyo Rail Station is not far from the RPH, another $10.00 cab ride.The morning of our departure the Bell Captain's staff were nice enough to transport our luggage across the street to the 3rd floor, Narita Airport departure point of the TCAT facility, an unexpected, pleasant surprise. Although the rooms were a bit dated, overall, it was an excellent two night stay. We would surely use the RPH again, a nice comfortable hotel with courteous staff, close to transportation, yet away from the hustle and bustle.

I keep reminding myself that I should start planning my hotel stays properly. This time I could not because I was on the phone with a rather impatient corporate travel agent that basically told me I should have better preparation before booking a hotel, in the end, I let the agent make the decision for me which was not the most intelligent thing to do. This time I got to stay at The Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo. It was located in an area called Nihombashi, which is an area where commerce in Tokyo first started. You get to see many traditional shops, but the area is so quiet, and the only thing that keeps it going is the many little eateries that dot the street. The hotel is located next to the TCAT where the airport city shuttle buses dock. A great plus especially tired after a long flight. It is also just next to the subway, which is a plus since the place is so isolated you don’t get overwhelmed with the intricacies of the Japan subway system.The hotel room, though super old, is well kept and clean. It is still using a traditional lock and key, which is so heavy! They gave a little sachet to ladies who check into the hotel, which consist of a facial cleansing set. A smart move that got me buying the product later at the shops. I particularly like the toiletries in the bathroom, you could almost not pack a toiletry bag, as they had everything including mouth wash and nail clipper. The bathtub though old but well maintained boasts the best water pressure I have experienced for old hotels. Perhaps because the Japanese love to have their bath soaks. I suppose this hotel is a great location for those who have a short stay and want to be away from the hustle of major Tokyo spots. One had to literally take a train to each popular destination, but it was not so difficult getting around. I must say this hotel has great breakfasts of both international and Japanese cuisine. So good that you don’t mind having breakfast here everyday!

We stay in the Royal Park Hotel whenever we travel to Tokyo for a number of reasons. It is very easy to reach when arriving in Tokyo as it is a short distance by taxi from Tokyo Station, literally next to TCAT, the terminal for the airport buses from Narita and other airports, and next to several subway stations. Being in the heart of Nihombashi area, it is close to a large selection of interesting restaurants and eating places, so you are not limited to hotel dining choices. The hotel itself offers high standards of service and support, as well as stylish and good quality facilites, such as an excellent breakfast buffet, foyer, tour assistance, etc. The rooms are attractive, comfortable and very well appointed.

It's a good hotel but definitely does not deserve 5 stars.. Still easy access from the airport and very close to metro. The staff is friendly and can speak english. In conclusion i can recommend it to people who come to Tokyo for business or vacation

A few days ago my friend and I attended a charity bazaar sponsored by many embassies which was held at the Royal Park Hotel. I've been there a number of times before for various events and always found it a pleasant place. This time we decided to have lunch at the cafe in the lobby although it was rather pricey at 2,600 yen. My friend had a sandwich and I had spaghetti, since our first choice of the Obento luch box was sold out. We both agree that it was one of the worst lunches we have had anywhere, no matter what the price. Although we complained the staff just shrugged it off. We'll never eat there again. It was a big disappointment.

I was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was to get to this hotel from Narita Airport. The hotel is connected to the TCAT and the subway system in Tokyo. The limosine takes an hour from the airport. The rooms are standard size with a very comfortable bed. Stayed on the Executive Floor which included breakfast, happy hour cocktails and the gym/spa.Breakfast was a huge buffet. Something for any nationality. Had an omelet every day along with fresh fruit, juice and coffee/espresso. Open 7-10am.Happy Hour on the 20th floor was perfect. Great view, make your own cocktails, or pour your own wine. Several appetizers avialable every evening.The gym had several cardio pieces and a basic curcuit training set up. Also a aerobics/yoga room and a pool.

we stayed for 4 nights in this hotel and we thought it was excellent. My husband was sick and the management organised for us to go to the Catholic hospital to see an English speaking doctor. The assistant manager never failed to enquire as to how my husband was feeling. Breakfast was so good with a wonderful variety of both western and Japanese dishes. We were on the executive floor and the only problem was that the executive lounge staff never kept up with the replenishment of drinks, food and glasses. We always had to ask them to top everything up.Still, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel. The position is great and all the amenities are first class

Good value but a dated hotel. Breakfast time (till 09:30) is not up to international standard. Neither is the spa. Good: free WiFi, friendly staff and direct connection to metro station and airport shuttle.

Have been staying here for many years and it has never been disappointing. Suggest upgrading to executive floor which provides breakfast, gym, and evening cocktails and snacks so it is good value for couples. Easy bus access to and from both Narita and Haneda airports.

This is the hotel when I went to Tokyo first time.The best point it the position very easy to go anywhere.There is the subway entree tight at the lobby.And the breakfast impressed me alot.Very delicious and a lot of choice.The room is clean and cozy.Very quiet for a good rest after a daytrip.If you are sightseeing in Tokyo this hotel is a good chioce.

Had another good stay at the Royal Park. There's a limit to how much I will pay though - so shop around. I won't pay circa £150 a night as its not worth it. Probably up to £120 max per night inc breakfast.Got an upgrade to an 'exec' room this time which is basically the same size room but with added touches - like more toiletries and slightly different bedding. The rooms arent huge but I recommend the ones on a higher floor. Avoid the single rooms. They tend to be like a shoe cupboard and I find them quite depressing. Book a twin as a minimum.If you can get breakfast included then do so. Its very good indeed. However, I wouldn't pay the normal daily rate for it as it's too expensive. The internet speed is very fast which is nice. Certainly compared to Europe and the US. It was also free which I think is normal for this hotel.The staff are always professional in my view. The location can be great but it depends on what you're up to in Tokyo. Being next to the TCAT suits me fine. Plenty to do in the area as long as you are willing to 'dive in'. Generally, this is my preference whilst in Tokyo but only if I can get a fair deal.
user_name:
s2rmtrooper
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: I spent four days at this hotel while on business in Tokyo in September, and can only give full credit of top quality to all elements in the hotel that added to my support needs and comfortable stay.It is a large hotel, with 9 restaurants plus bars and my room which was an executive category had absolutely all that was needed for comfort, relaxation and "homework". Being on business, with limited time for privacy, I recommend the executive option with access to a spacious executive lounge on 20. floor - both for breakfast and afternoon/early evening refreshments. If not, there are still more than 9 in house restaurants/bars to choose between ... The location is also convenient, with only approx 10 min taxi drive to/from Tokyo Station and the Maronouchi district - and the Airport Bus Station (to/from Narita and Haneda airports) is only 2 minutes' walk from the hotel entrance.Not to forget, the service attitude and support of the hotel staff everywhere and on all levels is impressive and adds a lot to my clear intention to revisit this hotel on next opportunity ...

I was there in early September for business. The client booked the Royal Park on my behalf - location wise, it can't be better if you want easy transfer to and from the airports cause it's literally 2 minutes' walk from the TCAT.I agree with some other reviewers that the hotel has seen its better days but the rooms overall are still clean and well kept.On the Executive floor, the lounge offers both refreshments through out the day and happy hour finger food. I can't say the food is great but the drinks are very nice, especially the types of exotic tea leaves on offer.Their new lounge was opened on the day I departed, 2 Sept; I presume that it will be better than the one I have been to.Breakfast on the top-floor (supposed to be restaurant offering scenic view of Tokyo) but the buffet spread suffers from a lack of variety. The breakfast at the lobby cafe is a lot better - with both Western and Japanese choices.What I like about the Nihombashi area is its history - there are lots of famous restaurants in Ningyochou - teppanyaki, grilled chicken rice, etc. They are all within walking distance from the hotel.Service is great in a sort of business way - formal but not especially warm. My Japanese friend brought his son along to see me and the little boy wanted cakes. We asked the front desk personnel for advice and she wasn't really showing any warmth towards the boy (we spoke in Japanese by the way, not English).All in all, a good hotel with great location. Will I come back again? Hm...only if more reno is done to the rooms.

This is the 3rd time that I have stayed at this hotel. It is very good. The staff is friendly and very service oriented. The food is good and it has great access to the subway station. The gym could use a bit of an upgrade.

It is supposed to be a good hotel but I found it boring and outdated.Furniture are old and the classical style with heavy wood and marble does not make me feeling really good.Nothing to say about the cleanliness of the rooms but overall it was not a good experience. I have been there three times and I don't think will stay there anymore.Rooms and small - but this is almost a default in Japan city - and all services offered by the hotel are pretty expensive.Staff is speaking poor and no English and in the few occasion I asked them help for some location even the people from concierge looked at me like I were asking directions for the moon.The hotel offer a generous and really good morning buffet breakfast with huge choice of beverages.Location wise it is very good as it is connected with Limousine Bus Station and with a subway station.The area around the hotel is worth to visit as it is home of many famous confectionery and traditional pastry/biscuits bakeries.

Just got back from a business trip and was not overwhelmed based on the previous reviews posted on trip advisor, but also not bad. Very courteous doormen waiting on guests and the lobby was modern but that's where the upgrades or renovations ended. The room was a double double and spacious as we booked the executive floors. Decor is very much stuck in the 80's, bathroom was tight and if one isn't careful, you can slip on your way in and out of the shower/tub as it's elevated a bit from the floor. Great shower water pressure though, that made up for the sip and slide tub. Decor in bathroom definitely from the 80's, nice pink hue to the countertop, worn carpeting but overall - clean. Just like Tokyo - everything was clean and well made. The pillows were a little hard and flat but after a 13 hour flight, could have slept on plywood and it would have been fine. Nice buffet upstairs on the 20the floor exec lounge for b'fast...nothing out of the ordinary but quieter than 1st floor restaurant and nice views. GREAT service, everyone was very courteous and it makes you wonder why American hotels can't mimic the Asian level of hospitality. Given the rates we got as we are a Japanese multi-national corp -- not bad. But next time, likely look to stay at The Palace Hotel overlooking the Imperial Palace for about the same $$$.

I enjoyed my stay there. The location is excellent, there is a train subway beneath the hotel and many other train stations within 3 mins of walking. The hotel service is also excellent and the room was clean and spacious.

I have just returned from a four night stay at the Royal Park Hotel and unfortunately it is not a hotel in which I would choose to stay again. On the plus side the service is excellent. The staff are incredibly helpful and always on hand. However the hotel is dated, drab with small and rather cramped rooms. The AC took a long time to get the room cool, the bathroom was clean and had a solid choice of amenities. That being said, it was like being back in a bathroom from the 1970’s including non-slip tape in the bath. Room service was prompt, very courteous and perfectly acceptable but the choices were limited within each choice of cuisine. The hotel just misses the mark for me which is a shame as the staff really work hard to create a positive experience for guests.

I recently stayed at the RPH again. This was probably the 15th time I have stayed there and the hotel remains consistently very good. The team have been there for as long as I have been coming, so they recognise me now and are very welcoming. Normally I have breakfast on the Executive floor but this time I stayed with many colleagues and we tried the 1st floor breakfast. It was very nice indeed. I really cannot fault this hotel. I love the position as it is situated next door to the TCAT which means a 1 hour direct limo bus to and from Narita and 20 minutes to Haneda. The hotel is also situated directly above Suitengumae subway station so very handy to public transport. Oh and by the way, a Sumo training centre is close by and you can visit this for free. You just need to make an appointment via concierge.

This hotel is a good value for expensive Tokyo, and the service is exceptional. The property wears its 25 years, but the rooms are clean, small and comfortable. The breakfast buffet has a large selection of international foods, so you certainly won't go hungry. Getting around on the incredible Tokyo Metro system couldn't be easier, and the hotel is well placed for sightseeing and an easy bus ride to Narita airport. If you're looking for modern, chic Toyko, this hotel isn't it. But for a good value in an older, charming part of town, this could be a good bet. Don't miss the lovely Japanese garden on the 5th floor!

We stayed at the Royal Park while visiting Tokyo to go to Disneyland. The rooms are quite nice and very clean however for American standards they are very small so keep this in mind if you spend a lot of time in your hotel room. For us it wasn't much of a problem as we were not in the room much. The hotel has a metro station right next door and is very close to the main Tokyo train station which means that it is very easy to navigate the entire city from this hotel. The staff was extemely helpful and spoke excellent English. My wife and I speak very little Japanese but this proved to be a non issue. They also provided us with a card that included the hotel name and address in Kanji which was nice because if we hopped in a cab to come back we just had to show the driver the card and they knew where to take us. Over all we were very pleased with our stay the only downside was the size of the bed being used to a large bed a twin took some getting used to but still it was clean and comfortable. I would highly recommend this hotel and the only reason that I did not mark it all 5's was due to the size of the bed. That is purely a personal preference and for a single traveller would not be an issue at all.

This hotel is perfectly located next to the Tokyo City Air Terminal. So you cannot beat its convenience. The hotel prices are reasonable considering this is a very expensive city. Service excellent and the hotel has great amenities such as a large pool which is free for executive floor guests. Breakfast buffets are excellent and food quality very high. Breakfast is at no charge for executive level guests and the cost difference is not that great. Hotel has plenty of restaurants so enough to choose from. Besides the air terminal it is a few steps from the subway line. So excellent valid, superb location, and an array of amenities. Highly recommended

The hotel was celebrating 25th anniversary this year, a reasonably old property but charming as well.I like the location, its close to my office and close to city terminal to Narita airport. I enjoyed walking around the area. There are quite a few eating joints in the surrounding.The staff is its biggest plus, everyone is more than keen to help you. The experience from the moment i entered the hotel was clearly representative of warmest hospitality. The keyboard of my internet TV was not working probably because i was trying to operate from a distance, the response was they brought a PC for me, free of charge. That's an example of what they do to make your stay convenient.Rooms are good and convenient. The restaurants are costly but the food is good. The Sushi place is amazing.I would think the fair rating of this property would be a high 4 star but the exceptionally professional staff would help it qualify for 5 star rating. Cheers!!

From the entrance to the departure, I felt I was treated very well by professionals. The property itself may be old, but I felt comfortable, everything was layout in right order and very clean. Royal park hotel is one of rare Hotels with well trained hoteliers, which can offers "comfortable hotel experience". Great accesses from & to airports are plus, too. I also enjoyed "shitamachi ( old part of Tokyo) walk & dinner as well. I will stay again next time n Tokyo.

From the moment I entered the lobby, I was greeted with the warmest of service at a hotel. Everyone, from the greeter, to the bell boy, to the guy at the check in counter, was so eager to make my stay a very pleasant one. By now though, I didn't allow that to cloud my initial perception that this was an older hotel which probably had its days of grandeur many days ago. My room was pretty tight and the furnishings were all very 90s. That said though, there was nothing wrong with it at all if you were OK with dates designs. The room was very clean and everything was laid out in a very logical manner. The toilet, though old school, had nice soap/shampoos and there was also a handy kit comprising of a comb, nail filer, nail clipper, Band-Aid, sewing kit. It was these little details around the room which made me appreciate the simple luxury that many swanky hotels tend to miss nowadays. The hotel is situated right by Tokyo City Air Terminal and you can take a bus to/from Haneda and Narita for ¥3000 or less, making this location very ideal. It's very close to the river and morning jogs along the river offer a great view of the Sky Tree. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by Royal Park and would stay here again my next trip.

I stay here when I am in Tokyo. I love the location-great walking around the side streets, many excellent restaurants and bars.I ate in an Indian, just down the road, and a Japanese Steak House two blocks from the Hotel. The service at the Hotel is excellent.The Hotel is next to the TCAT which is directly served by bus from Narita airpor.t

This hotel is one of the easiest in Tokyo to access from Narita International Airport as the Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT) is attached to the property. It is handy to the Marunouchi, Otemachi and Ginza districts and not too far from the world famous Tsukiji fish market. The rooms were a bit small and dated, but were clean with good amenities.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for a couple nights on our way back from Australia... It was a great choice... central location, directly across from the bus station, so easy to get to from the airport. The staff were very friendly and courteous. We were greeted in our room with a bottle of wine and a fruit plate. We dined at the teppanyaki restaurant which was phenomenal, highly recommend it. Can't say enough positives about this hotel, would definitely stay here again when in Tokyo.

The hotel is located near the TCAT, and simple access from Narita airport. I checked at the Executive level. Unfortunately, the room I stayed was a smoking room, and I am not a smoker. The smell in the room was awful. The hotel was unable to change my room, or to upgrade. The room was very small, outdated, dark, but quiet and the bed was comfortable. No wifi. Outdated bathroom also, but with nice amenities. No room service available after 9:00 pm. I had a dinner with sushi and a creme brûlée. Good sushi but the creme brûlée can be improved. The guy who came with the dinner was helpful even if he did not speak a word of English. Nice breakfast at the executive level, with beautiful view. Location of the hotel is easy to reach Ginza.

I arrived on the bus from Narita that ends up at TCAT (the Tokyo City Air Terminal) which is right next to the hotel. I was booked in an Executive Floor room so check-in was a sit-down affair on an upper floor. The hotel was excellent and I enjoyed the breakfast in the lobby restaurant each day. There is another place for breakfast on the top floor too but it is unspectacular although there is a bit of a view. The hotel restaurants are quite expensive (normal - like all) so I ventured off on most nights to the surrounding area. The hotel provides a very good list but it is a bit dated - places that were supposed to be open were not. So call ahead or start out when you are not too hungry! I had to do quite a bit of real work and the WiFi and wired connections in the room were excellent. I could get all devices on the Internet with no difficulty. I will be back soon - and will stay at the same place.

The hotel is located at the Tokyo City Air Terminal so access to metro and Narita was welcomed after a long flight from Chicago. I checked in on the Executive level where I treated myself to some nice snacks and drinks. My room, an upgrade, was modern, spacious, and very well-furnished. The weather outside was awfully hot and humid, however, the air conditioning was very responsive and strong. Beds were comfortable and room was quiet, making for a welcomed sleep. The bathroom was spacious and filled with all kinds of nice convenient additions.For my first night with a 14 hour jet lag I ordered pan-fried fish, rice and soup from room service. It arrived fast and was satisfying. The most memorable attribute was the service. Every dumb question I had at the front desk or concierge was handled with patience and a smile.This was also true for the concierge lounge.The health club was very nice and the men's spa was so relaxing after a long day of business. Caution: You must follow the rules for footware rules or you will be scolded. Once I figured out the footware rules, the saunas, showers, and relaxation room was heavenly.I've eaten at most, or all of their restaurants (I've stayed here a few times) and all have good to excellent food. I had the bento box lunch in the lounge in the lobby and service was fast, friendly and the food was fine. I also had an upscale dinner on the 5th floor Japanese restaurant, near the tea garden.
