This dinner was special and memorable. I had breakfast each morning on the 20th floor. The buffet was adequate, view was beautiful. I would like to have had more Japanese food selections. Treats and beverages on the 20th floor lounge was convenient.Overall, I felt very special and welcome at the Royal Park and I believe the quality is quite high.

The staff is friendly, extremely helpful, and communication is easy. The room I stayed in was well appointed, comfortable, and had all necessary amenities. Best of all, access from and to Narita was simple and quick, and getting around the city was also easy from here. I've stayed elsewhere in Tokyo on my many previous trips, but I'll be coming back here from now on.

I stayed at the Royal Park hotel whilst on a business trip because it was close to my office. Needless to say, its proximity was not worth it. The property should be avoided. Above all, the worst thing about this hotel is the air conditioning (if you can even call it that). I had it set to the lowest possible temperature and it was still hot - there is no way to control the fan's speed as well. If there was such a thing as an "extra low" setting, this was the unit was set to. I couldn't sleep at night and they didn't even have a fan to give me. Furthermore, the window doesn't open (not that this would help much). This can be unbearable in the heat of Tokyo's summer (33+). There were other issues as well. I was booked into a room with a double bed and they tried to tell me that I actually booked a room with two single beds. I had to argue with the front desk staff and have my travel company call them (because I didn't have a confirmation printed out, which they insisted I provide them). Eventually, I decided to switch hotels. I told them I was checking out early and, again, they put up a fuss by saying that I couldn't! I told them my rate allowed me to do so and, after getting into a lengthy discussion with the manager, I was finally allowed to leave. I moved to the ANA Intercontinental, which is a FAR better property and even had a lower corporate rate (at that point, I didn't care that I would have a 27 min commute to my office).Some other thoughts:Location - It is easily accessible via an attached metro station and a bus terminal with direct links to Narita. There isn't much else in the area except for a few restaurants, many of which are closed on the weekends, and mini-marts. There is a Starbucks about 10 min walk away. There are great areas of Tokyo, but this one doesn't showcase the city well.Service - Per my above complaints, I wasn't that impressed with the service. The staff's English was okay to poor. Food - I ordered room service once. It wasn't good and I never tried it again. Rooms / property - They are small and clean. What you would expect from a 3 star hotel. Oddly enough, your key into the room is a skelton key. It may sound quaint, but I found it annoying to carry around. In general, the best way to describe the property is that it looks like something out of the early 90s. Other points - The Internet is free (wireless and wired) and works well.I am sure you won't be surprised that I won't stay at this hotel again. Tokyo is a great place, with many different properties to stay at. I don't see any reason why this one should be considered. I travel a lot for business and I can't understand why there are so many good reviews.
user_name:
legacytraveler1
New York City, New York

review_body: The Executive Floors of this hotel right up the elevator from the Suitengu metro station, on the Hanzomon Line, make this a great place to relax in the bustle of Tokyo. Rooms on floors 16 to 19 have full amenities, but the best parts are the free self-service cocktail hour from 6 to 8, with an assortment of light nibbles, and the full made-to-order breakfast on the 20th floor. The breakfast is far better than the average buffet and the chef will make you an omelette to order. It is a great way to start the day whether you are sightseeing or on business. This is not the best hotel in town, but it is certainly one of the best values for the price.

I have stayed at the Royal Park five or six times as it is close to the office where I do business in Tokyo. I used to stay here as a rule but the price became a little too high when the US dollar bottomed out against the Japanese yen. Now that it has recovered substantially, I am once again in a position to stay here a little more often. The location is terrific as it right next door to TCAT, a common destination for buses from Narita (about 50 - 60 minutes) and Haneda (about 20 - 25 minutes). It also allows access to the Suitengumae Metro station directly from the lower level of the hotel. For the price you pay, the accommodations are quite good, the service is excellent and the breakfast buffet is top notch. The rooms are spacious and very clean. The facilities are a bit on the older side but they are very well kept. The staff are extremely polite and efficient. Use of English is never a problem. The concierge is always helpful when you need directions on somewhere to go or how to get about on the train or subway. That was reinforced on my recent stay as the advice I received was quite useful. The price is still a little high but it is very reasonable when considering prices in general in Tokyo. I certainly feel I get a good value for what I pay. If Nihonbashi is a convenient place to stay for your visit, this is a great choice.

It was my first trip to Japan in December 2012, i was fed with loads of information from my friends and colleagues about Japan.....and nothing was true. For me this was a heavenly place.About Hotel..To start off, the hotel was very good..spacious...and perfectly located. The airport bus terminus was located in the adjacent building complex and and metros stations within 250 meters from the hotel. The service was fantastic, reminded me of Taj quality of service. The sleep quality, the upkeep...was exceptional. Highly recommended place. However from cost point view, Japan is very expensive, because of their weak currency!!!About Tokyo...Distance from Airport to hotel via airport shuttle bus( Which is frequently available outside airport terminus, for which the ticket needs to be collected near the exit gates) was about 45 mins. Though Tokyo was more a commercial district, the strange thing that i noticed was, it was a young crowd all over, old people were usually found near temples.Coming to Metro, one thing that every visitor needs to experience, the metro during peak hours. There is a dedicated guard with white gloves on, just to stuff people in. Be ready to be completely sandwiched!!!!! would highly recommend this hotel and Japan to any traveller who is looking towards eastern part of the globe.When in Japan, you need to try the Shinkansen or the Bullet train...The routes that we tries was Tokyo to Osaka and Hiroshima...Amazing feeling....a life time experience..

Ok so it's not super modern sleek and a little old school but it has great service, breakfast included, pool and gym ( currently under renovation) and is close to the metro. The rooms can be tiny so if you can splurge for a larger room, do it. We didn't know so we had two twin beds. Also, there are English speakers here, always a plus in my book. It's also very clean....huge for me. I will never stay in a dirty hotel. Other options exist but this is too bad.

Royal Park is a proper high end hotel, there's not too much to say except that is ticks all boxes: great location (near the City Air Terminal and directly above an underground station), modern and clean rooms, friendly staff, great dining and rooftop bar. It's not an economy hotel, you pay for all these and you definitely get the value for the money. I have to add one special note though, for the breakfast. You really have a lot of choices here, and all is prime quality! Vegetarian or non-vegetarian, you can sure have a breakfast with a vengeance and then some, in the form of countless deserts, fruit choices and juices. I went for the scrambled eggs which the chef makes in front of you from fresh eggs - and I still think of them sometimes and get in the mood for scrambled eggs!Royal Park is a nice taster of Tokyo and by its location it will help you to an easy accommodation with the city, especially if it's your first time. I can only recommend it!

This hotel is situated beside of T-Cat airport bus terminal which is pretty convenient, not so far to attractive areas such as Ginza, Tsukiji or Akihabara. Some of their staff speak English well and my stay was confortable.

I've stayed at this hotel multiple times and although at first, I didn't think it was great value, staying at other hotels in Tokyo, I've come to realize that it is one of the best value hotels around (assuming you can stay there for about 26,000yen, including tax and service). For 26,000 yen, we get a twin room - two nice sized beds, not the best quality beds, but decent - plus breakfast buffet which is high quality - offers both Japanese and Western (this type of thing would be 2,000-3,000yen per person in Japan), and free access to the indoor pool, gym, and sauna. Now in the US, FREE access to the pool/gym is a given, but in Japan, most hotels charge 1,000-3,000yen for access. So this is why I've come to appreciate the value at Royal Park. They don't charge you extra for things that are usually charged extra at other hotels (even at Western hotels like The Ritz in Osaka). Also, we always get rooms on the Executive Floor which gives us free access to drinks and a printer and there is a dedicated concierge there that speaks fluent English. The best thing about this hotel is the location. It is connected to T-CAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) where you get direct access to Haneda and Narita airport by bus. It is only 25min to Haneda and taking the bus is great when I have check-in baggage. The hotel is also less than 10min from Tokyo station by cab, so if I have to make a bullet train trip out to Nagoya or Osaka, it is very convenient. I'd recommend this hotel to business travelers.

I stayed at the Royal Park recently for 2 nights on a business trip. As this was my first time in Tokyo (and Japan) I very much appreciated the ease of transfer from Narita airport - just 70 minutes in the 'Airport Limousine' (actually, a bus) takes you to the T-CAT station which is literally over the road from the hotel. A metro station is directly below the hotel, so transportation is pretty easy. The hotel itself is nicely appointed (I got a free room upgrade and it was pretty spacious accommodation) and the staff were extremely polilte and friendly - great service really. I used the main resturant for breakfast (excellent) and also tried the Sushi restaurant for dinner (also v. good). The only issue for me is that the a/c struggled to cope - I set my room temp to minimum and the system struggled to get the temp down to a comfortable level even though it wasn;t too hot/humid outside (Im found the public areas too warm also).

This was our second stay in the Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo. We were pleased on both trips. The hotel is located adjacent to the TCAT (Tokyo City Air Transit) terminal so that it is ideal to travel to and from Narita airport via the bus (one hour drive). There is a subway stop (the purple line) in the basement and navigating Tokyo is easy from this hotel. The service is unbelievable! Very polite and capable staff.There are also numerous restaurants in the area and it is very convenient to eat delicious and affordable food. We also had the breakfast buffet daily which was awesome (both Western and Japanese style breakfast available).In addition, there is a gym to maintain your exercise program. There is also a lap pool to exercise and also for the kids to relax at the end of a day of sight-seeing.I think it is the ideal hotel for business or pleasure trips to Tokyo.

As a first timer in Tokyo I appreciated the easy access by Bus from Narita airport. Staff are extremely friendly and helpful. Got a room on the executive floors and room size quite acceptable and mini bar well equipped. Breakfast starts at 7am and can recommend the top floor restaurant with a nice view while you enjoy your freshly made omelet. The 16th floor executive open bar is a good place the meet after work. The hotel is by today's standard maybe slightly old fashioned but that is not to say it is not well kept or run down, on the contrary. Free internet is definitely a big plus and bed is very comfortable.

The hotel is just beside the TCAT, and a metro station. Friendly and helpful staff. It's a luxury hotel but rooms are dated, they need a renovation. The standard rooms are small. Breakfast is good. They offer free mineral water only in the deluxe rooms, taking a package in the executive floor they don't have this service in the standard rooms.

Location is a breeze and the hotel is designed to welcome the western visitor be it us invests or pleasure. I stayed on the executive floor with the drinks and lounge access which was nice. Room is big by Japanese standards and the bathroom is well stocked including hair oil for tired scalps!!!! All in all hard to fault

Arrived on a rainy day. The bus from Narita to the T-CAT was a breeze to negotiate and a gentle transition from air travel to city life. The walk to the hotel is very short; the second floor passage bypasses city traffic and is protected from the elements. The staff of the hotel are remarkably polite and nice. Sunday breakfast in the lobby cafe, Symphony, is a bit hectic but a treat. Access to Tokyo Metro (Suitengumae station) is direct from the hotel's B2 level. Took several cabs and there was never a wait. A short walk in nearly any direction takes you to just about any amenity you might need while travelling, as well as some rather good restaurants. There really wasn't much reason to stay in the room except to sleep. stayed in a non-smoking room, which smelled faintly of tobacco for the first few hours. Colleagues who stayed on smoking floors cautioned that the experience is rather intense.

This hotel just celebrated it 25th anniversary. It's a luxury hotel, despite its design reveals its age.Excellent service as always.Facilites: the swimming pool really needs update, as its walls appeared without tiles and rather scratched -definitely not nice to see. The gym is rather small but well equipped. Nice sauna and jacuzzi area.Breakfast on top floor: watch out, if the hotel is fully booked you may have to be on a waiting list. Consider calling for a booking, to avoid time loss.Restaurants: ORPHEUS (top floor, lounge): lunch with international buffèt, dinner with limited selections of a sort of fusion menù. In both case, good quality, despite high price. Nice view, but the location of the Orpheus windows do not have spectacular skyline of skyscrapers (like at Park Hyatt or Dai Ichi hotels)Genjiiko Japanese Restaurant: I tried the low cost menu (around 5200JPY) and found a miserable food quality. They created a very nice Japanese garden. with pond and trees: the view is definitely nice.YANONE SUSHI restaurant (basement): excellent sushi bar -with hotel price, but great, cheerful service and excellent taste. This seems to me the best restaurant of the hotel, for quality/price ratio.Overall: I'll definitely come back. (I tried the Dai Ichi but feel there is no comparison).For the restaurants, except the Yanone Sushi, I see limited reasons to stay in the hotel.

Although this hotel is kinda old but it is still very well maintained and retained it's charm ! Room is spacious as we got ourselves a room on the executive floors. We have 2 little toddlers and the room is spacious for the 4 of us. Because of time constraint we did not get to visit the executive lounge on the 20th floor, but totally enjoyed the great breakfast buffet spread on the 1st floor of the hotel, the buffet spread is just wonderful even if you are a picky eater, you can surely find something to satisfy yourself to kick start the day with. Love love love the buffet ! This brought me to start comparing Sheraton Grande Tokyo Bay hotel's buffet which is quite a disappointment if you compare with Royal Park Hotel ! 2 thumbs up to Royal Park Hotel's buffet breakfast spread !! The thoughtfulness and kindness rendered by the staff in the hotel is indeed great to begin with. From the little fine gesture like placing a card beside the bed every night telling us what the weather would be the next day is very thoughtful and sweet ! The toiletries in the bathroom is almost perfect ! You could literally go to this hotel without your bathroom toiletries ...from the basic like soap, shampoo, shower cap, tooth brushes etc...They even provide hair products like hair tonic and hair moisturizing products ! The hotel staff are always helpful and their ability to communicate in English is really useful to foreigners who don't speak Japanese.Location of the hotel is great as it is just above the train station but if you have little kids who cannot walk a fair distance, by all means bring an umbrella stroller with you, get something cheap and that you won't feel the pinch even when you have to throw it away if it gives way.There are quite a good number of convenient stores just opposite the hotel main entrance as well as a supermarket just less than 5 minutes walk away. If you need some seasonal fruits there is also a fruit store just opposite the supermarket. A couple of drug stores are also near by, great place to get the Japanese made beauty products. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone who wants to have a comfortable stay and we would surely be going back to this hotel again on our next trip! Mr & Mrs N Wood and family

I have stayed there 8 nights on a business trip to Tokyo. It is a great business hotel with impeccable service and clean and spacious room (15th floor) a rarity for Tokyo... Of course it comes at a hefty price (about USD200 /night). The bar on the 20th floor has great views of the City with Tokyo Tower in the background. The hotel is located on a subway line station Z10 Suitengumae. Note that the sport facilities cost USD 30 per day...

Royal Park biggest advantage is that it is connected to the Airport Bus Terminal in Tokyo. Cabs are seriously expensive in Tokyo. The location is good too, you good go for a good walk from 10 min to an hour. In fact at the reception you shall find a suggested walk route covering certain well known landmarks of the city. For Indians there is good news as there are 2-3 restaurants serving Indian cuisine just 4-5 min away. The hotel rooms are compact and functional. They do have all amenities. The hotel staff is courteous too, I had arrived 4 hours ahead of Check in time but they suggested me to take another class of room which was available at an very reasonable extra cost. They offered access to their Business lounge on some 17th floor, where you could enjoy complimentary Drinks and Snacks.It has a well appointed Gym, which was too given complimentary with the upgraded room.

When I went to this hotel I noticed that the place and its location is top notch, service is amazing and I was amazed by the cleanliness of the staff and how helpful they actually were in everything!I loved this place with respect to the fact that this Hotel made me feel like home!

This comfortable business hotel is located right next door to the Tokyo City Air Terminal (really a bus terminal). This location means you can grab a bus to the airport, a decent meal or cup of coffee without walking far. Since my time is Tokyo is work-oriented, I like the convenience this offers. The hotel and staff are excellent. Always helpful. The rooms are fine and functional, as is the WiFi in the rooms. The subway is also conveniently close. I'll be staying there again.

Japan isn't cheap, but by Japanese standards this hotel is very good value for money. The friendliness and attentiveness of the staff is the most outstanding feature of the hotel. Rooms are comfortable, with all the facilities you need - and the air-conditioning works quietly and efficiently, unlike many other hotels. It is very conveniently located - just across the street from the air terminal with buses to/from Narita airport every 10 minutes. It also has direct access to the metro station without having to go outside.

My wife and I had a great stay at the Royal Park Hotel on what was our first visit to Tokyo. The hotel has convenient access to transport with direct links to the Tokyo subway network and also the T-CAT station for access to airports. That was good but for us the hotel facilities and staff were what made this most enjoyable and memorable (the best hotel we stayed in our four weeks in Japan - having said that it was also the most expensive we stayed in). We stayed for five nights and booked a room on the executive floor so had complimentary access to the executive lounge as well as the pool and gym which were very good. Our room was quite spacious and had everything we needed; the breakfasts were great with a good range of high quality items available at the buffet. We felt at home at the hotel quite quickly and certainly will stay again if we get back to Tokyo (and the budget allows). We have no hesititation in recommending the hotel to others.

The hotel is conveniently located to the TCAT station and connected to the Suitengumae subway station. The room is on the smaller side compared to what you will find in most US hotels. The design of the rooms are a bit on the dull side but perfectly functional and clean.The staff provides great service. Checking-in and out is quick and swift. There is a safe in the room. They have finally switched their shampoo, soap, shower gel to something more skin and hair friendly.The breakfast is great with a wide variety of western and Japanese dishes but make sure you book your room with breakfast or it will get expensive.

I'm not sure what it is about Japanese hotels? This was my first time at this hotel and was selected because it's right next door to TCAT, the Tokyo City Airport Terminal. But notwithstanding this proximity, it wasn't as straightforward as one might expect to find the hotel. Signage is sparse and they direct you out onto the street with an arrow to turn right. Once I was out there and turned right, I came to the road but still no idea where the hotel was?As it turned out, I crossed the road and after walking up and down for a few minutes, I saw the entrance to what looked like a hotel. As i approached, I asked the doorman there if this was the Royal Park Hotel and he pointed to his cap with the hotel name on it.Why is it that the hotels I've been staying in in Tokyo seem so old and in need of refurbishment? Am I not looking in the right places?I have no issue with the srvice, as with every place in Japan, even YHA's, minchuku's and ryokans, the service is always excellent! It's just the hotel rooms and decor that feel as if they're from a bygone era.They are fairly pricey too but of course, this is comparative and i'm comparing it to my last hotel in Seoul so perhaps that's an unfair comparison.When checking in, they asked if I'd like an upgraded room for an extra 6000JPY and while I was tryign to recall how much that was, I was so tired after travelling there, I accepted this. Getting to my room, it had a couple of single beds but veyr basic furniture and little space to place my suitcase but this was the same in my previous hotel in Tokyo a couple of months before.My photos will describe it better but basically, the design of the room was dated and there wasn't a lot of room, even if only for a three night stay.Breakfast was fine and the restaurant had a wide range of choices and was attractively laid out. I particularly enjoyed the grapefruit juice there and the bacon was thin and crispy.The door key was a big heavy brass key with the room number on it which in many othrer hotels, would be frowned upon as beign perceivedto be a security risk if you lost the key but I guess because they're so honest in Japan, a sense of style overcame this!The lounge on the 24th floor was OK but the tables were so close together that you could easily read the newspaper of tgeh guest sitting next to you!The staff there were friendly and helpful though as is typical of the Japanese. There are a couple of PC's next to the reception desk in the lounge and I used this to print out a document but hten had to go to the ground floor to have it scanned following signing it. Why don;t theyhave a scanner in the lounge? Good question.So maybe this hotel is pretty good for Tokyo but could definitely do with a spruce up!

Royal Park Hotel is within a quiet two minute stroll from T-CAT station which is served by Narita Limousine bus service ( http://www.limousinebus.co.jp/en/ ) The staff were very friendly and helpful and always willing to assist. We booked an executive floor room with executive lounge access. The lounge facilities were adequate with coffee, tea assorted biscuits and pastries. Our "non-smoking" room did smell of cigarette smoke on the first few nights(I am an ex smoker and have finely tuned nostrils!)and luckily the smell disappeared when we became accustomed to it?The room 1650 was a little bit worn with tea or coffee stains on the light shade, curtains and celling. No obvious air extraction from the bathroom along with staining of bathroom tiles from dampness. If the room was updated or given 1 days worth of TLC by RPH it would be fantastic.Cleaning and general tidying by the hotel staff was very good.Executive breakfast on floor 20 was a failure in my eyes. The variety of food was minimal compared to the wide range of food on ground level. The area was quite small and became crowded,I felt as if I were fighting and rushed to fill my plate. We only spent one morning eating breakfast there.There were a few restaurants on-site and they were VERY pricey, the exception to this rule was the restaurant on the ground floor (where you eat breakfast).Direct access to the hotel can be via Tokyo Metro station "Suitengumae" exit 4 which is located in the Chuo Ward of Tokyo and is served by the Tokyo Metro Hanzomon Line. The location is perfect for access to the whole of Tokyo, just buy the metro 1 or 2 day pass and go explore! The area near the hotel felt safe and we happily walked along the river bank late at night.When I next visit Tokyo I will happily stay at this hotel again. I have high expectations and this hotel came close. It may not be in the heart of Tokyo or a big name brand but it does make up for it in service and a quiet relaxed location.

As many others have said, this hotel is well located - next to the airport bus terminal, above a subway stop, near convenience stores and affordable restaurants. We started with convenience stores, moved up to the little market about a block to the right, then ventured into small restaurants with pictures in the window. We had such a good time exploring the neighborhood. Each morning, we ate at Jonathan's (turn right, go the the 1st major intersection, look left.) It's Tokyo's answer to Denny's. Then we'd catch the metro right outside the restaurant with day passes that we bought at the front desk. At the end of the day, we came back to a friendly hotel, a quiet room and a nice hot shower. Royal Park Hotel gets high marks all around.

The only reason I'm giving this hotel 4 1/2 circles is because the bed was only so-so, my room was kinda small and didn't have the most beautiful view (see pic with this review). Other than that, it was a great place. I normally stay at Marriott's so I wasn't sure what to expect. Huge, opulent lobby, several gift shops, six restaurants, right above a subway station and right next door to TCAT, so super easy to get there from Narita. Shower was GREAT and bathroom amenities were more generous and way better than average. Heating/air conditioning worked well and was QUIET!! Food was very good. True to Japanese tradition, the staff and service were incredible! I would definitely stay here again.

As mentioned more than a hundred times the location next to the TCAT station is very convenient as well as the subway station on the ground floor. The Hanzomon line takes you straight to Shibuya, no change needed!The hotel rooms are a little old but very clean and have everything you need. Even tho most rooms face a freeway you can't hear anything thanks to the double glas windows. Breakfast is ok for the price but nothing really worth mentioning. Pool is good as I heard but costs additional money which is very usual in Japan and absolutely ok with me.Only downside is that the hotel is very crowded, especially on sundays.

Adjacent to Tokyo Central Air Terminal (TCAT) makes it simple to get from Narita to the hotel (especially for first-time travelers to Tokyo). Easy access to Honzoman Subway from B2 level in the hotel. Staff service was first-rate all around. Quiet rooms and no traffic noise. Although the travel guides don't discuss the area (Ningyocho and environs) where the hotel is located we found it to be one of the most enjoyable parts of our stay; you just have to be willing to explore the area on foot.

If you're arriving from Tokyo Station, just take the cab to the hotel - it's just a 10mins ride. This hotel is not right smack in the heart of action but the fact that it sits just above Suitengumai Station which makes sightseeing in Tokyo a complete breeze. The fish market is also close by via train but for any early risers who want to grab the morning's golden ticket to view the tuna auction - please arrange for a cab (trains don't operate in the wee hours!). Best of all, the Tokyo Air Terminal is just NEXT DOOR! What's not to like? The ride comes every quarter or so very promptly and the journey to Narita Airport takes 55mins. If you have too many bags to carry, the hotel bell service is happy to assist with a trolley to the terminal waiting area. No booking required, just show up and purchase ticket right there and then (ask front desk for the bus schedules). Now, as others have reviewed, this is an older hotel but the tradeoff is the size of the room! Very generous indeed. Breakfast was filling and they served an array of fresh bread and pastries daily.

This is a big 5 star hotel right next door to the Tokyo City air terminal which makes it very convenient for commuting from and to the airport. Apart from this bonus, the hotel is quite grandiose and defenitely 5 star quality both in service and accomodation. The rooms are of good size for Japan, well equipped with amenites and other details to the exception of an infuriatingly slow water boiling machine with very complicated operating instructions! The lobby is very beautiful and the Bell Captain service works exceptionally well, all staff very pleasant and helpful. The hotel has several restaurant options to chose from, some with a set menu. Prices in this hotel are not cheap but then quality never is. The Synphony has a fabulous breakfast buffet, perfectly cooked softboiled eggs are a sure sign of excellent cooking skills! There are breakfast choices to suit any taste or preference, wether europen or oriental, excellent orange juice, and marvel of marvels , a coffee machine producing really good expresso and capucino! Wi fi is free everywhere. All together the Royal Park is an excellent choice.

This large hotel is conveniently located in Nihonbashi, next to the City Air Terminal which connects direct to Narita by bus and right above the Suitengumai subway station. I have used it for years and it is always a pleasure to stay. The staff are fantastically helpful and all who deal directly with the public speak excellent English.The rooms are reasonably large and are very comfortable, with free internet access via the TV.There are several Executive Floors, some of which permit access to the Executive Lounge, where snacks and drinks are available.Breakfast is served in a large restaurant on the ground floor and offers a huge buffet selection, but sometimes there is a queue. This restaurant also serves dinner. There is also a very nice Japanese restaurant, which looks out over a charming Japanese garden, and a Chinese restaurant in the hotel. Smoking rooms are available and smoking is also permitted in the excellent Scots Bar. In general, Japanese people are more tolerant of smokers than many other nations and it is quite common to be able to smoke in bars and restaurants, of which there are many nearby. However, many of these will not offer English.

This is my place in Tokyo. The staff makes you feel at home, everytime and in every single detail. Apart from the facilities and the location, the staff is really the key reason to come back to the same hotel everytime I come to Tokyo.

Nce hotel with large rooms for Japan. We stayed in executive level with the lounge and it was worth the. Extra to be able to relax with a drink and snack at the end of the dy of sightseeing in Tokyo. Beds very very comfy and well stocked bathroom with everything you could ever want. We ate at both the 20th floor restaurant for breakfast which was good, but the normal non executive level restaurant on the ground floor had a better variety of food for breakfast so I think this is a better option. We ate in the Japanese restaurant one night in the hotel, on 5th floor, it was okay but not outstanding, but if you are tired and dont want to travel far it is good. The hotel has a good guide to English menu restaurants near the hotel that is useful. The neighborhood around the hotel is quiet and peaceful and nice to walk aound. Metro station directly under hotel gets you pretty much anywhe you wnt to go easily. All in all it is hard to imagine how you could go wrong with this hotel. Te reason we booked it was we could walk straight from TCAT bus from Narita to the hotel in 2 minutes, which is as easy as they say!

I used to stay at this hotel for business trip. This time after so many years I stayed here with my daughter for leisure. For some reasons, we got upgraded to an executive floor (but no access to the lounge) and the room was fabulous. Royal Park Hotel has an awesome bathtub - deep and long. The location is excellent right next to TCAT (the limousine bus terminal to both Haneda and Narita). We had dinner at the restaurant nearby and there are multiple convenience stores around. The sky lounge bar was worthwhile with a great view. The service is excellent and the room is immaculately clean. I'll keep going back to this hotel.

It wouldn't be hard for me to make this a 5 star "excellent" rating, but there are just a few key things missing. You can't announce yourself as a 5 Star accomodation, charge that kind of room rate, and then ask for 2000-2500 Yen each time to use the pool, or the work out area. And that's a price for either/or. Not a price to use both!! And then if you wish to use the little sachet of coffee or tea next to the hot water kettle in your room, that 281 Yen.If you want to be a nickle and dime hotel, then go ahead, but to fix these issues, that seem to be the only negative about this place, would be very easy.Aside from those annoyances, I have nothing negative to say about the hotel. It's in a great location, the breakfasts are amazing, room clean... It's a really nice place to stay. Fix the "cheap" image you give yourself with the Pool, the Gym, and the little extras. Cheers, sleep well!

I have now stayed at the Royal Park Hotel, on more than a several occasions. I would have to say without doubt, it is one of my favourite hotel's globally. Service is always excellent, the older style decor works, the rooms are spacious by Tokyo standards, and the proximity to the T-CAT makes it exceptionally convenient for air travel. I had customers with me, who will now use the hotel when they travel to Tokyo.

I travel extensively and I have never before been asked to pay extra to use the gym.I'm trying to keep fit so I went to the Gym early in the morning and was told I need to pay 20USD just to step inside, hand over my key, fill in a form etc....And the breakfast is not as good as reported by others. It's OK but it's not thst special. Ridiculous.
user_location: Ho Chi Minh City, null, Vietnam
user_name:
Clifford J
Ho Chi Minh City, null, Vietnam

review_body: Just returned from a 5 night stay at Royal Park Hotel. The location was perfect for me - directly across from the train station. When I arrived, they gave me a 'gift' for women only. I was pleased to open it and find Shiseido bath and facial products which I now love! The room size is a normal size for Americans, but large for Japan. So, if you're traveling from the US, this is the hotel I'd recommend. The staff was very friendly and helped us with all our local needs. Highly recommended.

This is a good Hotel in Tokyo. Service is good and you find lots of English speaking personnel in the hotel that can assist you. Breakfast is top of the line, one of the best I've tried. Good quality ingredients used. Having a snack or high tea is very expensive though. Overall is an expensive hotel but the service is great and the rooms are decently sized for Tokyo. Room has blackout curtains that doesn't seem to be the norm in all Tokyo hotels. Great to help with the Jet Lag. Location right by the TCAT if a plus.

I have stayed at the Royal Park many times over the years. It's an elegant hotel located right across the street from the TCAT station, making it easy to get to from the Narita airport. There's even a covered walkway on the 2nd floor if you arrive in bad weather. There are lots of fantastic (but really expensive) restaurants in the hotel. A good (but small) gym and spa. There's also a metro stop in the basement- I LOVE that.Right across the street is a 7-11 and in the TCAT building is a McDonalds so if you have kids or just want a quick cheap "something" you can get it quickly and easily. There are also numerous little restaurants in the area for a food at all price levels. For alittle fun right across the hotel down an alley is one called Texas-that plays old OLD western songs but doesn't seem to serve any Texan food. You can even walk to the button museum or a 100Y store which always is good for fun souvenirs.

This hotel is great because- conveniently located right near from Tokyo City Air Terminal. Very easy to go to the airport by bus- fantastic swimming pool, opens from 06:30, clean and big (I think 20m length which is great for a hotel in Tokyo)- nice room amenity. They gave me a little skin-care set, including Shiseido make up remover, face wash lotion etc. I loved this- beautiful Tokyo panorama view from the top floor breakfast placeThe hotel is probably not that new, and has a little bit of 'dated' style.But everything worked decently

Just come back from a 3 day stay in Tokyo with the family. Prior to going, I spent days looking for the most suitable location, quality of hotel and size of rooms (3 kids + 2 adults). The Royal Park fitted the bill very well. Firstly the rooms are of a good size - I would describe them as "normal hotel room size" which apparently for Tokyo is big. They were very well equipped and meticulously clean. Secondly, the location is great - right above TCAT and train line so going out for the day was pretty easy and getting back to Narita even easier!- although the distances to get to some attractions were quite a jaunt. We were on the executive floors which was a good option as breakfast could be taken on the 20th floor (lovely quality food!) for great views. Also drinks and snacks included. In terms of pricing I checked all the main hotel websites (agoda, hotel.com, expedia etc) but found the best deal by far to be on the actual hotel website!. Great choice and very pleased with it!

Royal Park is an amazing hotel. It's like a little slice of heaven in a hectic city. I stay there every time I come to Tokyo. All of restaurants are superb, and the staff is outstanding. I even like the quirky metal skelleton keys for the rooms. The room and bedding is sumptous, and very spacious. Highly recommend the executive floors if you can swing it.

Great location, close to transport, but then again, what isn't in Japan. Really good staff, very quiet and comfortable hotel and executive floors and facilities were great. Excellent venue for business. Breakfast was very enjoyable too.

love the location. puts you right in the Ningyo-cho district. Great food and local shopping. Take a walk to visit the seven luck shrines of Nihonbashi. Easy transportation from NRT airport to the Tokyo City Air Terminal

Have stayed many times at the Royal Park Hotel, and every time I am met with a smiling face in the reception. The hospitality is great and beds are very nice. Some rooms are though a bit "tired" however still good value for money. Especially I love the breakfast at the 20th floor, where you can sit and enjoy a nice breakfast with a perfect view of the city

Posh hotel thus expensivePROS-------Located literally over a metro station. Time from room to metro < 3 minTaxi rank outside the hotelHuge selection of restaurants within 5 min walk max5-6 restaurants in the hotelNice breakfast quality and selection (although not the best I've had). You can also have sushi-style breakfastStaff can speak great englishStaff has great mannersStaff very helpful with all kinds of requests (even for an umbrella!)Very well lit and safe area to walk inRoom huge for japanese standards, equal to a Marriott or Intercontinental roomAll kinds of amenities in the room (several pillows, free wifi, complimentary toiletry)4 lifts so you never wait for more than a couple of minutes, even in busy hoursFree drinks and snacks for executive room guests for several hours each day (on the 16th floor lobby)Great view from executive guests breakfast area (19th floor I think)ATMs in the main lobbyBus station from/to Narita airport opposite the hotelCONS-------Hotel can get very busy, so twice I was told that there is no free seat for breakfast and that I had to wait. It was on New Year's Eve and New Year's day. I know, busy period, but still unacceptable

The hotel is a perfect choice for travellers as it is situated near TCAT (direct bus service from Narita) and Suitengumae station. Rooms are spacious and clean. Staff is very nice and extremely helpful but u might face some problem communicating in English. Breakfast is wonderful. I enjoyed my stay and look forward to going there again.

Location is great near bus station for Airport but room price is a way too high For this price you would expect to get more but every thing cost more- GYM / POOL / SAUNA / Breakfest - each cost more ~ 2.5K yen extra- In the lobby you have nice coffee shop and resturants but if you want just to sit taliking to someone only 4 arm chairs and 2 sofa (total max 6-7 ppl. can be sitted in Lobby and not in one of the coffee shop or resturant (and in the coffee shop even a Jappnise firend told me the price of the coffee is exaggerated - but since I paiy he didn't mind).Sum all the above -> you can get much better deal in the same area.

Great location and comfortable for business travelers. This was my second trip to Tokyo and it is on my list of top / best places to work / visit. I highly recommend the executive floor. One urgent consideration for Royal Park is to expand food choices with lower prices. The cost of dining in the hotel is prohibitive; it is extremely expensive and the value is not commensurate with what is charged. This would enhance all this fine hotel has to offer. Breakfast is wonderful so keep that up!

Executive floor was all well organised with Japanese hospitality, parfect choise for business and private travelors from abroad, excellent access to T-CAT (bus station attached to the hotel where frequent services are available from /to Narita airport). Non smoking Queen Bed room was spacious enough with clean, also enjoyed Japanese style bath room at Spa. Breakfast restaurant at 20th floor gave us a good western style of food with view. Hakozaki (where the hotel locates) is not in the city centre but instead has a quiet down town (shita-machi) atmosphere. In fact it had easier access to Ginza, Tsukiji, Asaksa and most of other polular places by Tokyo Metro. Myself (Japanese) and my colleague (non Japanese) both appreciated lots of hospitalities during the stay.

1. right next to TCAT (Tokyo City Airport Terminal: place where the airport limo arrives and departs) so very convenient, plus there is an underground station right below it. 10-15 mins taxi drive from most locations in central Tokyo.. you cant go wrong for its location.having said that, there are other things i'd like to dwell upon:2. Service: Excellent, (pricey ...but still excellent) ask for anything and you get it, for the 3 nights that i stayed there I had a very good experience.3. Old hotel: not been renovated since a long time, its shows its dated nature.. I am not complaining, just setting your expectations right, so that you are not disappointed when you check in.4. Executive Lounge: free snacks, drinks.. its all charged in your room rate, but its a nice warm fuzzy cozy feeling up there in the executive lounge.5. decent choice of restaurants near by: ask the bell desk for help on eating out nearby.6. Breakfast: 20th floor has a nice view but limited breakfast options: Symphony on level 1 serves a wider spread for breakfast and is more comfortable and recommended for flexible timing and a bigger spread.

We stayed in the Royal Park Hotel in November of 2012. It's a very nice hotel, centrally located and close to the subway system. We booked a room on the 16th floor, which is the club level and it did not disappoint. The happy hour food and drink was awesome. Great food, a great selection of drinks and very pleasant service. We booked several excursions and all went well, except you need to make sure that they return you to the hotel when the tour is completed. One of our excursions did not bring us back to the hotel, but we enjoyed finding our way back on the subway system. We enjoyed the breakfast in the hotel everyday. A very nice buffet on the lobby level as well as the top floor. The food in the lobby was better, but the view from the 20th floor was worth the effort. You can not go wrong with this very nice hotel in central Tokyo, Japan.

I am a regular visitor to the Royal Park and have found it a very comfortable hotel for extended business stays. Rooms are always clean, service is very polite and the hotel offers many restaurants if you are unsure about venturing out on the town! (You really should--lots of great 'local' places to visit nearby.) I prefer the executive floors so you get free wifi as well as access to the top floor breakfast buffet each day (it is a little more cozy/quiet than going to the main restaurant downstairs for breakfast). I will say, however, that while the service and food are very good I do think it has been scaled back 'just a bit' over the past few years--fewer buffet choices, a bit less fruit etc. Still though a very nice place to have breakfast, I've just been spoiled in the past.Be sure to take a stroll down to the Sumida River (less than five minutes) and enjoy the walk there, especially if the cherry blossoms are out in force!TCAT is just across the street (take the elevated walkway from the second floor) and very convenient for travel to/from Narita/Haneda airports.Great place to say, you will enjoy it.

Many times, I stayed in this Hotel and you start knowing all the details and you recognize the staff. it is very well located, 2 minutes walking from the TCAT (direct Bus from Narita Airport into Tokyo). Being so far way from home it is important the feeling as being at home. My trips to Tokyo are all about business and coming back from the meetings in the evening you do not even need to eat out, since the offer of restaurants, the diversity and quality in the Hotel is very good. It is a pleasure to stay here.

excellent location,wonderful restaurants and staff with a helpful and genuine smile.Being attached to the TCAT makes the journey to and from the hotel so easy. Will definitely return here whenever in Tokyo

The Royal Park Hotel is next door to the TCAT limousine bus station and has direct bus links to both Haneda and Narita airport which makes it extremely convenient for overseas business travellers. It is also directly above a Metro station. Within 5 mintes walk is the Sumida river with good walks in both directions along the river bank if you want to escape the crowds of the city. I have stayed here many times over the past few years and the hotel has continued to upgrade its rooms and amenities to ensure that it always feels fresh and new. There is complimentary wi-fi available throughout the hotel. The buffet breakfast choice is good.

I have been using this hotel for over 20 years, and since I stay at least 4 times a year, I am guaranteed a warm welcome.Unlike many Tokyo hotels, the Royal park is small enough to feel cosy, though has a wide range of restaurants and bars.The rooms, particularly on the executive floors are fine for a weeks stay, and the bathrooms have large baths, and even a neck pillow - a first in any hotel I have stayed in.The Executive floor is worth the extra, as you get Breakfast, use of the lounge all day for coffee and snacks and in the eveniing 3 hours of drinking !!! Also included is Wifi and use of the Gym and pool.The pool in particular, is a wonderful way to release the stresses of business travel. After a water workout, the sauna and plunge bath are not to be missed.

My wife and I stayed at the Royal Park for six weeks on business in October and November 2012. We had a fantastic stay at this wonderful hotel. The staff at the hotel were the amazing and the best I have come across anywhere in the world. Without exception they were always friendly, courtesy and helpful. A special mention must go to the ladies in the Executive floor who were so helpful and genuinely warm and friendly to us. I would strongly recommend anyone staying at the Royal Park to upgrade to an Executive room so as to have breakfast, use of the spa and Executive lounge included. The breakfasts were excellent, both on the ground floor and 20th. We ate at the hotel's Chinese and Teppanyaki restaurants. The Chinese was good and the Teppanyaki excellent. The Orpheus Sky Lounge is a great place to unwind over a cocktail and enjoy the fantastic views. The location of the hotel is good, with plenty of excellent and varied restaurants within a five to ten minute stroll. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.

The location of the hotel is very vonvenient because it s very close to the TCAT, directly connected to the Metro and also centrally located in Tokyo. At my arrival I was told that I had been upgraded to benefit from the facilities of the business lounge, incl.complimentaryuse of the spa (ppol, sauna, gym). I made frequent use of this wonderfulk opportunity. offer. The room itself (1526) was a bit small compared to other hotels of this category. (i.e. Hilton, Imperial, etc.) The room service was fine and never disturbing. I can recommend the Royal Park Hotel to other visitors without any limitations.

Stayed here for 2 nights. This hotel can be pricey, but you could find good discounted rates online. Conveniently located next to TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal), which gives you access to Haneda or Narita using the Limo bus service. The Hotel is located above the Tokyo Metro Suitengumae station, so makes it so convenient to take the subway. Mitsukoshi Dept Store is located just one station away.Concierge staff is very helpful in planning travel and your way around Tokyo using the subway. They are also helpful assisting you planning your trip to the airport just going across the street to the T CAT. Tip, have cash to buy your ticket at Limo bus to either Haneda or Narita. I do not think this Limo bus station takes credit cards. Rooms are Ok, but are well overdue for a refurbish or remodel. Still clean and decent, but show aging. Size is small, but probably what you expect in Tokyo small size rooms. TV selection is poor for westerner. One great thing is that they have a bank Seven (Seven Eleven) ATM. Your overseas ATM card will work there. Japanese banks ATMs do not work with overseas cards. You can only make your overseas cards work at seven eleven stores, postal office ATMs, and I was told Chase bank, but I did not try it.Overall all personal is friendly, polite, courteous, and helpful, accommodating your needs, like you would find of any Japanese. The only one that might not be as friendly is the only Western lady that works there, but she does not do a bad job either. Restaurants are nice, Gym is really good as well as pool. Street were hotel is locates seems safe and there are a couple of convenience stores, which makes it easy to buy snacks. There is a Mc Donalds across the street on the T CAT station.Breakfast buffet is decent not really extraordinary not bad either. It has both Western and Japanese options. Stick with the Omelet station which is the best feature of this breakfast buffet. The rest is OK, not memorable.Location is great for business. Maybe for a vacation, but if for a vacation trip, I would stay on the Ginza or Roppongi area. There are some not so pricey decent boutiques hotel that would be also a good choice

The hotel is excellent. Very luxury, very posh.A very good selection of different restaurants.Everything is very clean, very good service !The staff is helpfull with good English skills.The direct connection to the TCAT is very convenient.

My business associate and I needed 2 last minute rooms while we were in Tokyo the first week of October and we walked in and the assistant manager took care of us right away...even set us up with a great rate. Hotels (or anywhere for that matter) with wifi are very few and far between in Tokyo. RP has it complimentary. Breakfast buffet is always wonderful and I always love how easy it is to jump on the train from below the hotel. If you want to walk to Ningyo-cho station it's about 5 minutes but as long as you know where you are going, catching the train from below the hotel, Suitengu, is nothing short of awesome. Thanks again, Royal Park.

Stayed at this hotel many, many times over the past 20 years and never regretted it. perhaps the greatest feature is its location as it is on the edge of Tokyo closest to Narita and Haneda Airports and connected to the Tokyo City Air Terminal. This means no traffic coming in or going out on the Limousine Bus.Recently upgraded many of the rooms. Workout facility never crowded and one of the best indoor pools in Tokyo.Subway into city accessed via elevator underground.

Convenient location, good service, helpful staff, clean rooms. Stayed for 9 days, would be good if breakfast buffet spread could be varied instead of serving same daily. The first hotel I stayed in that charges for gym usage, and don't provide complimentary bottled water.

I have stayed at this hotel twice this past week. First time I was given a lovely room with nice outlook. Services both time were impeccable The thing to watch is when you check in is they try to sell you additional packages. In all my travels I have never had to pay to use a hotel gym. Seems to be a Japanese thing.I paid 4000 yen for club access, late check out and breakfast.On my first stay earlier this week after I had to wait 45 minutes for breakfast entry so finally gave up and went down the road for a delicious local breakfast of 160yen.This is my second stay this week after a side trip to osaka and once again paid the 4000 yen.Tonight I couldn't find a seat at the club lounge which is part of the package as there seemed to be big groups of people taking all the chairs leaving none for the long traveller. Basically I was told to come back later......not sure how much later as it is only had an hour to run Now I just rang reception to confirm my 3pm check out to be told I couldn't have it as my room is booked and I have to be out by midday !So beware of the up sell where they don't deliver

We had 3 nights on the Exec Floor which included breakfast. Room was a good size, including a desk, chair and footstool. Check in for the Exec floors was on the 16th floor where you got to sit down and refresh with a cold washer (cloth/flannel depending what you call it). Could also purchase metro passes, one or two days from here too, which surprisingly were cheaper than you could get them from the metro itself. Best way to move around city.We arrived by metro to Suitegumae Station, walked to exit 4 and there was the entrance (side entrance) to the hotel. Breakfast each morning was on the 20th floor with a great view of the city and a great range of foods to choose from. Staff were very courteous and spoke English all the time.The train line we came in continued onto the Tokyo Skytree so very handy.Ate at the Chinese restaurant on the ground floor, beautiful food but quite pricey. There were coupons we could us at certain restaurants in the hotel but they all included fish which we dont eat.Used the gym once. It opened at 6am which is a bit late since breakfast finishes with last orders 8:30am. Small exercise area but huge stretching room.

The hotel is very well located, in particular its adjacent to the Tokyo City Air Terminal making connections to the airport via bus very easy. The overall feel of the hotel is one of quiet luxury, all the staff is very accommodating and gracious. The rooms themselves are 'OK', they are not large, but well laid out. Soundproofing is excellent. The decor is, however, dated and starting to feel a bit run down. The gym and restaurants are great.

I stay at this hotel a few times a year and the service is always great. It's right next to the TCAT terminal, so access to the airports and city subway is great. The rooms and facilities are dated, but very clean. I hope they have plans to renovate the hotel to match the level of service they provide.

Firstly, easy to get to from Narita airport as the airport coach goes straight into the air terminal bus station over the road. Don't take a cab into town...it costs way too much. The coach to the city air terminal was perfect. The local area around the hotel has temples, stalls, and little eateries for lunch...a short metro ride gets you everywhere else...and the metro is in Japanese and English, and the staff are super-helpful. Also this hotel is literally on top of a metro stop. The hotel is a classical, grand, old style business hotel. We stayed on the executive floor, so the bedrooms were pretty big (mini suites), with lots of extras thrown in for free. Wifi and water in the room is complimentary but why the tea, coffee and mini bar cost when I can wander down to the executive lounge and get them for free is beyond me! Free drinks at 5-8 pm allows for a G&T before going out for dinner, and the views from the top are great. Breakfast is also free on the exec floor but pricey if you're in a regular room. We ate Tapanake on the 20th the first night (great views as the chef prepares the food), and went out for dinner the rest of the time. As a 5 star, business hotel this place cannot be faulted. It is classical/old fashioned in styling, so don't expect super modern furnishings. But it has all the extras you would expect.

The rooms were spacious, immaculate and well-appointed (I must get a five-spray shower like the one we had here). Service was top-flight, and the breakfast was sumptuous, with a wide range of Asian and Western dishes. The location is connected by underground to a transit/retail plaza -- very convenient.The only reason I'm not giving it five stars is that my iPhone charger apparently was stolen from my luggage during the few hours we checked it before our departure. The desk clerk asked when we checked it to be sure we'd removed our passports and valuables. But I hadn't counted on anyone stealing a $40 charger. And I didn't discover the loss until we were far, far from Tokyo's Apple store.In short, enjoy this lovely hotel, but lock up your necessities, regardless of value.

We had the pleasure of staying at the Royal Park Hotel 2 weeks ago, for 4 nights. The hotel is quite large, but the staff goes to every effort to make you feel as if you are staying at your grandmother's house! The rooms are spotlessly clean, have a seperate area for sitting in a circular window area that could seat 4 people comfortably, bathroom amenities are amazing. The location is perfect for all subway lines and the buses, since TCAT is right next door. There are a number of restaurants in the area as well as the several that they have at the hotel. The exchange rate at the front desk is just as good as the banks, which is very convenient also. I would recommend this hotel to anyone that really needs the convience of getting around quickly via the subway stystem. A lot of business people were there, so you know it's a good hotel. The subways, by the way, are really,really easy to navigate and are spotless and safe. All of Japan is very safe!!

I stayed at Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo for 2 weeks in September 2012. Its a wonderful hotel with lots of great touches and features that make it excellent. Location is perfect for airport transfer using the TCAT terminal next door. For local travel there is a subway line in the basement and other subway lines a few blocks away. Wifi is free. Rooms are nice and the bathroom features are great. Besides the usual shampoo/soap, they also give you a hair brush, nail cutter, scissors and a "Men's kit" containing after shave, hair tonic and a "hair liquid" (not sure what that is). Service is outstanding. View is great. Breakfast at the lobby level was really good with a great buffet of Japanese-style and Western breakfast choices. At the top floor, the breakfast was Western style only. I strongly recommend you upgrade to the Executive Floors which gives you access to unlimited alcoholic drinks (champagne, wine, whiskey, vodka, etc.) + snacks every evening from 6-8pm on the 16th floor Executive Lounge. In addition, you also have access to beverages/tea/snacks all day at the Lounge. Also, you have free access to their world-class fitness room which includes an indoor pool, gym and hot tub. With great amenities, service, and location, the Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo is really awesome! Definitely going back!

I have stayed at this hotel before a few years ago when I nneded to be close to Ohtemachi. With TCAT next door, travel from airport to hotel is a breeze. Good restaurants and very good classic Japanese service. Highly recommend this hotel and look forward to my 9/19/12 to 9/22/12 stay.

That's a wonderful place in the heart of Tokyo. Great rooms, free internet and wifi around the hotel, direct access to underground, perfect sound isolation. Very good breakfast, nice restaurants. Wonderful toiletries, very helpful staff... Did I miss something? I really enjoyed three days there.

This is my hotel of choice when on business in Tokyo. Right next door to the TCAT means travel to and from the airport is a breeze. Rooms well appointed and exec floor lounge very good. Staff helpful and efficient. Prices are typical of the upper end for Tokyo which is never cheap. Easy walking distance to a number of restaurants catering for most tastes, I have walked to the Imperial Palace from here but it was a looong way. Breakfast i have only taken on the upper floors, which was always quick and tasty, although doesnt start in time for those really early morning flight transfers. Been in three earthquakes whilst staying here over the years so can vouch for the fact its well built! Only two downsides ever encountered was if you arrive early morning from the airport quite often no rooms will be free, and you will have to wait a few hours, hotel does its best but it can be a pain. Also they stopped putting the really nice bath soap in the plastic boxes into the rooms, wife was always very keen on those. Overall convenient and nice hotel, i like it.

I really enjoyed staying at this hotel. They have a swimming pool on the 5th floor that can be used by all guests which we thoroughly enjoyed. There's also the option to get massages, your nails done, your hair and make up done and to have a wedding here. The rooms are large, clean and decorated in the timeless 'expensive hotel' style (not modern, though). The staff are friendly and very helpful. Best of all was the free loan laptop we got to use. Most other hotels charge you for that. The hotel also as a few restaurants, but we did not try any of them. There is also a peaceful tea garden.The location of the hotel is good; in the basement is the Suitengumae subway station, from where you can take the train to, among other places, Shibuya. Very close is the Ningyouchou station, from where you can go to Ginza and Ueno/Asakusa. The neighbourhood is very nice, there's plenty of places to eat, sing karaoke or have some good food. Nearby is Amazaka Yokocho, a street with lots of traditional shops.

I stayed here for a week while on a business trip to Japan , its a really nice very Japanese styled hotel.Little different that typical 5 star hotels like Hyatt or Hilton , but I loved it. Its a little expensive The staff here is really friendly and helpful , would love to stay here againReally good location good connectivity form Narita \ Henada Airport , there is a substation right next to it.

we travelled to Tokyo for the first time... imust say its a great city. it is so well managed. we stayed at the royal park hotel.it is a very nice place. the area of the hotel is huge, the rooms are nice and spacious. the staff is good and very helpful. the food too is nice.we had a pleasant stay in royal park hotel. all the attractions of the city are near so we didnt have to travel too much. everything was in the vicinity.we enjoyed everything and had a lovely time

This hotel is a real 5 star hotel, amazingly friendly staff, perfect rooms, very nice restaurants and bars. Happy hour in bar in basement recommended. Breakfast is very expensive, but in one of the nice restaurants in the hotel and from very good quality. If you enjoy a good long breakfast then you will enjoy. Hotel is directly connected to airport via bus calle 'Airport Limousine', remember to buy directly a retourn ticket to save 20%. Underground is directly accessible, so even for tourists the hotel is not bad located. If you expect to stay mkre often then ask for the loyalty program, it is not so well anniunced but is a well structured program.

The Royal Park is a very good hotel, the only reason I do not give it 5 stars was the bed, I like a firm mattress, however this was like sleeping on a rock. That being said the rest of my stay was enjoyable. The room was super clean. The bathroom was large and clean, it had booth a separate shower and tub. The room was well maintained. The staff is super friendly and was always there to help. The restaurant is top notch, serving both Japanese and western dishes. It is located close to the Tokyo city airport terminal so transportation is easy to pick up. I would recommend this hotel to anyone that is visiting Tokyo.

I stay there for 2 days on a business trip. Besides the fact that I was greeted with a 5.3 earthquake (and its inevitable replicas at night that wake you up...) , I found the overall experience very pleasant. THe lobby is nice and spaceful, very well connected (directly to the metro station). All the staff on the lobby floor is excellent and so friendly and respectful. Elevators are spaceful. But then they are not an indication of the room size, which is of course tiny! but manicurely well kept. Beds is very good although small and A/C is quiet. I noted bathroom amenities which were plentiful. Breakfast and dinner were excellent . Surroundings are quiet and nearby there is an important temple to visit.Excellent connection to transportation and Narita airport via the bus terminal on the other side of the street.I wish I could have stayed longer so I could see the spring festivities which are beautiful ... next time!

i stayed at the Royal Park with my family at the end of may 2012 and it was such a great experience. located in a quieter neighbourhood then say Shibuya it is a treat to leave behind the busy city centre and catch a quick subway ride to the hotel. the service at the hotel is amazing and the staff are extremely helpful, especially the guest relations manager. the location may seem far from the the city centre but its not at all..and the convenience of the subway beneath the hotel is amazing! would definitely stay here again.

I was pleasantly surprised by this hotel. The rooms and baths are reasonably sized and well equipped, and the service was excellent. (I was on one of the executive floors, and had the 16th floor lounge and check-in area availble to me.) Breakfasts were included and I took mine in the 20th floor restaurant Orpheus, and it had everything I wanted. The other restaurants in the hotel were all very good. (The sushi restaurant, while good, turned out to be a little expensive, but I would go back.)One of the best things about this hotel is that is is steps from the Tokyo City Air Terminal, which is a bus terminal with direct bus service to Narita for 2900 Yen (about $40). Better than the Narita train which arrives at Tokyo station and unless you are staying in a hotel right near the station you must take a taxi from there to your hotel. Also, this hotel connects to one of the Tokyo subway lines on the B2 level, so you can take the elevator to the subway. Don't be afraid of the subway. Once you learn how to buy a ticket, the rest of a piece of cake. The signs are in English, the lines are organized by letter and the stops by number so it's easy to follow where you are and where you need to go. All in all this is a very good hotel in Tokyo. I would go back in a heartbeat.

I stayed at the Royal Park for two weeks on business and was very happy with the experience. My room was utterly spotless and the staff went out of their way to be helpful. The hotel itself is located in a safe, quiet neighbourhood and is well connected by transport: basement level 2 (B2) is directly connected to a metro station and next door is the "Tokyo City Air Terminal" - a bus depot with a regular (and reasonably priced) service to both Narita and Haneda airports. If you book an executive room you may be given the choice of having breakfast up in the executive bar on level 20, or on level 1 with the other hotel guests. The view on level 20 is excellent, however the food (both quantity and variety) is far better on level 1. The only negative things about this hotel are: there are very few restaurants or attractions within walking distance of the hotel, and some of the restaurants in the hotel itself are very expensive. For example, a colleague and I had dinner in the hotel's sushi restaurant and 10 pieces of sushi cost us US$60! It was good sushi, but still a bit expensive. I will be more than happy to stay here again when I am next in Tokyo for business; but if I was going to Tokyo as a tourist I would likely stay somewhere a bit cheaper and closer to the attractions.

We stayed 4 nights (May 17-21.2012) at Royal Park Hotel in Nihombashi area where the neighborhood is very nice and surrounded by several temples and shrines (just an hour walking) and not to forget the convenience of getting the TCAT limousine bus to Narita or Haneda Airport. There is a linked brigde to go directly to the TCAT bus station. The room is spacious, clean and with a lot of amenity and bed is excellent. This hotel is still using an old fashion big key instead of a card key to enter the room. Besides, it is also offering a Tokyo Metro pass at an attractive price (Yen 980 / pp for 2 unlimited days, normal Yen 710 / pp for 1 day) and close by to go for shopping areas like Nihombashi (1 stop) or Ginza ( 2 stops). It is a very convenience to take the metro as there is a direct linked from the hotel to Suitengumae Metro station. Unfortunately. WIFI internet is not free and too expensive (Yen 1260 for one device only, or need to purchase a WIFI card Yen 1260 for usage of other device) and even not free at the lobby area, so hotel need to anticipate current trend that people is having a smartphone and tablet when travelling.Nevertheless, this hotel offers a good value for staying at a nice neighborhood.
user_name:
Budi_KN
Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan, Malaysia

review_body: Stayed here for about a week. It's a nice clean hotel and close to the air terminal. Hotel staffs were friendly and even help to haul our many family lauggages to the terminal to catch a bus to the airport. Sushi restaurant is wonderful to have a meal with family and the pub is a great place to make arrange meeting old friend in Tokyo.We did enjoy our stay.

I just got back from a business trip to Tokyo after having spent a week at the Royal Park Hotel. I stayed in an Executive level room on the 17th floor and really appreciated the ammenities that come with that level room. The free WiFi was very reliable and fast. The included free breakfast up on the 20th floor was very nice with quality food, friendly service and great views of the city. My room was very spacious with a queen size bed, comfortable chair, large desk, mini-fridge, flat screen TV, closet, dressing area and full size bathroom. The list price for the room is on the high side but I got a discount rate I found online that was cheaper than a standard (non-executive) room! From the moment you enter the lobby, hotel staff is there to greet you and assist you with checking in as well as many other services they offer. Those checking into an executive floor room have their own reception area on the 16th floor as well. The entire hotel is very clean and upscale. There are several restaurants on site as well as several stores of various kinds. There is also a super convenient subway station below the hotel and a bus station (TCAT) just across the street which is attached to the hotel via a covered walkway over the street. The Airport Limosine bus service to and from Narita airport and the hotel is a great economical way to travel.....especially with luggage which can be more difficult on a train. Overall, there is very little I can think of that I could want in a hotel here that wasn't provided or available here. A top notch place!

I went to Tokyo almost every year for business meetings and visits. A couple of years back, I experiencedë to stay at Royal Park Hotel in 2008, 2009 and 2011.It was a luxurious hotel next to Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT). For easy access from Narita or Haneda airport, you might want to try the Airport Limousine Bus. It was a different experience using the limo bus, you'll feel closer to the city compared to the train service from airport to the hotel. To move around the Tokyo City is not an issue, Suitengumae Station (Hanzomon line) is just at the basement if Royal Park. But don't forget to purchase one or two days subway ticket a, you'll find it easier and cheaper to use the subways. A friend of mine said "As long as you have access to Tokyo subways, you won't die", hahaha..I stayed at a same room twice during my visit there. Maybe they have historical data of my previous stay, so they want me to experience the same as before. The room was spacious, the bed was very comfortable, internet services provided, the staff were friendly. Though the communication was bad, the staff tried to assist me as much as he could. I like the room very much, since I paid ¥27,000 for a night, certainly it should be a good room, it was never cheap to stay in Japan.Royal Park serves local and western food for breakfast. Not sure about lunch or dinner as we were enjoying our visits elsewhere. :)

My family had a wonderful stay at Royal Park Hotel! We were there during Golden Week the first part of May. The View was great from our room, easy access from the train, in the basement from the hotel. Also, We signed up for the Tokyo Cycle Tour and it is just blocks away from Royal Park. A wonderful, restful visit!

I have stayed at the Royal Park for many years on trips to Tokyo. It has always exceeded my expectations in terms or comfort, quiet and excellent service. The location across from TCAT makes for easy access from Narita and convenient access to the subway. The hotel has some of the best sushi and tepenyaki offerings for a Tokyo otel. Highly recommended

The past requested materials like pillow, pajama, etc are ready when you enter the room after check-in.It is very convenient and wonderful to have breakfast at the 21st floor and delayed check-out for the flight in the afternoon.

The rooms are on the expensive side and actually not really worth it, but I had such a good stay. Rooms clean, tidy and spacious with good beds. Shame about the expensive wifi but hey, it is a chance to get away from all that. Free newspapers in the morning add to that little extra, and tthe breakfast buffet is just scrumptious. Well located next to the Narita Limouisine bus so that is also an extra plus, with the underground station just underneath the hotel. Brilliant. Reception incredibly helpful and nice. And the lounge bar on the top floor is not that expensive as initially thought with great views over Tokyo. Negatives are that all other things costs extra if you are not staying in executive suites, so besides wifi, the fitness center and pool have entrance fees and add to the already expensive rooms. A bit annoying.

The Royal Park Hotel may not be the newest or cheapest hotel in Tokyo but this is the 3rd time I've stayed and it never lets me down. The staff are excellent as are the rooms and the breakfast. It's right next to the bus station for the Narita Limosine Bus, and the Metro.On this occasion I had laundry done and the service was excellent and reasonably priced. There a also myriad bars and restaurants within a short walk. Highly recommended.

This is located in the vicinity of our Tokyo offices, so I have been there many times already. This is clearly my favorite because of the fitness facilities , the spa and the huge swimming pool. The rooms a great although there is a distinct smell of something sweat like... Maybe because of the detergent they are using, nevertheless the service minded staff will promptly arrange an alternative room if this is an issue.

This was my second visit to the Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo. The staff is extremely accommodating and polite -- true to the culture of Japan. The breakfast buffet is outstanding, offering something for everyone's palate. The location is extremely convenient to TCAT Terminal from Narita -- literally across the street, which made arrival and departure a breeze. There are some nice restaurants all within walking distance if you are not up for a taxi or subway ride to other parts of town. If you need to, the subway station is also right there! I would like to extend a personal THANK YOU to the staff for the superb job they ALL do! Look forward to visiting again.

This hotel was so much more than we ever expected. We were treated like royalty by the staff from the minute we walked in the door until the minute we left. Everyone was so gracious, pleasant and overly accommodating.We had read on Trip Advisor about the proximity of this hotel to transportation. This was paramount for us because we wanted to see several parts of Tokyo. So knowing that there was a subway underneath the building and a couple other subway lines 2-3 blocks away, we were just where we wanted to be...5 - 10 minutes from everything.
