We considered staying in the Roppongi area, but after we visited Roppongi, we were glad that we chose our hotel, and stayed where we were! Roppongi was very touristy - nice to visit for dinner or for the day, but we preferred where we stayed at the Royal Park, which was 10 minutes from Roppongi and 5 minutes from Ginza, the hot shopping area! TCAT is the bus terminal. From Narita Airport, we took the Airport Limosine Bus just one stop to TCAT. Royal Park was next door. We hopped off the bus, and there was a telephone in the lobby of the bus station for Royal Park Hotel. We picked up the phone which rang the hotel, and within a few seconds, a porter/bellman was running over with a cart to get our bags. We didn't know how close we were, because we could have walked over on our own, but it was a nice way to welcome us.After we entered the hotel, we were seated at the Woman's Traveler Desk. I guess it's to assist female travelers? I don't know, but we were greeted by a wonderful woman who assisted us and checked us in to our beautiful room.Typically, I don't eat in hotels. I like to be fully immersed in the area I'm visiting, so I eat elsewhere, but the night we checked in, we were exhausted after a 12 hour flight, and headed upstairs to one of the 6 restaurants in the hotel. We went to the one where the chef prepared the meal in front of us. It was phenomenal, and a great view of the city from the 20th floor. Outside the hotel, we found several quaint restaurants where we had terrific sushi, noodles and rice.To us, this place was perfect in every way. We felt comfortable, and welcomed. Our room was beautiful and the staff was amazing. The location was superb because we could be anywhere in Tokyo that we needed to be, within minutes. For those who want options, this is where you need to be!This hotel is great for friends exploring Tokyo, and also would be great for business travelers, especially women who are traveling alone. We felt completely safe in the neighborhood surrounding this hotel.

Sign up for the I Prefer frequent traveler group (free) and take advantage of the executive floor perks. They are worth it, especially the late checkout on departure days, and the coffee, beer, snacks, and newspapers that are available in the lounge.

Great location, near city & TCAT. Staff very friendly & efficient. Rooms and everything else have a faded grandeur look about them, looks like it was high tech in 1990 and not changed since. Be careful of the bars >Y1,000 for a beer!!!

I stayed in Royal Park Hotel for business for 12 nights in October 2011.I stayed on the executive floor, which gave me free access to the lounge, and room rate was inclusive of internet access and breakfast on the top floor. I paid JPY25,000 per night, which was absolutely a better deal than what was quoted by my local colleagues, i.e. JPY22,000 - but only standard room and exclusive of both internet & breakfast. Internet connection was fast and breakfast was served at the top floor with a good view of the city. I found this good deal on the hotel's website. Be sure to look out for promotions the next time you plan to stay at Royal Park Hotel.Staff are friendly and speak English well. For example, concierge staff were very helpful in providing useful tips for sight-seeing, directions and some other occasions. Information such as subway route map and the city map of Tokyo was handy. You can also ask for a rate table that shows the approximate taxi fares to a number of destinations within the city.If taxi is not an option, the basement of the hotel connects to the Suitengumae subway station. It's a 15-minute ride to Ginza and Tokyo Station. There is a convenient store right across the street, and a number of restaurants and eateries as you walk down the street.Overall, I think highly of Royal Park Hotel and will recommend to fellow travellers, particularly those travelling on business.

Like other reviewers, I love the location for using the TCAT to and from Narita, and for travel around Tokyo in general. Staff, service and restuarants are all very good. I have stayed here 3 times and was impressed each time. Excellent but pricey Japanese restaurant on top floor, Executive floor and services are exceptional, and breakfast buffet on ground floor has a great selection of western and asian fare. Rooms are very well accomodated. The only reason not to give full marks is simply because the standard of hotels in Tokyo (and Asia) is so much higher than Europe & N America that to give an excellent would diminish the quality of some even better hotels (ANA Intercontinental Tokyo for example).

The Royal Park Hotel is an excellent hotel for people travelling for business or pleasure. The staff is all very outstanding and service oriented. English is not a problem at this hotel. As far as I'm concerned, this hotel service is on par or exceeds that of other 5 star hotels in Japan that are much more expensive. The restaurants that I tried, the Japanese sushi in the basement and the Chinese restaurant are both again excellent in quality and service. To top it all off, the hotel is right above the Suitengumae subway station and the TCAT bus terminal with direct bus access to Haneda and Narita airports. I will stay there again. In fact I have already booked my next stay starting 4March.

I'm becoming a regular.. attracted by the location.. just steps away from TCAT..Tokyo City Air Terminal.. very convenient connections to Narita Airport. Staff is first class, friendly and helpful. Big discounts are available if you look hard. For example, the hotel passes out 30% discount coupons for exec flors after a few stays. Corporate discounts can be even better.-Executive floor is nice, but nothing special. -Good fitness & pool area.-Internet fee is about $12 US, but free on executive floors.-Great riverside walk/jogging along the Sumida River.. goes for miles and miles-Subway access in the basement-Convenience store (7-11) across the streetA solid business hotel...

Staff friendly and helpful, restaurants a little pricey, across the street from the TCAT so easy connection to Narital and Haneda. The rooms very comfortable. On second visit was upgraded to corner suite- all I can say is WOW.

Stayed here for 2 nights on business in Jan 2012. Handy for airport via TCAT bus (directly under the hotel). Arrived around 11am after an overnight flight and had to wait for 90 mins for my room - was offered a business class upgrade for Y3000 which included breakfast but declined as I usually dont eat it. Worth buying the upgrade if you do - it also includes internet so represents a saving. As always in Japan the concierge is very helpful in planning travel to meetings and even a trip to the Sumo. Hotel can be expensive but some of the discount sites can offer reasonable deals.

Stayed here for business/personal trip. Conveniently located next to TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) which is easy access to and from both Narita and Haneda airports via limobus. Good choice of restaurants in the hotel lower level and around the area made it convenient to stay nearby. Staff very friendly and accomodating to your needs. Rooms a bit on the small side but nice and comfortable. The Execuitve Floor provides drinks and light snacks after a long day and a good place to meet informally. Breakfast buffet is sustantial and omelette station nice.

Big conference hotel, in general expensice as whole Tokyo so no complain about that, except breakfast almost 35 euro is overdone.Rooms are a bit small, but ok.The problem in tokyo you hardly will find anything better around 200 euro per night
user_name:
JanVeghel
Beek en Donk, The Netherlands

review_body: We stayed one night on the executive floor and four nights in the standard room. I didn't think the executive room was worth the higher room rate so go standard if budget is a factor. Easy access from Narita or Hadena Airports via the limobus to Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT). This is the easiest and least expensive way to get there. The hotel experience is very good but it is a bit pricey. We did really enjoy the high quality breakfast buffet which is included in the room rate. Eat a big breakfast and you will probably skip lunch and have a light snack in preparation for a Japanese dinner. It is right next to the Tokyo Metro and the stop is connected to the hotel (exit 4) which is really convenient. Get the unlimited metro pass from the hotel desk which will save some money if you travel around to multiple destinations during the day. There did not seem to be many things to see within walking distance from the hotel. Most local businesses/restaurants seemed to be closed on Sunday. My wife went on a full day tour of Tokyo organized by the travel desk which she really enjoyed.

Stayed here with my family for 5 nights. Generally a business hotel, but was fine for a few nights while on vacation. We had an executive floor suite - of course the rooms (like the rest of the hotel) had the corporate-like feel, but nothing to complain about - very clean and actually quite spacious. Although hotel is ready for a reburb now and probably has been for the last 5 years or so. Staying on the executive floor meant we had access to the free drinks/canapes at 5pm - I think the whole floor runs over at 5pm to grab a few free nibbles. Great little snacks (the first few that come out) but which then get a bit ropey as the evening goes on and the selection of alcoholic drinks/wines is limited. Any business class lounge would beat it by miles.Whilst the location is perfect for the airport, you just step off the TCAT from Narita and you are pretty much at the hotel, when visiting Tokyo again, I'd stay somewhere a little more exciting such as Shibuya. But the surrounding area was pretty interesting itself - has a few small temples/shrines that are worth a visit, just not too many restuarants for dinner in the evenings. Good sized gym and great little running track outside. Enjoyed the pool too. Although I was told off by the attendent at the desk for wearing my dressing gown provided in the room down to the pool... apparantly you MUST change into your bathing suit in the changing rooms rather than your hotel room - bit of a strange rule, but there you go!

The Royal Park is a very good business class hotel. Located next to the bus station from Narita and within walking distance of many Tokyo sights. Rooms are clean and quite with the now typical Japanese "bionic" toilets complete with fans to remove odors, heaters, and swing away bidet (which I think is disgusting).The restaurant is good. The staff is very helpful and courteous.

For the Western traveler first time to Japan, the Royal Park is the perfect place to stay. After the ~14 hour flight from the US or Europe and the hour long bus ride from Narita to TCAT, just walking across the street to the Royal Park is a major relief. Once there, the traveler will find the staff, the front desk, bell people, concierge all courteous, English speaking and efficient. I've stayed here in total probably two months and always had world class service. This hotel has a very convenient subway stop in the basement and another stop down the road at Ningyo-cho is also convenient. Definitely recommend happy hour at Royal Scots downstairs. Other food/drink in the hotel is very expensive but the self-serve noodle shop across the street is really good as is all the food in TCAT - go there for a little Japanese flavor! The woman traveler desk is awesome for helping Western women plan a foray into the city on their own. Literally no other issues or flaws (no noise, no bill mistakes, always accommodated late check out, early check in) in two months that I stayed there. This is a great hotel.

Stayed here with work for 6 nights. Room adequate TV selection poor for westerner. Small towels and average bathroom. Breakfast selection very poor, exec lounge very poor food and drink selection. Nealy every hol in Singapore KL or Bangkok I have stayed in would beat it. Food in restaurants 4/5 except tepanyaki 20th floor 6/5 excellent.

I found the Royal Park Hotel's staff to be extremely courteous. The overall facility and my guest room were immaculately clean. My dining experience was limited to breakfast only do to outside business appointments in the evenings - the breakfast buffets were well stocked with western and Japanese style items. The Royal Park is conveniently located nearby my company's Tokyo offices as well as the Tokyo City Air Terminal. If future travel brings me back to Tokyo I plan on staying here again and will recommend to my colleages.

Stayed two nights in the hotel, very nice room indeed, was upgraded to executive floor with access to a seperate lounge and breakfast area with a view of the city. A few steps from the City Air Terminal with very frequent shuttle busses to the Narita airport, subway downstairs from hotel which makes access to business and shopping areas very easy. High tech rooms with plenty of television channels and free internet access. Will return for sure. Restaurants in hotel are extremely expensive, equally good restaurants right outside the hotel (if you can find the ones with English menus).

I had a chance to stay at this hotel just for a night for a client meeting in Tokyo. Everyone who's been to Tokyo that Narita airport is a planet away! And this hotel is nice as it is bang next to Airport City Center and Limosuine buses drop you right on the door. The icing on the cake is that it next door to metro station. I was there only for night and hence unfortunately did not try any of the hotel amenities but room was well appointed, with nicely stocked bath supplies. I had good meal from room service and had a good restful sleep before my meeting next day. The breakfast buffet is very basic but will do for a road warrior like me! I would recommend this a business hotel

I've just got back from a 5 night stay at the hotel and it was a great stay. This hotel has incredible service, and the facilities are excellent.Just a quick anecdote on why the service here is the best. On the first day of my stay, I had just checked in at 3:00pm and one of the cleaning maids made a mistake to open the room door for a spot of cleaning (she did knock on the door and press the doorbell first, but I was slow in responding). She was mortified that a guest was still in the room. She said her sorrys and I accepted her apologies. However, the management called me 15 minutes later in the room and offered her apologies. When I checked out 5 days later, the concierge again apologized for the incident again showing the level of detail they go into to ensure guests are welcomed and that their stay is out of this world.Pros.1. Excellent location - there are lots of local restaurants and shops around and is right on top of Hanzomon Metro line.2. Service is out of this world. Room amenities are very well thought out. Everything you need is in the room, it even has a Nexpresso machine for your coffee.3. Complimentary Internet line and WIFI (speed was never an issue, youtube videos were fine)4. Breakfast buffet is excellent with a great choice (go to the Level 1 buffet, the L16 one has a smaller selection)5. Pool and Gym is perfectly adequate if you need it for fitness (but it would be nice if they could open beyond 9pm)6. Late check out (3pm). Cons1. The room view (I was on 12th floor) is nothing to write home about.2. The selection of TV channels does not have a great selection for non Japanese.The hotel is excellent if you want a hotel with a Japanese character for a business stay. I have stayed at the Shangri-la hotel in Chuo-ku and while it too was a stunning stay with excellent service, it has a very sterilized western feel. If you want to experience abit more of the Japanese culture, then Royal Park Hotel is an excellent choice (plus it was about 60% of the price of a Shangri-la room)

Awesome is the word and my recommendation is always seek an upgrade to executive floor. You have your own mini breakfast counter and snacks at your disposal. The wash rooms and service is awesome....The break fast provides you a decent range of options and Vegans will not go hungry. I love their Veg Curry and rice!!!!!very friendly staff - close to home

First, the Royal Park Hotel is situated above the Tokyo Metro Suitengumae station and beside the TCAT; this makes commuting convenient. Second, service and food quality at the Palazzo and Symphonie are delightful. Third, extra amenities like face cleanser and bath salts were provided, and were a pleasant surprise. Fourth, there were helpful English-speaking staff. Fifth, easy to get a taxi from the hotel. The only area of improvement is perhaps sound-proofing the rooms better-- I went to Tokyo on holiday and I could hear nearly every movement in the room next to mine.

Not cheap, but nothing in Tokyo is cheap. Breakfast buffet is expensive, but very high quality and worth it. The breakfast area is a high point of the facility.The service is way above average. The staff is very friendly, highly professional and unfailingly polite and considerate, even by Japan standardsBeing next door to the TCAT is a huge plus.The property is immaculately maintained, rooms and public areas are spotless. Hotel does not look its age.Food is delicious in restaurants, but you can find equally good food for less money at any number of small eateries in the area. If you go out of the front door and turn right, you will pass a half dozen in a 5 minute walk.

We had a lovely stay at the Royal Park Hotel on a recent trip to Tokyo. The staff were very professional and friendly, even to the point of taking all our luggage over to the TCAT. Very convenient at Z10 on the Hanzomon Subway Line which exits at the hotel. Rooms were lovely and very clean, as were the pool and fitness centre facilities. Room service was excellent and we had a very memorable evening in the Sky Bar with fantastic views to the Tokyo Tower. I can't wait to stay there again. Virginia, Australia.
Good hotel, great service and selection of restaurants/bars. Located in a business district but very easy to access from Narita (~1 hour on TCAT).

The Royal Park Hotel offers great service, a good range of restaurants, and is convenient for the TCAT and the subway. The hotel is old though, but it has been well maintained and is very clean. It is a little bit away from the action if you are after that, but you can get to Roppongi and Shinjuku in 25 minutes on the subway.

I have been staying at the RPH 4-6 time/year since 2003. Having lived in Japan, and again in Singapore earlier in my career, I am used to great service in good Asian hotels, but the RPH staff set themselves apart. They are extremely competent, as well as politely friendly. I was in Tokyo on March 11 2011 at the earthquake. The staff- from bellmen (and bellwomen) to management- everyone was calm, careful, and incredibly helpful. Perhaps not the most luxurious rooms (nor largest!), but arguably the best hotel I have ever stayed at.

Great hotel, great service, subway just under it!Breakfast was next to awesome and bar personnel was really nice! They made all the annoying things that all the annoying Westerners always want - bless the Japanese and their patience!In fact, the only not so nice person was really the only western lady that worked at the reception. Apart from this, great service!I really didn't have time to make use of all the available services, but the subway is just under the hotel and the connecting place to the airport (I used Narita), was just the building next to it!The street where it's located is safe, and there are a couple of small stores where you can get some snacks, as well as decent restaurants. Don't expect to find an ATM (that works with western cards) anywhere else nearby except on the hotel lobby itself - great thought by the management team!Internet was good, and every day you had the International Herald Tribune (not sure), delivered at your door.Very good everything, really! Pricy, but worth it!Travelled June 2010 (TripAdvisor only let's me select Nov 2010)

Great hotel - great service - great location - great valueThe most helpful and courteous staff I have ever encountered throughout my travelsClose to subway - easy access throughout TokyoA most enjoyable experience

Located at TCAT Royal Park Hotel offers good accomodation for a reasonable price. Tepanyaki Restaurant at top I can recommend and also the breakfast at the sky-lounge.Just a pity that lounge was not open every night.

I stayed here for a couple of nights during a recent trip to Tokyo. While I found the hotel to be good overall, I was somewhat disappointed and especially so considering the cost. The first issue was the rooms, which were very small and somewhat dated. There was nothing really wrong with them, but they paled in comparison to many of the hotels I have stayed at in China and Japan. Secondly, they seem to have WiFi issues as I had difficulty connecting my iPad on a number of occasions during each stay. Lastly, they didn't seem to have a business center one can access without additional costs, which was disappointing.Again, this wasn't a bad hotel by any regard and it is very well located in that it is located right beside the TCAT, which is one of the easiest ways to get to Narita. It just wasn't memorable and it is quite expensive.I may give someplace else a try next time.

Executive rooms offer all you can pretend for this fee in Tokyo. The hall and the restaurants are particularly beautiful, on aesthetic point of view. See no defect. Various food options and a nice sky lounge with -as typical in Tokyo- jazz live music.

Stayed at the Royal Park Hotel for a business trip and was impressed. Very clean and the staff was friendly and professional. Located in a nice area with convenient travel options to airports. Cost was very reasonable. Only negative: bed on the small side.

I was recommended this hotel. The first thing I was impressed by was how easy it was to reach from the airport. The "T-CAT" is literally next door, with limousine buses running every hour to and from Narita. During my four days in Tokyo this time I had to travel by Metro and train, and the fact that there is a Metro station directly under the hotel made this very convenient.The hotel staff were helpful and friendly, wireless internet was reasonable and the buffet breakfast was delicious. I would stay again.

It has been a while since I stayed at the RP in Nihonbashi and the promotion that they were running in July made it a no brainer to go back. The rooms are spacious and the staff still remembered my name even after not being there for a few years. The hotel is conveniently located below hanzomon station or just down the street from Ningyocho station (if you like taking the subway). Will go back again for sure !

My husband was staying here for business and I was able to join him for vacation. It was convenient as it was next to the Tokyo City Airport terminal (buses from Narita go here directly) and directly connected to the Tokyo Metro subway station. However, it was still a little bit out of the downtown core of Tokyo. We had a large room with 2 double beds, however the decor was a little dated. Overall a nice hotel. The staff was very helpful and spoke English. It was on the expensive side and for the price I would rather stay closer to Tokyo station, Ginza, etc... if this trip was purely for vacation purposes. Since my husband was on business however, it was a great location for him (only 5 mins from the office).

I stayed here for a week on business and was very happy and comfortable with the facility and service. Staying on the Executive program, you get amenities that seem frilly until you realize that the coffee in the lounge is better than the restaurant, that a tipple or fresh fruit to tide you over, and ease of Internet access together make for both a productive and civilized experience. The staff is very responsive and polite. It's also right on the Tokyo Metro, with the additional lines of the Ningyocho stop a mere five minutes walk away. I'd gladly stay here again.

Royal Park Hotel is extremely easy to get to either from Haneda Airport (taxi) or from Narita (airport bus) and a few minutes' walk. The metro station is easily accessible from the hotel and one stop leads to the best departmental store in Tokyo - Mitsukoshi. This store has history and yet caters to all ages.

May I start my review by saying please do not be afriad to travel to Tokyo. i have just returned from an 8 night stay and the only noticable difference was that most of the escalators and water features were switched off to save energy.Ok, back to reviewing the hotel.....Staff were really helpful and friendly. One of the staff was originally from Ipswich (Chris) and he went out of his way to make us feel welcome.As most of the other reviews state, rooms are small but very clean. One thing that has not been mentioned is the views from the rooms. They are pretty good. We stayed in two different rooms during our stay. For the first to nights of our trip we had a city view, and the last two nights we had a sea view. Both were very acceptable.Location is good, but I persoanlly prefer to stay in Shinjuku as it has a main station and you can get to most of the "touristy" areas without changing trains.There are plenty of places with reasonable prices that you can eat and drink at outside the hotel, so I was not tempted to try one of the hotel restaurants.All in all it was an enjoyable stay.

Even though I spent most of my time off hotel working but I must say I picked the right hotel for my business trip. The best thing I like about the hotel is the attitude of the staff. They always wear a smile anytime you see them or ask them. It's been quite a long time I did not fully feel such a nice service. However, the room is quite small - as perhaps the same as many other hotels in Japan, and the bathroom stuff is not up to standard I would expect from a Luxury 5-star hotel right in the Nihonbashi district of Tokyo. Oh one more thing I don't understand why such a upscale hotel still uses a big room key which is very inconvenient. Is it a tradition or a distinction?

This is a very nice hotel that is convenient for travelers. The hotel looks great and is very clean. It's right next door to the bus terminal (TCAT) and has a subway entrance in the basement that is very close to all the best areas of Tokyo. The rooms are small which is normal for Japan, but are very comfortable and clean. On a negative note, the TV channels were very limited for English speakers, and they need to add more channels. Also, the Ironing board is small (2 ft. long). Breakfast was very limited. A definite positive is the heated toilet seat, which was great in the winter time. You don't get this in the USA. Overall a very good hotel.
user_name:
sookie77
New York City, New York

review_body: I have stayed in many hotels in Tokyo and this is one of my favourites. Service is absolutely impeccable. Rooms are quiet and comfortable. Rooms have a PC including free internet which is a really nice touch. The only negative would be that you sometimes have to stand in line for breakfast.
RPH is perfect in every way. Convenience, service, value, comfort. Look no further.

I stayed for eight nights at this hotel in November 2010. I was on the executive floor and had a package deal for Y24,000 that included breakfast, internet and health club access. The executive floor also has a lounge which has complementary drinks. This is a very nice hotel with the excellent service one would expect in Tokyo. My only complaint, and minor, is that the rooms are small and starting to get a little tired, especially the bathroom, when compared to other hotels such as the ANA.

It is difficult to know what to write about the Royal Park. It was a good hotel, The staff were very friendly and generally efficient, the common areas nicely decorated. In Stand-out terms though, there was nothing to really write about.Very Good:>Staff, courteous and helpful>Restaurant Food (well at least the Breakfast and one trip to the Tempura Bar)>It's proximity to the Tokyo International Air Terminal was great>I liked the area it was inPoor:>Bath and Shower way behind that of most other upmarket hotels I've stayed in. The shower especially - basically a small shower head on the end of a plastic, flexible hose. with a plastic shower curtain.>TV - trying to find any English channels not a simple matter>In Room breakfast not too good (then again this applies to 99% of hotels)

I have stayed at the Royal Park for some years. It is very convenient, next to TCAT, and has a subway station in the basement. It is veyr very good value, executive room, free breakfast and wi-fi, Yen 25,000. Same price for 5 years and under half the so called posh hotels, Peninsula etc. Typically good service, comfortable rooms, good range of restaurants, pricey, but that is the exchange rate. Good pool, Japanese Bath , Massage, Gym, etc. Also efficient aircon, which I really like. Only problem is there are now 6 executive floors, and 6 ordinary floors, which means the lounge is heaving during happy hour, and there can be a long line to check out.

The hotel room is clean and comfortable with many nice amenities including English language newspapers and computers provided in the rooms. The staff is very attentive and helpful to the needs of the guests. There are many TV channels, but it would be nice to have CNN in English. The hotel is centrally located with may restuarants and sights within walking distance. It also has a subway station accessible from the lower floor and one can buy a two-day subway pass at the front desk; this opens up all of Tokyo to the traveler.

I thought carefully about the theme for this review and decided NOT to make it a Hilton comparison. I'll let the facts speak for themselves.I was stuck with it. Having stayed at the Hilton before in Shinjuku and knowing what level of service there to expect, I dreaded staying at another hotel, regardless of the travel agents promise of the "Luxury Rating" An experienced traveler knows better.The Friendly airport limousine (It's a bus folks, not a classic limo in the real sense) drops you off at the Tokyo Air Terminal (TCAT for short) It's a bus terminal, nothing more, with a few shops. Although the Royal Park is next door, signage is non-existent, and you cannot see the property from the drop off point. I knew it was there from reading Tripadvisor reviews, so I asked the Security guard for directions. and rolled the luggage across the street in the rain.The lobby is sumptuous and Grand. It gave the impression of luxury, wide spacious and full of light and restaurants.Every staff member smiled at you and was eager to serve or help.I was checked in quickly and a staff member assisted me to my room. I had asked for a king or queen bed, but none were available and had two double beds. Small disappointment but it had happened before.It was curious to note that the Hotel still uses Brass Keys, no electronic locks for the guest room doors. It's a big key, so have a big pocket to carry the key in or drop it off at the front desk when you leave.The elevators taking you to your room are quick and efficient.The hallways of the guest room floors were very clean and had quiet music playing.And then I arrived at my room....The standard guest room is small folks. Not a surprise, as I had stayed in Japanese hotels before and expected this. What I didn't expect was the stained room carpets. Not one stain, but many stains. The carpet was clean, but the stains were permanent, a sign of very old, very used carpets long past replacement phase. The TV was all Japanese language channels, a fact that evoked a sigh until I learned of the special remote control buttons that produced other channels with some English and other countries broadcasts.There was a mini bar in the room, which was good as they didn't provide ANY free water bottles, not even initial ones. As usual for hotels, mini bar prices were exorbitantly high.The bathroom had a very cheap and flimsy curtain plus rod, the kind attached via pressure against the walls type. It was not permanently installed. The shower nozzle was attached to the faucet via a cord, as some European Hotels are wont to do. That would have been fine, except the cord length on this one was so short, my 6 foot 2 length required me to duck down and crouch to use the faucet head. I found myself laughing at the insanity of it all. The showers and bathrooms themselves were clean, however the very upper walls of the showers were covered in small dirt particles, as were the ceiling vents. As the housekeeping staff were consistently somewhat smaller in frame than the ceiling heights, this may have been unnoticed, but seriously needed attention. The toilet was very clean, but when flushed, produced a sharp briny odor, like sea water. It was fairly disgusting to inhale.That first night, I noticed the bed was comfortable, even tho narrow and short for my body length. And then, as I began to fall asleep, the bites started. No, not one or two little pinches, it was continuous, like a swarm. I had disturbed a nest, I think, or maybe the room was full of tiny flying insects. In any case, I spent the night in complete misery because of those little pinching bites, sleeping little. I tried a shower again during the night, thinking maybe it was my skin that was dry, but as soon as I came back to that bed it was nibble, nibble, nibble.The next day, I approached the hotel staff and complained of the bugs. They quickly offered a new room and at my request, on the same floor. I moved into the new room that same evening after a day at work. Same stained carpets and dirt on the upper shower walls, cheap shower rod, and faucet attached for a 4 foot high human being, but no bedbugs this time around. One night in the new room during a shower, the water went from warm to scalding hot. Be aware of this propensity in this hotel for this to happen.A word about the gym. The Hotel had a spa, which contained a large workout room. The charge for using the treadmills, as I desired. was 1500 Yen. This irked me royally, as every property I stayed at was a free offer for only jogging or free overall for the gym. I paid the first day, and was treated to a series of equipment that was old and faulty. The treadmills slipped during usage. I noted this to the staff, but they did nothing to provide a service recovery such as a complimentary refund. Not even a thank you for telling them of the breakage. The next day, I found that the property was very close to a multi kilometer jogging path along the river. This path was fantastic, fresh air, and had a breeze to die for in the evening. I used this path from then on rather than the Hotel gym.The hotel had several restaurants, very well designed and having a variety of food and drink. A complimentary drink and dinner special coupon was enclosed. Be aware that the dinner coupon does not exclude you from the Service Charge and Consumption Charge they tack on into your check. As the area has MANY fine eating establishments, I recommend highly eating outside the property for economy and variety.The Hotel is on top of the Hanzomon Subway line, accessible by elevator within the hotel. It's ultra convenient for transit anywhere in Tokyo.On my next to last day, I made use of the coffee shop for a take away cup. This was a major ordeal for some reason and took over 10 minutes to prepare an ordinary coffee in a cup. Once they had done so (and charged an appropriately high amount PLUS Service charge even tho the service was bad PLUS the Consumption charge) I walked away with my coffee and two small creamers. In my room, I added the creamers, noting as the cream fell into the coffee it was sour. Auuuuggghhh. I went back down to the coffee shop and produced the evil ruined coffee. Once again, no offer to recover or delight with customer service nor was there any apology for the bad coffee, just a much quicker replacement of the coffee and this time they used a cream pitcher with good creamer.Check out day was efficient and service at the desk was fine. The transport to the TCAT next door was again a walk across the street with luggage. At least it wasn't raining this time.In summary, I would not stay at this property again..ever, as the most disgusting occurrence to happen is being bitten by bedbugs. It didn't help matters that the few incidents that happened during my stay (the broken gym equipment which I had PAID to use and the sour coffee creamer which I PAID for) had no recovery in terms of delighting myself the customer or encouraging my future stays at the property. Perhaps they do not care about this or perhaps it isn't important to them. Overall I see a property that markets itself as "Luxury" but below the surface it needs serious upgrading of the rooms and service recovery related training to remain viable in a competition based market of hotels that already know these lessons.Like the Hilton does.

We had a group of eight or so business colleagues at the hotel. Having the Executive Floor area to conference and unwind following day-long meetings was fantastic. The floor offers ample appetizers and drinks in the evening and the 20th floor breakfast in the morning was a great way to start the day. I wish every business hotel was this excellent! Of course, the price is hefty, particularly with the value of the yen vs. the dollar. But that is my sole complaint. I had altered our room arrangements when our daughter joined us and the hotel was very accommodating in changing our reservation to be sure to allow for a triple arrangement. They replied promptly by e-mail to all my questions prior to the trip and the concierge was terrific. Being right next to the TCAT was great for traveling to our conference center, to and from the airport, and later for the start of a short vacation.

The main reason I chose this hotel was its proximity to the City Air Terminal, and it was a huge relief to basically step out of the terminal and be right at the hotel. The staff were very friendly and the room itself (standard double on the executive floor) was spacious with a well appointed bathroom (I'm over 6" tall and the bath was more than big enough for me). The hotel has a charming old-school feel to it, including plush, softly lit corridors and room keys that are actually keys (and weigh a ton). There was no street noise to speak of and free wifi on the executive floors was a definite plus.The hotel's not particularly close to any major attractions, but it's right above the Hanzomon metro line (Suitengumae station, which you can access directly from the basement) which makes it easy enough to get to anywhere in the city. Tokyo Station is also close by (about a 20 minute walk or 5 minutes by subway, but you have to change to the Marunouchi line).One thing to note, the hotel's booking conditions state that if a guest hasn't arrived by 8pm the hotel has the right to cancel the booking. I doubt they hold too firmly to this rule, but if you're going to be arriving late (as I was) it's worth emailing ahead to let them to know to hold the room.

concierge floor 4 nightsvery convenient to TCAT bus stationclose to subway but found this line to not go where I was going20 min walk to Tokyo Stationfriendly service but given wrong info on TCAT bus and Tokyo fish Market building is well maintained but has an 80's feel to itroom had strong b.o. odor that never abatedquietnice Japanese breakfastdid not evaluate value
user_name:
namrof
Hastings on Hudson, New York

review_body: Convenient location, next door to TCAT. Excellent, friendly service throughout from doorman through to waiters and reception. Good spoken English. I recommend the Executive floor for its facilities, staffing and meeting areas.

I needed to visit one of our offices in Tokio and had the pleasure of staying at the Royal Park Hotel for 11 nights in November 2009 - Excellent experience from entering the lobby till the moment of checkout.I stayed in a 'standard' room and can't comment on the exec. floor but the room was clean and very spacious according to japanese standards.Very convenient is access to the metro system just at the lowest floor level of the hotel!If in Tokio, you must try the metro system. Nice and easy way to get around.

The Royal Park's main asset is its proximity to TCAT, Tokyo's City Air Terminal. TCAT's usefulness has varied over the years, with lows reached after 9/11 when some procedures were no longer handled there, but in the right circumstances it is extremely convenient, if check-in, luggage, and emigration formalities are all handled there (not all airlines are represented). This can mean the difference between enjoying one's last evening in Tokyo proper as opposed to a Narita airport hotel, for those with an early morning departure. TCAT is also right next to a freeway onramp, and traffic between it and Narita is broadly predictable, making the bus schedule quite reliable.This also means the hotel's vicinity is rather boring, with mostly offices and businesses around it. More lively areas are easily accessible by public transportation, though.The hotel is a solid operation, with quite acceptable rooms and service, obviously catering to a higher-than-average proportion of foreigners, especially from countries where taking the airport train with luggage is considered less dignified. Room prices reflect this, making the Royal Park most suited for short stays.

This was an excellent choice - located right next to TCAT, the subway and a 10 minute taxi ride to Tokyo Central Station. The service (reception/concierge/bell captain) was outstanding (this was my first trip to Japan). This is a modern, efficient, business hotel. So skip it if you are looking for a traditional Japanese inn ("Ryokan").Four minor quibbles1. The air-conditioner had a hard time coping with the record breaking Tokyo heat.2. The food in the hotel was way to expensive for the quality (there are excellent places to eat within a 3-5 minute walk).3. I got a massage in the room. Compared to massages in any part of the world, this one was a complete waste of time and money. 4. There is a charge for using the fitness center.

The room was very big, even with computer, desk, sofa and make-up-table. The furniture very classic, little bit boring for my taste. Bath room very nice with good shiseido products.A very classical hotel, the personal is wearing very classical outfits. Under the hotel is the connection to the subway. very convinient.

We had the pleasure of staying at the Royal Park Hotel for nine nights in May - it really was a first class experience from beginning to end.Bus from Narita Airport the first stop is Tokyo Air Terminal, pick up the phone in the lobby to the Hotel and a porter is with you in minutes.We stayed on the Executive Floor which included a wonderful breakfast each morning and cocktails in the evening. The evening ‘nibbles’ were mostly meat or fish, explaining that one of us was a vegetarian - every night they ensured that there was something especially for us.The area surrounding the Hotel is pleasant with shops including convenience stores, for sandwiches and snacks, and a coffee shop just across the road.Getting around Tokyo is easy once you have familiarised yourself with the metro system. Going to the lowest floor of the hotel takes you straight to the Metro station. We like to explore on our own rather than taking tours and were able to quite easily make trips to Lake Kawaguchiko (surprisingly scruffy) to see Mount Fuji and on another day Kamakura. The hotel obviously steer you in the direction of guided tours but if you take a trip to the tourist office in Tokyo (or drop into the ones at Narita Airport) they will helpfully supply you with information to find you own way. The Office in Tokyo was a bit difficult to find being on the 10th Floor of a building: 10 Fl., Tokyo Kotsu Kaikan Bldg., 2-10-1 Yurakucho, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo 100-0006 TEL: [-]Office hours: Open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.  On leaving, we were escorted by one of the Porters back to the Tokyo Air Terminal where she over saw us obtaining our tickets and waited until we had boarded the bus for the Airport!Exceptional Service and standards. Could not fault. Would highly recommend and would not hesitate to return.
Great qurlity but little expenceice

A work colleague recommended the Royal Park Hotel for me and my family (wife and 9 year old son) for our vacation. We stayed 5 nights on the executive level floor which has a separate lounge/check in area. The room size was okay, but a little small for 3 people. The double bed is the size of an american queen size bed. The service during our stay was simply great. The staff (all staff that we interacted with) were very helpful and patient. All of the staff spoke english and did their best to accomodate us for all of our needs. Each evening, I would go to the lounge to speak to staff to plan our next day. They were always accomodating with maps and suggestions of places to go and things to see.The Nihombashi neighrborhood has many small shops and restaurants that are worth trying. They will provide you with lists of restaurants that have english menus and lists of shops to visit (many historical, interesting shops and a shrine in the neighborhood). Within a block of the hotel is a good ramen (noodle) shop, soba restaurant and fruit store. There are several convenience stores within a 5 minute walk. The TCAT Bus station is across the street and you can catch the limousine bus to and from Narita in 55 minutes (depending on traffic) with no stops in both direction.

This was the latest of many stays at the Royal Park, and although there are many pluses, it's disappointing to come to a hotel with rooms sorely in need of change.First, the convenience of jumping on the bus at Narita and arriving at the TCAT station right next to the hotel is unbeatable. It's the first stop the bus makes, so you're here in under an hour. The location is also very convenient for getting to many Tokyo locations, including the Ginza. The restaurants are fine- main buffet is great with many different options throughout the week, the sushi restaurant also very nice.My main issues are as follows:1. The rooms look very old, surprisingly small selection of English tv channels, very outdated controls for the lights and audio.2. The gym is very small, usually way too hot, and is an extra charge (1,500 yen).3. Internet connection quite expensive.

We arrived from Narita late in the evening. The airport Shuttle bus takes you to the Tokyo Air Terminal (45 minutes) and from there the hotel is only 3 minutes walking. Breakfast is top quality and overall great value!

We stumbled upon this on this site, and then joined the I Prefer network to get the upgrade to the Executive floor, a little apprehensive as to whether it would even work. Imagine our surprise when we got the upgrade, and the welcome drink, and the use of the facilities throughout our stay. The staff were polite and helpful, even providing us with some key vocab before venturing out for dinner so we could try and read what was on offer. The area is good - not in the bright light hypo zone, but more a modest business area which can be walked to quickly get to good restaurants and local convenience stores. The metro of course gets you to the buzzy areas in no time, but we were quite grateful not to be on top of all of that, and at the end of a long day, to come back to a really calm oasis. The hotel is located conveniently next to a coach station, which connects up nicely to the airport. And it is under the Metro too. I would definitely stay here again when next in Tokyo.

This hotel was great! They supplied anything you could ever need for toiletries. Computer on the TV, but the japanese keyboard confused me so I hooked up my own laptop. Internet was free. The buffet breakfast upstairs was really good and included omelets made to order. Bed was comfortable.
We have stayed for 2 nights in one of the executive rooms. Everything about the hotel was excellent: rooms, service, food, etc. One of the best hotels I have stayed in!

A correct and reasonable Tokyo 4 star. Japanese hotels due to the very polite staff always are 1 star up compared to other countries. My only problem was when I arrived to check in at 9.30 am they would only release a room to me with a supplement . In fairness to the hotel they dont have to release a room till 2pm, but it does not build good will with the customer especially if rooms are available !!

Two night stay. Upgraded to larger room due to overbooking, slightly disappointed to be offered an option of paying for the upgrade first and then being put in the same room but told not to use the executive sevices. Large clean room, I didn't have time to check out the other facilities but there are a range of options to eat and a pool. Staff were extremely helpful, apart from the one trying to relieve me of another 6000 Yen per night . Overall to be recommended and very close to the TCAT for travel to the airports.
I stayed there for three days before going to Akita. This hotel is one of the best I have ever stayed at. Not cheap, but worth every penny!

We recently had a wonderful one-week stay at the Royal Park Hotel in one of the "executive floor" rooms. The extra cost for the executive floor was absolutely worth it. The breakfasts were great, and the evening cocktail hour was a treat. The best part of our experience was the absolutely wonderful staff, who went out of their way many times for us. The room was very nice - and while not large was comfortable, even for a one-week stay.The hotel is a bit out of the way - but in a nice area. The hotel has easy access to the subway system though - actually sitting on top of one line and with another line a couple short blocks away. We found it very easy to get around to all areas of the city. The restaurants in the hotel can be expensive (well it's Tokyo...) but as guests get 1/2 off the price. Not sure whether this applies to all guests or just for the exec floor. We spend most of our time in Japan in Tokyo and Kyoto - both very interesting, with a lot to see. Our "best" days though were side trips - Nikko from Tokyo and Nara and Himeji Castle from Kyoto. Each is very do-able in one day and has easy transportation via train.

A wonderfully clean and spacious hotel. Spent five days on the executive floor and these rooms are roomy and comfortable by Western standards. Attentive staff. Excellent French and Sushi restaurants on site.I highly recommend to fellow business travelers. Enroll in the "I Prefer" frequent stay program and you will be awarded for your stay. This is a Summit Hotel, a premium brand.

It's not cheap to stay here but if you can get over the cost you will not be disappointed. Beautiful rooms, good restaurant & bar and amazingly helpful staff will just about guarantee your satisfaction if you stay here.

We had great stay there! The service was wonderful, very present and helpful. Staff have their own lifts and are in your room 1 minute after calling ! I recommend the executive room : there is a special lounge with free cocktails from 5 to 8pm et free access to a nice 20m swimming pool with all comfort (and with 5 persons max in it).We took an upgraded executive room, it was big and perfect for us 3 (2 adults and a baby). We had a computer at our disposal in our room.The western breakfast is a nice buffet with a great view on Tokyo on the last floor.The location is a very good base for visiting : the hotel has its own exit in a subway station and another main line is 5min walk (maybe 10 with a baby) on the same street than the hotel. This is the best hotel we ever been. I just regret we had it first during our stay in Japan because then we were disappointed by the other 4 stars we chose !Very good value.

I stayed for a week in an executive room on the 16th floor. The room was very nice, on the exec floor you get free internet, breakfast, tea/coffee/snacks, cocktails, etc.The view was amazing from my room I could see the Tokyo Tower and the view at night was awesome. The room was very comfortable, and the bed was great. I enjoyed having a complete desk in the room to get work done at night. This hotel really meets the needs of a business traveler.I was most impressed with the service of the executive level lounge concierge. She helped me book a bus tour of the city, and answered any question I had. She also let me sneak in in my pjs in the morning to grab some regular tea since I'm not a big fan of green or plum tea in the morning.The only down side I would say is the pool/spa facilities are more like a gym then a relaxing area. And, I was kicked out for wearing a swimsuit in the jacuzzi. But, I was the only one there at first and I didn't know. I wasn't kicked out by a hotel person, just another person staying there. I wasn't about to argue with a naked person so I just called it a day and went back to my awesome room.I loved this hotel and I would definately stay again.

Stayed at this hotel in early August 2009. I had been there 5 years ago in one of the executive floor rooms. This time company booked a standard room at full rate (20,000 yen) and let me say there is a world of difference between the two types. The normal rooms are very small, bathrooms are dated. Small TV and loud (old) computer to access internet. No wifi. No double beds (all twins). If you're not in a executive room, they charge 5,000 yen extra for pool and gym- what a ripoff. Corridors are dark, there is a big elevated highway which is next to the hotel and unless you're on a high floor , expect a nice view of the Tokyo traffic... Unless you get a really cheap rate on expedia or priceline (less than $75/night), avoid this place, you're better off in a business hotel, of which there are many in the area for about 25% of the full price of a room at Royal Park Hotel. The positives are that the hotel is very clean and connected to the subway.

Great accomodation. Convenient Location. Friendly & helpful Lobby staffs. Great Restaurants. Room service was good. View from Sky Lounge was breathtaking. Good city view from each room. Good choice in Breakfast buffet. Basement Metro station (suitengumae station) that connects all the major stations. The basement is also connected with the City Terminal. Free internet access at Executive floors. Elegantly designed Lobby. A plus point for those who is travelling with babies is a small supermarket just opposite to the hotel Entrance.

My husband and I ,and another couple ,stayed at the Royal Park Hotel for 5 nights during a 2+ week vacation in Japan . The hotel was fantastic. We booked rooms on their executive level. Service was the very best we've ever had, the rooms were well decorated, each room had a PC for client use,we had use of their wonderful spa with gym, pool, sauna and the works...and they were wonderful; the complementary buffet breakfast was exquisite. The location of the hotel couldn't be any better...in a mostly residential neighboorhood, away from all the huge Tokyo crowds, but very convenient with a subway line right by the hotel. Travel to/from Narita Airport is also simplified by having the Limousine Bus station right next door to the hotel..it beats having to drag luggage up and down stairs and dealing with the crowds at Tokyo Station for the Narita train! We highly recommend this hotel....it's one of the best managed properties we've stayed in.

Although we are world travelers we have never been to Tokyo. I found a great package deal on Skyauction.com. It included round trip air from LAX to Narita on Northwest airlines and 7 nights at the Royal Park Hotel that ended up costing us $1644 each. It was advertised as a 4 star hotel but I think it should be 5 stars. Everyone at the hotel was very attentive and friendly, especially the girls at the bell captains desk who helped us make reservations for a trip to Kyoto on the bullet train and get tickets to a Chuck Mangeoini Jazz Concert at the Cotton Club. We had a standard room (not on the executive floor) and it was very nice. 16th floor room with large window that overlooked a large section of the city. Wonderful toiletries in the bathroom. We thought the restaurant prices were high (breakfast was $23, dinner about $100 each) so we ate at neighborhood places, which was much cheaper. The location is wonderful, as the "Friendly Airport Limousine Bus" terminal is just next door. We took the bus directly from Narita to the station for about $28 each. The porter from the hotel came with a cart to get our luggage. (Use the Royal Park direct line from the bus lobby). The subway is directly under the hotel and we went all over Tokyo on the subway. The hotel sells 1 day passes cheaper than at the station. (about $6). For some cheap eats, McDonalds is in the bus terminal on the 2nd floor. The terminal is immaculate and so are the subways. Very easy to get around and explore Tokyo cheaply. For a great evening, take in a concert at the Cotton Club (near Tokyo station) or go walking in the Ginza area. Take the subway to Ginza. We also booked a 1 day tour on the bullet train to Kyoto (from Tokyo City tours) that included lunch for about $225 each. Great price as we found out that the train tickets (if you buy them yourselves) are more than $275 each. The tour price inluded a lovely lunch at the hotel adjoining the Kyoto train station. (another great place with a 5 star hotel and a beautiful shopping mall). Overall, I thought the hotel was first rate and highly recommend it.Pat and Tom ElliottOrange, California

The staff is incredibly attentive and quick to respond to any need. I was booked into a room with two double beds and I found the workstation to be rather cramped as there wasn't much room to pull the chair out at the foot of the bed.The metro stop (Ningyocho) is a short ten minute walk. If you travel to Tokyo you really need to see the Imperial Gardens. Travel books I read said the closest metro stop is Kayabacho. Take the Tozai line two more stops to Otemachi and you're practically right across the street from the garden gates.

Booked on my banks AMEX travel service. Didn't know much about the hotel but it looked good and had a good price.I ended up staying here for 8 nights.6 with my g/f. 2 with a friend.Both rooms were on the Executive floor.From the very start service was outstanding. So so friendly. At check-in there was a problem with my room, due to me wanting a King bed and them booking a twin. Problem was rectified after they personally showed me some rooms to make sure I was happy with them. Made check-in a little bit longer but they were very helpful and it was kinda fun.Rooms are nice. Nothing ultra modern, nothing dated. Nice and comfortable. The great thing about this hotel is that you get a PC with free internet! In our room we had a tv facing the bed and a PC on a separate desk.Breakfast was great, we were in a smaller area due to being on the executive level - no queues for the omelette guy which was great!The only other restaurant at the hotel we tried was the sushi bar - it was average.There is a train station directly underneath the hotel and another one 5 minutes walk away.The area the hotel is in is a bit further from the 'action' of Tokyo. However, it has great restaurants and feels a lot more relaxed and homely. You get the feeling you could be staying at a apartment because its not all glitzy and touristy.The nighttime cabs back from Shibuya will hurt your wallet though!Overall - Perfect comfortable stay. Nothing bad. Great service, always smiling, always willing to help and genuinely friendly.

I returned from a week-long stay at the Royal Park Hotel a few days ago. Outstanding service and accommodations!! Not a very cheap hotel but I wasn’t looking for cheap in Tokyo being an expensive city. I had a great experience with every staff person there and I commend them for such a stellar service they provide in order to make my stay the best experience. The HotelI don’t know about other reviewers saying that the hotel hallways were dark or the rooms seemed worn out a bit, I saw none of these things personally. The hotel hallways seemed adequately lit, very clean, my room was very well maintained with nothing worn out. The bathroom spacious enough, with plenty of toiletries available for me, plenty of hot water, and the famous modern Japanese toilet I was looking forward to being acquainted with, lol! (warm water spraying, bidet, warmed up seat, etc).My room (#1710 at the executive floors) had an independent climate control that I could easily regulate. The mini bar fridge was not working but I didn’t care as I never use the drinks in hotel rooms so that didn’t bother me. I loved the free and unlimited internet use, as well as the plenty of TV channels, Japanese and English language selection. the room was cleaned every morning at around 9a. A small detail I found priceless was that every day I found a small card placed on my nightstand with the next day's weather forecast to plan accordingly. I also received two complimentary newspapers every morning. Also, as another reviewer had mentioned, the windows are well sound proofed and my room also looked towards several highways and the Sumida river. I personally liked the view. The executive lounge (16th flr) was a great way to end my day. I would go there reading my newspaper alongside my drink. A great way to unwind from a busy day. The lounge has free food and drinks.(8p is last call for food and drinks though – kinda too early if you ask me). There are two staff people there at all times and they would be happy to assist you with any questions you have. The LocationI often hear from other reviewers saying that the hotel is out of the way. Out of the way of what?? Tokyo is so HUGE that everything and everyone is out of the way from each other, UNLESS you take the subway to reach your destination. The hotel is literally connected to the Suitengumae subway stop of the Hanzomon line. The second you get out of the train, you proceed to exit #4 and the hotel entrance is right there! How much easier can it get? It’s ridiculous!! Not to mention that you can buy a one-day train pass for the Tokyo Metro subway (Not the Toei subway line though) right at the hotel reception. It’s around 600 Yen. And most hot spots are just a few station stops away. So unless you are looking for the “Shibuya experience” of the famed pedestrian crossing intersection to be right as you exit your hotel, or the Ginza experience of having the ability to walk into a Luis Vuitton store right as you exit your hotel then you might need to look elsehwhere. In addition, I loved the neighborhood where the RPH is as I walked the streets up and down and saw the mixture of cute little shops (noodle shops, tiny toy stores, pastry shops, convenient stores, grocery stores, book stores, a Starbucks, etc) mixed in with office buildings. That’s what I like doing when I am in foreign places, to see how everyday is for the locals, office workers or otherwise and I could do it by walking the neighborhood which I found VERY safe even at night.The FoodThe hotel has many restaurants. I only tried the Symphony for its breakfast (nice selection) and the Hamada Sushi Restaurant for its sushi (excellent sushi). The rest seemed very expensive but I also didn’t have time to try them all being there for only a week. My suggestion would be to forget eating at the hotel restaurants every day as there are many little noodle shops (from 400 to 700 yen a plate) everywhere near the hotel and IMO that is the best way to eat and see where the locals go (who do not speak English whatsoever so venture out on your own risk, lol)The ServiceThe service at RPH was stellar, second to none! Any time I would approach the reception area for whatever questions, the staff was eager to help and make everything easy for me. Everyone had a smile on their face and very polite. The first day I arrived, I went to the reception to check-in and was immediately assisted with my luggage, was whisked to the Executive Lounge and shown to a table where I could eat and have a drink while the staff person was finalizing my check-in process.Final words, a great experience. Do not hesitate to stay at RPH hotel as it caters to every need, business or pleasure. Oh and if you choose to book a room at the executive floors, do not forget apply for a hotel membership in order to receive (and submit) the discount coupons to be applied towards your bill. Sorry for my long review, I hope you find it usefull. Thank you.

Stayed for 5 nights in a delux room. We knew the hotel was a little out of the way, but felt the access to the bus to to/from the airport and the fact that it was above the metro system was an advantage. Also like to get out and about in places that are not always in the centre of things. Hotel handy for shop accross the road for drinks snacks etc.We arrived very early (9.30am) and a room was not ready which we expected as the hotel was full from the night before, but the staff did all they could to find a room at the rate we had paid but none were clean,so we were offered a upgrade at a reducd rate to the club foor. We normally stay on the club foors but find ourselves increasingly cutting our day short to return for cocktails, and getting up for b/fast when really just want a little lie in, so on this occasion we just booked a normal room at a good price for Tokyo. We waited with a coffee for just under an hour for a room to be ready.Room quite a good size, a little worn in places and quite drab in decoration. But everything you needed including a safe (which is in the bedside cabinet). Comfy bed, ok linen but the bathroom was a little dated but clean, shower over bath which was very low to stand under, although the toilet was an laugh as everyone knows who has been to Tokyo. All the bits and bobs you need in the bathroom as far as shampoo etc. were there. Only real gripe was the amount and size of towels, but you could ring up for more.Room faced the expressway which was well soundproofed from the traffic, although could hear bathrooms a little from other rooms. Eventhough we were next to the lifts we never heard them.Access to a tv come pc in the room with internet access was good, but you do pay if you use the internt on your on pc, which was fair enough.Shops below the hotel handy as well. Did not have b/fast or use the bars but there was quite a selection of eating places in the hotel to choose from if needed.All in all we wanted a decent hotel at a fair price with easy acces to get around, which is what the Royal Park provided, if I was to go to Tokyo again, if the price was good we would stay again

I agree with previous review. I stayed both at Park Hotel for 3 days, and then my last night at Royal Park Hotel. I paid much higher at Royal Park Hotel and it wasn't worth it.Room was old, hallway was dark, no safe in room....I was amazed by Tokyo Park Hotel, and I would not go back to Royal Park.

I had seen the reviews on this site, and figured, if I'd stayed at the #1 hotel (Tokyo Park Hotel) and loved it, why not stay at the #2?I have to say that between the two, I liked the Tokyo Park Hotel more. That hotel's rooms were modern and thoughtfully designed. The Royal Park's rooms were clean and also well thought out, but I had thought, nothing that special. More than adequate, but less than awesome.Chuo-ku is a vast district, which includes Ginza. The hotel however, is right on the fringe of the district. It is, as many other guests have mentioned, very close to the Tokyo City Air Terminal, which does help to minimize the pain of coming in from Narita. However, you're not exactly in a happening area either by staying here.I will say this - my wife is expecting in a few months, and I was delighted to find that there is a nearby temple that is dedicated to easy childbirths. I walked over there and threw in a few coins as an offering. I had evidently gone on a big day (maybe it's always that busy)!Service was good. I had taken the advice of others, as I didn't have any free meals, and ate elsewhere. As mentioned, there's a good ramen place just beyond the temple on the main road. But I think if you want to stay in a nifty district of Tokyo, one can probably be closer. On the other hand, you are right on top of a subway station so the connections are good during the day.

We went on to book this hotel based on the tripadvisor ranking and feedbacks. Its a great hotel with great service. I cannot say enough about the service. We were checked in into smoking rooms but we were not told about it. After complaining, the desk staff reception who checked us in came up to the floor and apologize profusely. He also gave us a new room and transferred our bags.The breakfast buffet is ok. You get eggs, bacon, sausages, salmon, omelet, rice pilaf. The location is just ok, there is not much activity in the area but the hotel is connected to the subway station so you can easily go to any place you want. Ginza is 2 transfers away, so no problem there.The view we got from our room was not so good. If you look out the window, we see cars and an elevated expressway. We were usually out and at night we close the curtains.Its a good value for money hotel.

I have stayed at this hotel twice, and I plan to continue using it for all my business trips to Tokyo. The rooms are clean, well-stocked with amenities, and, by Tokyo standards, quite spacious. The staff is exceedingly polite.I always opt for the Executive Floors, for four reasons:1. The Executive Lounge offers and excellent selection of snacks and beverages, and is a great way to unwind after work (trade show work in my case).2. The executive rooms have the USEN440 Satellite Radio. Now this is not a major thing, I know, but if you've never experienced Japanese Satellite Radio, you are in for a treat. You would be hard pressed to name a type of music that they haven't devoted a 24 hour station to, not to mention soundscapes, language lessons, and Auld Lang Syne (the Japanese signal that a place is closing).3. The breakfast buffet is included, and it's a good buffet. Certainly better than anything that passes for a breakfast buffet in the States.4. Free Internet. If you are like me, and have to check your email nearly constantly, then this is worth it. When you add the buffet and the Internet access to the mix, the price difference between the executive level and the other floors starts to look far less imposing.I recommend stepping outside and eating at one of the neighborhood restaurants for most of your meals. There is a good selection of restaurants nearby that cost much less than the ones in the hotel. If you want to go really cheap, there's a pretty good ramen place a few doors away that will only cost you around 700 Yen.The hotel is located in the Chuo-ku district, which puts it a little off the beaten path. If you are the kind of person who likes to step out the door into full Tokyo commotion, then this is not the hotel for you. The hotel is close to two of the major subway lines, so it is easy to get nearly anywhere from the hotel. One of these lines is directly under the hotel. The other is just a few blocks away.If you are a business traveler, and you find yourself stuck at hotels a lot, eating breakfast buffet food, and logging onto the computer at all hours, the Royal Park Hotel is a wonderful way to make a trip to Tokyo a lot less fatiguing.

My husband and I stayed at the RPH during a 3-day trip to Tokyo. It's located in a more business district of Tokyo, but access to both metro and other train lines are walking distance. If you are looking to be in the middle of the scene, this is not the hotel for you. But if you want a nice base to explore Tokyo from, this is a solid choice.I was a little confused about the difference between the TAC (Tokyo Air Terminal) and Tokyo Central Train station. The TAC is a bus depot - it's attached to the RPH via a covered walk way. The busses to Narita are efficient (like every thing in Japan). However, if you take the train in from Narita, you will NOT arrive at the TAC, but rather at the Central Train Station. Its a 700 yen cab from the train station to the RPH.We were checked in promptly. I had requested a king/non-smoking room. The only one available was on the Executive Floor - so they kindly accommodated us. Except, they asked us not to use the executive lounge, which I thought was strange. The room was small (they had told us it would be at check-in) but for Japan hotels is was fine. Bed was comfortable. The bathroom mirror was heated so it never completely fogged up. The buffet downstairs has a huge selection of "western" food. Its pricey, but the food is good. "Great Scott" the basement bar is nice, quiet and a good spot for a drink if you arrive late. We had a little issue with the concierge initially, but when the assistant manager helped us - everything worked out.

The Royal Park was something I lucked into. It happened to be the first on my approved corporate list and I know why. To get there, I got off at Narita and walked up to the Airport Limousine desk and asked for the bus to Tokyo City Air Terminal (TCAT). 10 minutes later I was on the bus being offered tips by an returning ex-pat Japanese. Less than an hour later I arrived at TCAT, read the little map there (there's a direct-connect phone if you need help) walked around the corner and was in the hotel in 5 more minutes. The staff was gracious and I was whisked to the executive check-in. They got me a drink and checked me in while I relaxed. The ONLY thing that bothered me was that the girl who checked me in was adamant about taking my bag which was probably as heavy as she was. She refused a tip showed me the hotel room (which included a full computer, 200 channel cable radio including a station that plays ONLY the Rocky theme), free internet, nice desk, comfortable bed and the world-famous toilet seat in the pristine bathroom.The views from the top floors are great, I didn't eat in the restaurants, except for the included breakfast buffet, which is OK. However, there's a little dumpling place just down the street - take a right out of the hotel, go a block, look for the yellow standing sign on the sidewalk, excellent goyza dumplings - that I ate at several times. Several convenience stores around for late night / early morning drinks, rice balls, etc. made it ideal for me.Other than being mortified about a young lady carrying my bag, everything about my experience here was excellent.

Arrived on Christmas Day and stayed for 5 nights.The hotel is next to Tokyo City Air Terminal and it is very convenient to get to/ from Narita Airport. There is a subway station under the hotel and relatively it is easy to get around the city in the subway system. In my opinion, I found this is a quiet hotel which situated in a quieter part of the city. Some very nice charming little shops in the area. The hotel lobby was nice and I stayed in the executive floor. I must say that my first impression of my room was rather disappointing. The décor of the room was rather old fashioned and lighting was rather melancholy like. The tiles of the bathroom was very outdated. On the early hours on the 27th, the electricity of the entire hotel was turned off from 2 – 5 a.m. due to electrical maintenance work. The room was quite big and well equipped in the room. It was very thoughtful that they have a small humidifier in the room. The swimming pool was pretty nice but not luxurious. I checked out the gym and found out that one has to wear their sneakers in order to use their equipments?!? Good free breakfast was served on the 20th floor lounge. However I found the table was rather low for a comfortable meal.On the whole, I found the hotel comfortable and relaxing. The staffs were very friendly and helpful. If you were looking for a modern, exciting and cheerful hotel in a bubbling area, I’m afraid this hotel might not be a marvellous choice.

Agree with most of the other reviews - reasonable price, good sized room and great service. If there is a downside it is how expensive the hotel restaurants are.The simple solution? Walk out the front door of the hotel and eat at any of the many restaurants slong this main road. I had a great sushi meal at "Okaru" - a sushi train sort of place. I ate more sushi than I should have and paid less than $10 US. Anyone who tells you Tokyo is an expensive place to eat has not checked out the sushi, ramen (noodle) and yakitori restaurants away from Ginza.

I stayed in the Royal Park for 4 weeks on a lengthy business trip. In short, this is probably the finest business hotel I have ever stayed in. A few of the things I loved: a nicely decorated, spacious room; a PC with free internet access (in the room); a metro station directly under the hotel; a nice selection of glasses in the room (tall, tumbler, wine etc.); great food from the many hotel restaurants; a wide range of toiletries; a fantastic shower; free use of a DVD playeror BOSE music system on request; 8 types of pillow to choose from (!) and finally, impeccable service from all the staff. If you are planning a trip to Tokyo, for business or pleasure, bypass all the obvious chain hotels and give this little gem a try.

We (wife and two kids) just got back from Japan (Tokyo) and we stayed at The Royal Park Hotel (RPH) for five nights. We were in Tokyo over the Thanksgiving week. The reviews from this site greatly influenced my decision in picking RPH and I am glad that I did. Every positive thing that was written about RPH is true and then some. After a 13 hour flight from the U.S., we arrived in Narita and took the Airport Limousine Bus from Narita to the T-CAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal). The Terminal is located adjacent to the Royal Park Hotel. I was pleasantlysurprised to see a dedicated phone for RPH as soon as we got out of the bus. Within 3-5 minutes of calling the hotel to inform then of ourarrival, a bell hop who speaks English arrived with a luggage cart to help us back to the hotel. I am starting to feel good about this hotel.We arrived at the hotel, which is connected to the T-CAT, and are promptly led to the executive lounge on the 16th floor to check in. Ah, yes, the executive floors. I took the advice of those that recommended the executive floors and, yes, the extra cost was more than worth it for my family. You can’t beat the convenience of a free buffet breakfast on the 20th floor and snacks and cocktails on the 16th floor executive lounge in the evening. With the price of food anddrinks in Tokyo, the difference in price is more than worth it. Add tothat the pampering and free access to the gym, pool, sauna, wireless internet in the executive lounge, etc…Our room was very nice and roomy even by American standards. It was very comfortable and we were able to adjust the thermostat. We had an executive twin suite with two twin beds and an extra bed. We had to pay an additional 5,000 yen ($47 approx) per night for the extra bed. The cost of the extra bed is worth it considering the alternative of having to pay for an additional room. My kids are still very young so it was comfortable for us. The room had a Dell computer with free highspeed internet service. I was also able access the internet with my laptop by connecting it to the Ethernet wire.
