The kids were able to access their internet games on the Dell computer while the wife and were able to surf the net on the laptop. The bathroom was nice and comfortable. I had mentally prepared myself for a very small bathroom based on some of the previous reviews, but it was okay as long as it was one person in there at a time. The Toto toilet is the bomb. The toilet seat is warm and it comes with a “shower” and bidet. Getting around town is easy from RPH. There is a train line under the hotel and access to the Tokyo rail system is only 5 minutes walk from the hotel. We were able to buy 2 day tourist rail passes at the front desk. The front desk staff is very nice and they were able to give us good directions and tips on using the Tokyo Metro Rail. This is the most economic way to explore Tokyo. The trains run on time and there is a train every 5 minutes or so. We were able to go to Tokyo Disney, Ginza, Roppongi, Ueno, and Akihabara. There are several convenience stores and Japanese restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. There is a McDonalds within 5 minutes walk of the hotel. Overall, this is a very nice hotel for the price. The location is convenient for getting around Tokyo. The staff was very pleasant and nice and most of them speak English. I am recommending this hotel veryhighly and will definitely be staying at the RPH next time I am in Tokyo.

I have ever stayed at Royal Park Hotel twIce.I reserved exective floor each time.Room type was deluxe twin.It looks out of Asakusa and Ueno area .Though a vIew of room which I have stayed was not so good, Room was large and very comftable.Desk top Computer was equipped on the writing desk in advance.We could use complementary Internet access.There were stapler , highlighter and paper clips in desk.I think it is useful for person on business.Club lounge is located on the 16th floor.People help themselves to food and soft drink.I was pleased with changpaine .It's pretty good.20th floor is bar lounge,it looks out of Tokyo Tower.It's nice view.If you stay Club Floor,you can eat breakfast here,and you can stay by 3 p.m. Staff are very helpful.Though I stayed alone, I had a good time .Ｈotel is close to TCAT and hakozaki ramp.If you stay at Royal Park,parking is free of charge up to thirty hours.Ｔhere are not so many hotel in Tokyo that parking is free of charge.I often go to hotels by car. It's really good.Royal Park is one of my favorite hotel in Japan!I

Very spacious and well located.Warmly greeted after very long journey and reservation handled promptly & efficiently.Room was well equipped and very spacious for Tokyo.Vast selection of restaurants with various types of cuisine and a pre-dinner drink in the top floor bar afforded a superb view.Fitness facilities were also excellent.In every aspect service from all staff was attentive and courteous and what did help was good english by front-desk & bell captain for guides to city and locations.Scotts bar was a well used refuge but I would point out drinks are expensive!!Thoroughly enjoyed my stay and intend to return.

We plan to spend a week in Tokyo with my wife, and we use tripadvisor to choose the hotel (note that The Mandarin was unavailable, so this hotel was the best ranking one available).Practically, as it has been previously written, the location of the hotel is perfect to visit the city. Not because the hotel has a central situation, but because it is right on a subway line (you take the elevator and you are in the subway!), which will enable you to spend 30 minutes maximum to access the main quarters of Tokyo. To go to the Hotel from the Narita Airport is very convenient: the Hotel is 30 meters close to the Airport Bus Limousine (and the time between Narita and RPH is about one hour).We booked a deluxe room with King bed. The room was spacious with classy furniture, the bed was very comfortable, and we had a desk with a computer and free internet connection: so you don't have to go to a cyber coffee or to a dedicated lounge, you can surf directly in the room for free, which is very cool. The bathroom was rather small compared to the size of the room, but very effective to use, pressure, electronic toilets, and a large bunch of amenities. The view on the city was beautiful even if I think other side (north) may present a better point view. The most enjoyable part of the stay in fact was the staff, very kind and ready to help for anything. During our stay we ask the desk to check if an excursion we had book on our own via internet outside the city was confirmed. In fact they had lost our reservation and the hotel has managed to arrange everything beyond our expectations. I have traveled in many hotels, and some times in better star-rated ones, I have never seen such dedication and kindness...The royal park hotel enable us to fully enjoy our stay in Tokyo, and I think it's an ideal place to discover the city with no worry at all !

One of the main reasons I stayed at this hotel was because of the amount of reviews it recieved. Everything you read is correct! The hotel is great! It has a train station on the lower level of the hotel! Easy way to travel, and staff is very nice! They upgraded my husband and I to a higher quality room because we were honeymooners and they gave us free breakfast coupons. I also read on the previous reviews that when you become an i prefer member you recieve free internet access as well. Before you book your stay become a member so you get that benefit. I really had no complaints about this hotel. It's Clean, Friendly, and Convinient!

We had a truly wonderful stay at the Royal Park. This was our first visit to Japan (and Asia for that matter) and we wanted something very comfortable, and accessible by the Limo Bus, in Tokyo. We decided on the Royal Park based on reviews here and on the looks of their website and couldn't have been happier.We decided to stay in an executive room so we could have access to the free breakfast buffet and cocktail hour, so we arrived at the hotel and promptly made our way to the 16th floor for check-in. The employee couldn't have been friendlier or more polite, and our room, on the 18th floor, was just gorgeous. We had a huge window with amazing views of Tokyo lit up at night. As we arrived at our room the maid was just finishing up turndown service, complete with a little origame box with mints in it. The beds were very comfortable and the bathroom had lots of great amenities. We enjoyed turning on traditional Japanese music on the radio and then being able to pipe it into the bathroom for when we were soaking in the tub. The breakfast was amazing; one of the best I've had on my travels. It is free for those staying on the executive floors and is filled with a huge array of foods; breakfast meats, cereals, potatoes, French pastries (the brioche was delicious) and danishes, an omelette station, various fruits, and fresh-squeezed juices. All of this and amazing views of Tokyo from the windows of the 20th floor. The hotel itself is beautiful, with a lush lobby, and there is access to the subway from the bottom level of the hotel, making getting around a snap. We loved the Royal Park and could not be happier with the room, the amenities and the services.Tracy

Cannot recommend this hotel highly enough - a jewel for travellers to Tokyo. We spent our last night in Japan there after touring the country for two weeks, and could not have been happier with the experience, from check-in to the in-room amenities, this is a first class hotel suitable for tourists and business travellers alike. The proximity to the TCAT makes it a breeze for arrivals and departures for Narita and Haneda, and the Hanzomon subway line is almost literally outside the front door - which makes up for the fact that there is little in the way of dining or sight-seeing right around the premises. Great facilities and amazing staff.

I have just returned from four nights in Tokyo and have to commend the Royal Park HotelThe hotel is attached by an overhead walkway to the TCAT - Tokyo City Air Terminal. This is where all the "Friendly Limousine" bus services to and from the both Narita and Henada airports terminate.Meaning having spent a stress free hour getting into the city, you dont then have to join the masses on the Tokyo subway getting to your hotel (cost of bus to Narita Y2900) The Underground station under the Hotel is Z10 on Hanzomon line which with a two day Tokyo Metro pass we found to be ideal for getting anywhere.On arrival we where sent to the the executive check in on the 16th Floor. I would recomend you look at paying the difference for this as it includes not only a complimentry breakfast served in the 20th Floor Sky bar , free internet access in your room, free access to the Pool and gym but also access to a three hour complimentry bar each evening in the Executive lounge.The room was small by international standards but this is the norm in Tokyo and didnt detract from the experiance.The staff in the executive lounge spoke perfect English and where always keen to assist providing everything from Train times to rudimentry Japaneese lessonsSo if your heading for Tokyo I have no doubt you could do much worse than this hotel

We stayed at the Royal Park Hotel in July 2007. I would recommend this hotel for anyone and I would stay here again anytime.We followed the advise of another TA member and joined their "club" (free of charge) and we decided to upgrade our room to the executive level. We received a great suprise when we arrived - as the room rate was dropped by 30%. The executive floor rooms offer free full breakfast (western and japanese style), free access to the in-house gym, executive lounge access with complimentary happy-hour nightly with a well stocked bar (I had champagne every night). I completed their club application, which they had to mail to me, and in order to cut-down on processing time I decided to scan the application and emailed it to them. They had our membership package, with club card, ready for us upon check-in. Check-in for the executive floors is handled at the executive floor lounge.It's a nice upscale hotel with over 1/2 doz restaurants. They have an in-house gym with good equipment and a yoga/stretching room as well. I don't remember seeing a pool. The provide in-house massages (my husband swears is the best massage he's ever had).The staff was wonderful - at every level (not just executive floors). They were caring and very helpful (suggesting nearby restaurants), providing customized maps for us.Rooms are well appointed with the usual amenities you expect in an upscale hotel (robes, slippers, minibar etc)Restaurants; they have several restaurants and lounges throughout the hotel. Some more upscale than others - all with different cuisines.There is a subway entrance attached to the hotel and across the street is the Tokyo Air Terminal Bus Station - which also has a corridor connecting it to this hotel)At our departure, we needed to get a bus to Narita Tokyo airport and they had 2 staff members assist us to the bus terminal (access directly from the hotel). Again, if you can upgrade to the executive floors - the perks are worth the price and may actually save you money if you add up all that you'd have to pay for if you stayed in the other floors. Make sure to join their club to get a room discount and perks.Enjoy.

We stayed in the RPH for five nights in July and found the overall hotel excellant.As we were travelling with our children I requetsed two non smoking rooms adjacent to each other - we got interconnecting rooms which was great. I requested an early check in - we did have to wait an hour for the room, but it gave us time to have something to eat before having a sleep after a long flight from Ireland.I joined the Summit club, of which the hotel is a member (I actually booked the stay with them, as their rates were a lot better than the hotel itself) and was happily surprised with a gift of a bottle of wine per room for being a I" Prefer" member. As a member one is also entitled to free use of the pool, sauna, gym. The link to the Summit Group is on the hotel web site.The buffet breakfast was very good and gave everyone an oppertunity to sample japanese breakfast food as well as the usual western food. The one issue I have is that I would have loved a large cup of coffee in the mornings....not small cups that have to be refilled over and over again.With all the choices in Tokyo, we didn't eat dinner in the hotel so I cannot comment on the restaurants.One of the main reasons for choosing the hotel was the swimming pool. We were staying duing the rain that accompanied the recent typhoon, so my daughter made great use of the pool in the evenings since we didn't fancy walking around in the rain after a day of doing just that.The hotel is connected directly to the metro, so accessing places is very easy. There were always taxi's outside also should one wish to use them. And of course the hotel is beside the airport express bus station (TCAT) so the trip from the airport was easy.I would recommend this hotel to both business and leisure travellers.

My wife and I had an unexpected two day stay in Tokyo and were pressed to find a good, reasonably-priced hotel in a hurry. We found this place via Expedia and read a lot of good reviews at TripAdvisor and were convinced. We were happy to find that the praise was well deserved. The place was well located next to the downtown Air Terminal (which made it easy for us to get to and from Narita Airport via an express, direct bus). The room itself was very clean and comfortable. The staff were very professional and helpful. All-in-all, it was a great value, a great location, and a gem of a hotel. We highly recommend it.

Stayed 5 nights at RPH at end July. I had 2 separate reservations due to different room rates - I called the hotel directly to book a single room for the first night and used the corporate deal for the rest. The rate showed on the website was cheaper than the one which the hotel offered. The reservation staff who could speak native English explained that they were under different reservation quotas (The hotel itself and Summit Hotel Group Reservation), and she could not give me the rate showed on the website. I expressed my disagreement and finally she offered me a rate which was lower than the one I found on the website and with BBF (I thought it's 21000 yen inclusive tax versus 22000 yen inclusive tax without BBF).I arrived at about 11pm in the evening. Check-in was smooth and fast (within 5 minutes). The single room was huge, clean and with a good quality of double bed (about 4 feet width). I also found a set of "Shiseido" facial product, a bag of Japanese hot spring powder and a set of toiletries for men at the bathroom. Every room had a "Dell" desktop with TV monitor for the guest use. I moved to the another room with twin beds next day. But the room size was slightly smaller than the single room I got last night, particularly it's with 2 standard single beds. There's only a set of men toiletries at the bathroom. Besides, set up was the same as single room. Internet access was fast and smooth. I used my own laptop and hotel's desktop somtimes if I just wanted to check something on the web and update news. Room service was fast (within 20 minutes) and the meal was not too bad. They also tried to fulfill our request of "French Fries" which they did not offer. I found they did not charge internet access on my bill, it's probably it's included on my corporate deal. But I am so happy to get a in-room computer so that I can access it whenever I wanted to. Concierge provided excellent service - wrapping service, helping us bring our luggages to the T-CAT Terminal. Overall, RPH is a standard business hotel with a touch of surprise. The only downside is it's not close to the shopping areas, such as Ginza, Shinjuka and Shibuya.

Real luxury. I cannot fault this hotel. My room was spotlessly clean and very confortable. The staff were great and my meal in the French Restaurant was exellent. I cannot really comment on the location as I was only on a stop over. The price seemed very reasonable.

Me and my partner stayed for a week at the executive level. The included lounge and breakfast were well work the extra cost. The airport shuttle and metro entrance both situated directly under the hotel greatly Simplified our trips to all parts of the city.Wifi was free in the executive lounge but not available elsewhere. Executive rooms all have free broadband (network cable is in the room).

One of the best hotels that I have stayed in. Beautiful building, nicely appointed rooms with attention to details. Very courteous and sophisticated staff. Great food service. very convinient location - next to bunch of shopping and bus station.

My husband and I had a wonderful stay at the Royal Park Hotel in October 2006. We stayed on the executive floor, which I highly recommend. The front desk staff promptly guided us to another floor where we were smoothly and quickly checked in. The room was spacious by Tokyo standards. Our room had a seating area with a love seat and coffee table. The decor was modern and comfortable. There was also a well-lit vanity. The bathroom was a very decent size with a modern shower/bath. Breakfast for those staying on the executive floor was on one of the upper floors and had a very nice buffet and an omelet chef. Breakfastservice was prompt and friendly and the food was quite good. The location is also worth mentioning. It is in a very "shitamachi" type area--a pleasant, old Tokyo neighborhood. The Suitengumae metro stop on the Hanzomon Line is less than a five-minute walk. It is neither central like Tokyo Station or Ginza, but neither is it too far from the major sites. We found the location to be convenient and quiet at the same time.

My partner and I stayed here for 4 nights on our most recent trip to Tokyo. I am so glad we did! The hotel was attached to the TCAT (Tokyo City Air Terminal) which has direct limousine bus service from Narita airport (50 minutes). We upgraded to the Executive Floor which gave us a nice room on the 18th floor with sweeping views of the city skyline. The Executive Floor option, which was a few dollars more than a standard room, gave us access to the Executive Lounge on the 16th floor. They have a full-time concierge there who was very helpful and very friendly. We had access to a full American-style breakfast in the morning on the 20th floor (complimetary) which included a stunning view and cooked-to-order eggs and good coffee! In the evening, they had small appetizers and a nice selection of cocktails and wines available for you. The room was small, but the ammenities were nice, including an in-room personal computer with free internet access (wireless was available if you opt to use your own laptop -free too!). The service and staff was excellent. Always a smile and a bow. As a gay couple, I never once felt uncomfortable and the Japanese went out of their way to make certain we were comfortable as well. The hotel is on the Hanzomon line with easy connections to all the other lines and with the subway in the basement of the hotel, travel was very easy. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a great hotel in a great location! Would definitely stay again.

My wife and myself have just spent six nights at The Royal Park Hotel. From start to finish we had superb service throughout the hotel. Admitted it's not the cheapest, but I think for Tokyo it represented good value. Very well positioned, with direct access to the metro system, and direct coach link to Narita airport.We had an exective double, (two flat screen tv's!!) 24hr free internet access. The only complaint I can think of is the small size of the bathroom, but the high standard of bathroom toiletries and towels more than made up for it's size. (and the loo seat!! OMG!) I would highly recommend this hotel.

Very easy to get to from Narita as the Express Bus station (connected to the Royal Park) is first stop (about an hour ride though). The rooms are small (as you expect in Tokyo) but everything you need is there.It is very convenient for travel as the lower ground floor leads direct to the tube station (it is on the purple line, the tokyo metro is surprisingly easy to navigate - all stations are numbered)The bathroom is small but good - the shower bath is a seperate enclosed wet room, with the WC and sink in an adjoining unit. It works quite well. Bed was comfy, good range of lighting. You get a PC and free internet in your room. Very useful.I was in an exec club room and was checked in on the exec floor. A nice touch. The exec floor was open for three or so hours in the evning and a good range of drinks and snacks were available. Breakfast was included on the top floor, a great buffet with friendly and helpful staff. The view from here is good, right over tokyo and on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji.The hotel has a number of restaurants - the only one of which i tried was the chinese which was superb!Staff really went the extra mile, from help with transport, to supllying free painkillers in the middle of the night when i had a searing toothache (bufferin, very good). I needed help to print and fax in the business centre and i felt they did a really excellent job of making you feel welcome. Only downside was the pool area which was a bit 'clinical'. They made me wear a swim cap, but hey ho.....Would return without hesitation. The rates are really rather good for what you get. If money no object, try the mandarin or the park hyatt, but the royal park represents a very good choice for the price.

My husband and I, we spent 5 nights at the Royal Park Hotel in Tokyo and we will surely come again. The hotel is in a great positition, very well connected both with Narita airport (by the Airport Limousine service, a bus that stops exactly in front of the hotel) and every other part of Tokyo, since there is a passage to subway (Suitengue station) at the B2 floor.The decor is very accurated and the service is really efficient.Our room was spacious and very welcoming and we didn`t pay too much considering the normal prices in Tokyo. The breakfast buffet was very rich and pleasant. We would suggest to dinner at the restaurant on the 20th floor, in front of a superbe view of the town and trying the emotion of admiring the chefs preparring your dishes just under your eyes...Finally, we would consider our staying as a wonderful experience.

I stayed here for four nights recently on business and was impressed by the enthusiastic, helpful and prompt service of the staff and the hotel's top-notch amenities.As the other reviews point out the Royal Park is convenient to the Narita airport bus and the Suitengu-mae and Ningyocho subway stations, and not too far from Tokyo station where the shinkansen stops.The rooms feature a TV/PC system that allows free internet browsing and some e-mail functionality (although server restrictions did not permit me to respond to emails). Wireless is also available for a fee. The hotel features a large pool, fitness club, sauna, etc, albeit with additional usage fees attached.On upper floors you get a great view of the Tokyo cityscape. The rooms are large, comfortable and well-equipped, and the breakfast selections are terrific. The neighborhood around the hotel has plenty of places to eat, drink and buy stuff. For business it's a solid choice. For vacationers, it's also fine, but not exactly in the midst of sightseeing territory. The benefit of being right at the Narita bus terminal is probably worth this, though, expecially for first-time visitors.

We stayed here for seven nights on the executive level, and it was well worth it. We had a terrific view of the Sumida River, an excellent breakfast every morning, access to the lounge for drinks all day and evening cocktails and finger foods in the evenings all included. Plus, there is a terrific udon house directly across the street for cheap late night eats too. The restaurants seemed expensive but we didn't utilize them (didn't really need to). The hotel is connected to the Suitengu-mae subway stop which is very convenient. It's proximity (directly across the street from) to the Tokyo City Air Terminal, TCAT (limosine bus service stops here) from Narita make for convenient travel to/from the airport.

I love Tokyo almost as much as I love Paris. One of the most difficult things about Tokyo, though, is getting to and from the airport without: a. winding through the rail system after a 14 hour flight; or b. blowing your budget on a cab.The Royal Park Hotel is across the street from the Tokyo City Air Terminal (T-CAT), where buses take you directly to and from Narita or Haneda for a mere 2900 yen in less than an hour. And the hotel itselt is very VERY nice, with well-appointed rooms, free computers, terrific concierge, lots of (expensive) restaurants, brilliant service, in-room massage, executive business services, and direct access to the Tokyo Metro, where you can get anywhere in the great city within a few minutes.My only regret about the Royal Park Hotel is the flock of American tourists you will invariably find (not that I blame them) in the lobby - it's so easy to stay there without any knowledge of the language, that the Royal Park has to work very hard to remain Japanese. Go downstairs for a reasonable lunch at the Sushi Bar. Yes, it's in the hotel, but this is filled with Japanese businessmen. It's one VERY Japanese sushi bar with some of the best cuts of Toro in all of Japan. There you'll see how the Royal Park is not just an English-Speaking hotel.

We stayed here for three nights in April of 2006. It was one of the best hotels we have ever stayed at, and we have stayed at many very good hotels.This is not billed as a five-star hotel, but rather more of a business hotel. But the ambience, decor, dining, and the service and kindness of the staff made it a very special experience and perfect for us as tourists.After a long day of Tokyo sightseeing it was a very calming oasis to come home to. Highly recommended.L & A, CT

Stayed at this hotel in April. This is indeed a solid, 2nd tier business hotel, but it’s not a top tier, best in class hotel. It’s adjacent to the bus to/from Narita, just a luggage cart away. It has native English speakers at the desk, as well as English speaking Japanese staff at the desk. Hotel has some really nice restaurants as well. Each room has a TV/comp monitor, and a Dell desktop under the desk.On the other hand this is NOT a top of the line luxury hotel. While it certainly is viable option in the USD 200/night, that is what one basically gets. I am sure going at higher price levels one may get more too. It feels very much like a Hilton room, as opposed to say “the Ritz”.

What an amazing experience. . . executive suites are the only way to stay. I was reluctant to spending the money just for 16th floor check-in and an included breakfast. It was the best decision I could've made. The service at Royal Park is amazing. I did not pass by one person that did not greet me with a Good Morning, Good Afternoon, or Good Evening. . . The staff is amazing, the room is even more amazing - I felt like I was in a hip little studio apartment in downtown Tokyo. I didn't want to go sightseeing because I loved my room so much.The 16th floor staff for executive check-in is fantastic. The lady that was there was so helpful and accomodating. . . any questions I had or directions that I needed, she was on top of it. I think this group goes above and beyond what is expected out of a normal four or five star hotel.I would also like to recommend the shiatsu massage services. Awesome. It was the perfect end to two weeks of business trip and a perfect beginning to four days of vacation in Tokyo. I just can't say enough about how wonderful this hotel was.Location is perfect if you like local culture and exploring the city. Breakfast is great on the days you don't want to eat tofu and salmon - great omelettes and delicious fruit. Next time I am in Tokyo - I won't stay anywhere else.PS Ladies - you get your own private check-in (if you're not in the executive suites) and a special gift bag just for female travelers!

Truly a 5 star hotel.Most convenient if you fly to Narita, Tokyo bacause the Tokyo City Air Terminal is right next to it.Don't worry about huge luggage. There is a toll free telephone on the ground floor of City Terminal, which connect you to the Bell Captian and all your bags are looked after.Stayed there in Nov/Dec last year, very much impressed and I recommended this hotel to a couple who had a stopover in Tokyo for a few days in February this year.They loved the hotel for its very high standard of service, luxurious room and convenient location.I will recommend to anyone who doesn't speak Japanese bacause staff speak very good English not just "(some pegion)English spoken" and deal with your request professionally.Not the cheapet but you pay what you get.

what makes all the difference to this hotel is the views from the business bar at the top.if you get the chance, you should take time to sit a while, mimosa in hand, and look out over the bright lights of the big city below.i also had the priviledge of an aerial view of a thunderstorm over tokyo - an amazing experience just when i thought the hotel couldn't get any better!amenities and food are good (the lunchtime teppanyaki menu is a very reasonable treat) and service is excellent.
